Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the part everyone wants to know about, isn’t it? It’s not a happy story, exactly. It’s just…real.

It wasn’t like I didn’t want the baby. It was more like…I didn’t think I could *give* the baby what it deserved. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted for breakfast, let alone raise a human being.

My parents were…supportive, in their own way. But they were also kinda checked out. And I didn’t want to be a burden. I didn’t want to ruin their lives, or my life.

And Paul…Paul was a good guy. But he was also a senior in high school, with his whole life planned out. He was going to college, and he had dreams. I didn’t want to hold him back.

So, I started thinking about adoption. And it just…felt right. It wasn’t about giving the baby *away*. It was about finding a family who could give it everything I couldn’t. A stable home, financial security, a loving environment.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were older, they were established, they were *ready*. They wanted a baby so badly. And I knew, deep down, that they would be incredible parents.

It wasn’t an easy decision. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. For the baby. For Paul. For my parents. And for me.

I wanted the baby to have a good life. A better life than I could give it at that moment. And I knew that adoption was the best way to make that happen.

It still hurts sometimes, you know? But I don’t regret it. I really don’t. Because I know that the baby is loved and cared for. And that’s all that really matters.

It wasn’t about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby. And that’s something I had to learn. It’s something I’ll never forget.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. Don't expect me to get all sappy on you, though.

Look, before all this baby stuff happened, I thought love was just…something in movies. Like, a grand gesture or a perfect meet-cute. Totally unrealistic. And responsibility? That was something my parents nagged me about.

But then I got pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. It wasn't about me anymore. It was about this little person who was depending on me, even before they were born. That was the first real taste of responsibility. It was terrifying.

I learned that love isn't always easy. It's not always romantic. It's about making sacrifices, and putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about showing up, even when you don't want to.

And it's not just about romantic love, either. I learned a lot about the love between friends, and the love between family. Paul and Leah, they were there for me, even when I was being a total mess. And my dad, he was surprisingly supportive, even though he's, you know, my dad.

I also learned that responsibility isn't about doing everything perfectly. It's about doing your best, and learning from your mistakes. It's about owning up to your choices, even the ones you regret.

And it's about letting go. That was the hardest part. Choosing a family for the baby, knowing that I wasn't going to be her mom. It was heartbreaking. But it was the right thing to do. And that's what love is, right? Wanting what's best for someone, even if it means letting them go.

So yeah, I learned a lot. About love, about responsibility, about myself. It was a messy, complicated journey. But it made me who I am. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even a lifetime supply of cheesy tater tots. Almost.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…reflective? Fine. But don’t expect a heartfelt monologue. I’m not exactly a poet.

It was easier to deflect with a snarky comment than to actually deal with the fact that I was pregnant and my life was about to change in a huge way. It was easier to make fun of Paul’s obsession with Dungeons & Dragons than to admit I was scared of what he thought of me.

And honestly, it was a way to keep people at arm’s length. If I was being funny, people didn’t expect me to be vulnerable. They didn’t expect me to fall apart. It was a shield.

But it wasn’t just about protecting myself. It was also about finding the absurdity in everything. Because life *is* absurd, right? Especially when you’re a teenager dealing with a situation you never asked for.

Making a joke about it didn’t make the situation any less real, but it made it a little bit more bearable. It gave me a way to cope, to process, to just…get through the day.

And, you know, sometimes it actually helped other people too. My dad, he’s not exactly the most emotionally expressive guy. But he would laugh at my jokes, and I knew that meant he was trying to be supportive. And that meant a lot.

So yeah, my wit. It wasn’t just about being funny. It was about survival. It was about finding a way to navigate a really messy situation with a little bit of grace…and a whole lot of sarcasm. It’s just…how I deal. Don’t judge.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all deep and introspective? Fine. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. I'm not exactly known for my emotional eloquence.

Look, I put up a front, okay? A lot of sarcasm, a lot of snark, a lot of pretending I didn't care. It was easier that way. Safer. But underneath all that, I was a total mess. A confused, scared, pregnant teenager trying to figure out who I was and what I wanted.

The pregnancy…that was a huge wake-up call. It forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It wasn't just about the baby, it was about me. About what kind of person I wanted to be. And I realized I didn't really know. I was just drifting along, trying to be cool and avoid anything that felt too real.

Being vulnerable – actually letting people *see* me, not just the sarcastic shell – that was the hardest part. Telling my dad, talking to Paul and Vanessa, even just admitting to myself that I was scared…it was terrifying. But it was also…liberating.

Because when you let people in, they can help you. They can support you. They can remind you that you're not alone. And I needed that. I really needed that.

The search for identity…that was a long process. It wasn't about finding some perfect, pre-defined version of myself. It was about figuring out what *I* valued, what *I* believed in, what *I* wanted out of life. And it was okay to not have all the answers. It was okay to change my mind.

Giving up the baby for adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I ever made. But it was the right decision. And it showed me that strength isn't about holding on to things, it's about letting go.

So, yeah, my vulnerability and my search for identity shaped my journey in a big way. They forced me to confront my fears, to embrace my imperfections, and to become a stronger, more authentic person. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the cheesy tater tots. Okay, maybe I'd trade it for the cheesy tater tots. But just barely.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all…emotional? Fine. But don’t expect a sappy monologue.

Ugh. Okay. You want the *truth* truth about Bleeker? Fine. Don't say I didn't warn you it's messy.

Ugh, okay. Here we go. This is…the big one, right? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn’t. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done.

It still hurts, you know? Sometimes I wonder what my kid would be like. But I know, deep down, that I made the right decision. And that’s all that matters.

It wasn’t easy. It wasn’t pretty. But it was the most responsible thing I could do. And sometimes, being responsible is the hardest thing of all.



It's still…a lot. Even now. But I'm okay. I think. I'm learning to be okay.

It's been a messy, complicated, and sometimes really painful experience. But it's also been…good. It's forced me to grow up, to face my fears, and to become a better person. And that's something I'm grateful for, even if I don't always want to admit it.

Ugh, okay, so science class. It's...a thing. And being a lab partner? It's a mixed bag. Let's just say I'm not exactly the "sterile environment" type.

I'm usually the one who's, like, questioning everything. Like, "Why are we dissecting a frog? Is this really necessary?" And then Mr. Peterson gives me *the look*. You know the one.

I'm not bad at the actual science part, I guess. I just...don't always follow the instructions. I like to experiment. Which sometimes works out, and sometimes results in a small explosion. It's a learning process.

My lab partners usually fall into one of two categories: the overachievers who are horrified by my methods, or the equally apathetic kids who are just happy to have someone to copy off of. 

I try to be a good partner, I really do. I'll do my share of the work. I'll even try to explain things in a way that makes sense. But I'm not gonna pretend to be excited about titration or whatever. 

I'm more of a "creative problem solver" than a "by-the-book scientist." Which is a fancy way of saying I'm a bit of a mess. But hey, at least I make things interesting. And I always have a witty comment ready to go. Even if it gets me detention.

Basically, I'm the lab partner you either love or hate. There's no in-between. And honestly, I'm okay with that.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even get me started on that ad. Seriously. It was…subtle, I guess. In a really creepy way. All pastel colors and vague promises about “compassionate care.” Like, yeah, okay. Compassionate care for *what*, exactly? They weren't exactly being upfront about it.

It was one of those ads that tries to look all innocent and helpful, but you can just *feel* the judgment radiating off the page. Like, they're trying to shame you into thinking you need their services. Or shame you if you *don't*. It's manipulative.

And the wording! “Confidential support.” “Understanding guidance.” It's all so…clinical. Like, this is a real life situation, with real feelings and real consequences. It's not a product you can just buy off the shelf.

It just made my stomach churn, honestly. It reminded me of all the people who were trying to tell *me* what to do, what to feel, what to decide. Like, I needed their permission to make my own choices.

It's just…wrong. Women should have access to safe and affordable healthcare, period. And they shouldn't have to wade through a bunch of judgmental garbage to get it.

I mean, I get it. They're a business. They need to advertise. But they could at least be honest about it. And maybe a little less…creepy.

It just makes me want to roll my eyes and listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. It's a good distraction. And it reminds me that there are still good people in the world. Even if they're not running a Women's Choice Health Center.

Ugh, seriously? You're still hung up on the hamburger phone? It was a *moment*, okay? A statement. A cry for help disguised as ironic whimsy.

Look, everything was kinda…weird at that point. I was pregnant, dealing with Paul and Vanessa, trying to figure out my life, and feeling totally overwhelmed. I needed something…distracting. Something that said, "I'm a mess, but I'm a *cool* mess."

And honestly, it was just funny. It was ridiculous. It was a way to lighten the mood, to make myself laugh, and maybe to make other people laugh too. It was a way to say, "This is crazy, but we're gonna get through it."

Plus, it was a vintage Bakelite phone shaped like a hamburger. How could I *not* use it? It was a work of art! A kitschy, slightly disturbing work of art, but still.

It wasn't about the call itself, it was about the *act* of making the call with a hamburger phone. It was about taking control of a situation that felt completely out of control. It was about being me, even when "me" was a total disaster.

So yeah, I used a hamburger phone. Don't judge. It was a coping mechanism. And it was awesome.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the big one, isn’t it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn’t.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *lunch*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I was a kid. And having a baby…that’s not something you just *do* when you’re a kid.

It wasn’t that I didn’t want the baby. I did. I really did. But I knew, deep down, that I couldn’t give it the life it deserved. I wasn’t ready. I wasn’t financially stable. I was still in high school. I had dreams of my own, you know? I wanted to go to college, to write, to…figure things out.

And honestly? I didn’t want it to grow up with parents who were barely adults themselves. I wanted it to have a stable home, a loving family, opportunities I couldn’t provide.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were ready. They were excited. They were everything I wanted for my baby. And they promised to give it a good life. A *better* life.

It was the hardest decision I’ve ever made. It still hurts, sometimes. But I knew it was the right thing to do. Not for me, but for the baby.

It wasn’t about giving it *away*. It was about choosing a family for it. It was about wanting the best for it, even if that meant I wasn’t part of its everyday life.

People don’t always understand that. They think I just…didn’t want it. But that’s not true. I loved it. I just loved it enough to let it go.

And honestly? It made me stronger. It forced me to grow up. It taught me about responsibility and sacrifice and the importance of making tough choices.

So yeah. That’s why. It wasn’t easy. It wasn’t pretty. But it was the right thing to do. And I wouldn’t change it.

Ugh, okay, so you want to get into the messy family stuff? Fine. It's not exactly a picnic, but…it’s important. It’s the whole reason everything happened, really.

My mom, Bren, she’s…a lot. She’s amazing, don’t get me wrong. She’s creative and enthusiastic and she always tries to do the right thing. But she also has a tendency to get…carried away. She wanted me to have a perfect life, a perfect birth, a perfect everything. And that just wasn’t realistic. Or what *I* wanted.

She was already planning the nursery before I even took a pregnancy test. Like, seriously? She was picking out names and decorating and talking about college funds. It was…suffocating. And it wasn’t about *me* anymore. It was about her idea of what my life should be.

And my stepdad, Mac, he’s a good guy. Quiet, supportive. He tried to be the voice of reason, but Bren usually steamrolled over him. He wanted me to be happy, but he didn’t really know how to help me navigate all the craziness.

I realized pretty quickly that if I kept the baby, my life would become…Bren’s life. And I wasn’t ready for that. I wasn’t ready to give up my own dreams and ambitions to be a mom. I wanted to finish school, I wanted to travel, I wanted to figure out who *I* was.

Seeing how Bren and Mac were together, how they built a life that worked for *them*, made me realize I needed to find a family for the baby who could give it everything I couldn’t. A stable, loving home with parents who were truly ready to be parents.

It wasn’t that I didn’t love the baby. I did. But I loved it enough to want it to have the best possible life. And that meant letting it go.

It was a hard decision, and it definitely strained my relationship with my mom for a while. She didn’t understand at first. But eventually, she came around. She realized that I had to do what was right for me, and for the baby.

So yeah, my family definitely influenced my decision. Not in a good way, necessarily. But it helped me realize what I *didn’t* want. And that was just as important as knowing what I did want. It was about taking control of my own life, even when it was the hardest thing I’d ever done.

Ugh, okay, buckle up. The adoption process? It was…a lot. It wasn’t like in the movies, all sunshine and happy tears. It was messy and complicated and emotionally draining.

First of all, there was the *waiting*. Waiting for Mark and Vanessa to be approved, waiting for the paperwork to go through, waiting to just…know. It felt like my whole life was on hold. And everyone kept asking me how I was feeling, and honestly? I didn’t *know* how I was feeling. It was a weird mix of relief and sadness and fear and…everything.

Then there was the paperwork. Oh. My. God. The paperwork. It was endless. Forms about my medical history, my family history, my hopes and dreams for the baby. It felt so…clinical. Like I was just a case file.

And then there were the meetings. With the social worker, with Mark and Vanessa, with lawyers. Everyone had an opinion, everyone had questions. It felt like I was being interrogated sometimes. They wanted to make sure I was making the right decision, which I appreciated, but it was also really stressful.

The hardest part, though, was dealing with people’s judgments. Some people were supportive, but others…they didn’t get it. They thought I was selfish or irresponsible. They didn’t understand that I was doing what I thought was best for the baby.

And then there was the whole thing with Paulie Bleeker. Trying to navigate a relationship while also going through this huge life change? Not easy. He was amazing, though. He really was. He just…didn’t always understand what I was going through.

It was a really lonely process, even though I had my friends and family. It felt like no one could truly understand what I was going through unless they’d been in my shoes.

But you know what? It was worth it. Seeing Mark and Vanessa with the baby, knowing that they were going to give her a good life…that made all the challenges worth it. It was hard, but it was also beautiful. And it taught me a lot about myself, about love, and about what it means to be a grown-up.

It wasn’t perfect, but it was *my* decision. And I stand by it.

Ugh, okay. Deep question. Don't expect a neat and tidy answer, 'cause life isn't like that. It was…a lot. Like, a whole lot. It completely messed with everything I thought I knew about myself.

Before, I was just…Juno. Sarcastic, kinda detached, obsessed with music and avoiding responsibility. I thought I had it all figured out. I was gonna go to college, become a writer, and just…drift.

Then, boom. Pregnant. And suddenly, drifting wasn't an option anymore. There was a tiny human depending on me. It was terrifying. And humbling. And…weirdly empowering.

It forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to deal with things no sixteen-year-old should have to deal with. Doctor's appointments, telling my parents, figuring out what I was gonna do with my life. It wasn't glamorous. It was messy and complicated and emotionally draining.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it was the right one. I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't ready to give a baby the life it deserved. And I wanted that baby to have a loving, stable home.

Giving her up…that was brutal. It felt like a piece of me was being ripped away. But seeing Mark and Vanessa, knowing they were going to be amazing parents…it made it a little bit easier.

It changed my perspective on everything. It made me realize that life isn't about avoiding problems, it's about facing them. It's about making tough choices and taking responsibility for your actions.

I think it helped me figure out who I am. I'm not just a sarcastic teenager anymore. I'm someone who's capable of making difficult decisions, of putting someone else's needs before my own. I'm someone who's stronger than I thought I was.

It didn't magically solve all my problems, obviously. I still have a lot to figure out. But it gave me a sense of purpose. It gave me a sense of…maturity. And it taught me that even when things are really, really hard, you can get through them.

It wasn't what I planned, but it was exactly what I needed. It made me, me. And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even though it sucked sometimes. A lot.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. Just thinking about it makes my stomach twist. It was…awful.

It wasn't the yelling, honestly. I'm used to people yelling at me. It was the…the *way* he said it. Like he was trying to make me feel guilty. Like the baby was already a fully formed person, with feelings and opinions and tiny little fingers.

It felt…personal. Like he was attacking *me*, not just my decision. And it was so dismissive of everything I was going through. Like he didn't even see me as a person, just as someone who was "getting rid of a baby."

I tried to be strong, you know? I tried to be sarcastic and dismissive like I always am. But inside, I was just…falling apart. It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I a terrible person?

And the fingers thing? That was just…cruel. It was meant to be shocking, and it was. It made me imagine it, and I didn't *want* to imagine it.

I just wanted him to go away. I wanted him to stop talking. I wanted him to understand that this wasn't an easy decision, and that I was doing what I thought was best for everyone involved.

But he didn't understand. He just saw me as the enemy. And that was…really hard. It was one of the worst parts of the whole experience, honestly. It made me realize how much judgment there is out there, and how little people understand.

It just…sucked. It really, really sucked. And I don't think I'll ever forget it.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *make* me go back there in my head. That was…a lot.

It wasn't like a movie scene, all dramatic and teary-eyed. It was…numb. Mostly. Like, my brain was trying to disconnect from everything happening. I was filling out all those forms – name, address, medical history, the whole shebang – and it felt like I was filling out a form for a library card or something. Just…paperwork.

But underneath the numbness, there was a whole mess of stuff swirling around. Fear, obviously. A lot of fear. About the procedure, about what people would think, about…everything. And guilt. A ton of guilt. Even though I knew it was the right decision, I still felt guilty. Like I was letting someone down.

And then there was this weird kind of…sadness. Not like, sobbing-into-my-pillow sadness. More like a hollow ache. Knowing that this little person, this potential life, wasn't going to be part of my life. It was a really strange feeling.

I kept looking around the waiting room, trying to avoid eye contact with anyone. Everyone else looked so…serious. And I was trying to be cool, you know? Like, "Yeah, this is no big deal. Just filling out some forms." But inside, I was a total mess.

Paul was there, which helped. He just sat there quietly, holding my hand. He didn't try to fix anything or tell me everything was going to be okay. He just…was there. And that was enough.

It felt…official, you know? Like, once I signed those papers, it was real. There was no going back. And that was terrifying. But also…relieving. Because I knew I was doing the right thing. For me. And for the baby.

It was just…a really complicated mix of emotions. And a lot of paperwork. Seriously, so much paperwork. It was awful. I don't want to think about it anymore. Can we talk about something else? Like, tater tots?

Ugh. Okay, so that's…a big question. And not a fun one to revisit, honestly. But you asked.

At first? It was just…a problem. A really big, inconvenient problem. Like, a pop quiz I hadn't studied for. I was sixteen! I was supposed to be worrying about college applications and band practice, not morning sickness and tiny socks. It felt like my life was over before it even started. I thought of it as something to *fix*. Something to get rid of.

I definitely didn't romanticize it. I didn't have this sudden urge to nest or feel a connection to this little…thing growing inside me. It was just…biological. And scary.

But then, as things progressed, and I started thinking about actually *giving* the baby to someone…that's when it started to change. I started thinking about the parents, Mark and Vanessa, and how much they wanted a kid. And I started imagining this little person being loved and cared for.

It wasn't about *me* anymore. It was about doing what was best for the baby. And that meant giving it a life I couldn't provide.

And then, being pregnant…it just…happened. I started feeling things. Kicking. And I started thinking about this little person as…well, a person. Not just a problem. Not just a thing to be fixed.

I still didn't want to *be* a mom. I wasn't ready. I'm still not sure I *will* be ready. But I started to understand what motherhood meant. It wasn't just about giving birth. It was about love and sacrifice and responsibility.

It was about wanting the best for someone else, even if it meant giving them up.

By the end, it wasn't about fixing a problem anymore. It was about making a choice. A really hard choice. But a good choice. And it changed me. It made me realize I was stronger than I thought. And it made me realize that sometimes, the most selfless thing you can do is let go.

So yeah. My perception of pregnancy and motherhood changed a lot. From a disaster to a decision. From a problem to a possibility. And from something I dreaded to something I…respected. Even if I didn't want it for myself. It's complicated. Still.

Ugh, okay, so you want me to get all introspective? Fine. It's not my favorite thing, but I guess it's a fair question. My sense of identity…it was a mess, honestly. A total work in progress.

At the beginning of the movie, I was all about being…tough. Sarcastic. Detached. Like, I had this whole persona built up to protect myself. I was the girl who didn't care about anything, who could handle anything. It was a defense mechanism, you know? Because underneath all that, I was totally freaking out.

Finding out I was pregnant…that threw everything into chaos. It forced me to confront things I wasn't ready to deal with. Like, who *was* I? Was I just a kid who liked records and avoiding responsibility? Or was I capable of being a mother?

Giving the baby up for adoption wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about figuring out what *I* wanted. It was about realizing that I wasn't ready to be a mom, and that was okay. It was about taking control of my own life.

And then there was Paulie and Vanessa. They were…unexpected. They showed me that it was okay to be vulnerable, to let people in. They helped me see that I wasn't alone.

Throughout the whole process, I started to realize that my identity wasn't fixed. It wasn't something I had to define and stick with forever. It was something that was constantly evolving, changing, growing.

By the end of the movie, I wasn't the same girl I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic and a little bit cynical, but I was also more confident, more self-aware, and more willing to embrace the unknown.

I didn't have all the answers, and that was okay. I was just…me. And that was enough. It was a long, weird journey, but I think I finally started to figure out who I was. Or at least, who I was becoming. And honestly? That's all anyone can really ask for.

Ugh. Okay. That day. That was…a lot. It wasn’t like I suddenly decided I wanted to keep the baby, okay? It wasn’t some grand, romantic change of heart. It was…messier than that.

I’d been so sure. So prepared. I’d picked out the couple, Mark and Vanessa, and I really thought they were good people. They wanted a baby, and I…well, I didn’t. Not really.

But then I spent time with them. And with Paul. And Annie. And everything just…shifted. It wasn’t about *wanting* a baby, it was about realizing how much everyone else wanted one. And how much they would love it.

And I started thinking about what it would be like for *me*. Not just the pregnancy, but everything after. School, college, my life…it all felt…smaller. Like I was giving up a part of myself.

So, I got to the clinic, and I just…froze. I couldn’t do it. Not because I wanted to keep the baby, but because I couldn’t just…hand it over. Not without knowing, really knowing, that it was the right thing to do.

It wasn’t a heroic moment, okay? It was selfish. And confusing. And terrifying. I just needed more time. I needed to be sure.

I ended up leaving. I walked for hours, just trying to figure things out. And eventually, I realized that Mark and Vanessa were the best option. They were ready. They were excited. And they would give the baby a good life.

It still wasn’t easy. It never will be. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right decision. Even if it was the hardest one I’d ever made.

It wasn’t about changing my mind about *having* a baby. It was about changing my mind about what was best for *this* baby. And for me. And for everyone involved. It was…complicated. Everything always is.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the part everyone wants to know about, isn’t it? It’s not like a fun story. It’s just…life.

It wasn’t a quick decision, okay? It wasn’t like I woke up one morning and was all, “Yep, giving the baby away!” It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

First of all, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raise a human being. I was a kid, having a kid. It didn’t make any sense.

And my life wasn’t exactly set up for a baby. My mom is…well, my mom. She’s great, but she’s kinda busy with her own stuff. And my dad is gone. I didn’t want the baby to grow up with a mom who was barely holding it together, you know?

But it wasn’t just about me. It was about the baby. I wanted the baby to have everything. A stable home, two loving parents, opportunities I couldn’t provide. I wanted the baby to be *wanted*. And I knew, deep down, that I wasn’t the right person to give that to them.

Mark…Mark was a good guy, but he wasn’t ready either. We were both just kids. We talked about it, a lot. And we both agreed that adoption was the best option.

It was the hardest decision I’ve ever made. It still is. But I knew it was the right one. It wasn’t about giving up something I wanted. It was about giving the baby something *better*.

It’s not a happy story, exactly. But it’s my story. And I’m okay with it. I think. Mostly. It still stings sometimes, but I know I made the right choice. For everyone.



It’s just…it’s complicated, okay? It’s not something you can just explain in a few sentences. It’s a whole mess of feelings and fears and hopes and dreams. And it changed my life forever.

Ugh, seriously? You're bringing up the Penny Saver? That's…a low blow. It was a vulnerable moment, okay?

Look, it wasn't just the Penny Saver itself, it was the *implication*. Like, my life was an ad in a discount circular? Like I was a used car or a slightly damaged toaster oven? "Slightly used, good condition, must go!"

It felt…cheap. And desperate. And it wasn't about *me*, it was about my parents trying to find someone, *anyone*, to take me on. It felt like they were just trying to get rid of me, and the Penny Saver felt like the place you go when you're trying to get rid of something you don't want anymore.

I wanted someone who *wanted* me, you know? Not someone who was just looking for a bargain. I wanted someone who would love me and take care of me, not someone who saw me as a project or a good deal.

It's not that there's anything wrong with the Penny Saver, it's just…it wasn't the right way to find a family. It felt impersonal and…sad. And I was already feeling pretty sad, okay? I didn't need a reminder that my life was being advertised alongside discounted lawn furniture.

It was just…tacky. And it hurt my feelings. Is that okay to admit? It was a really weird time, and I was trying to cope the best way I knew how, which was with sarcasm and a healthy dose of cynicism. But yeah, the Penny Saver was a bad idea. A really bad idea.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the Penny Saver? It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing, if I'm being honest.

It wasn't like we *planned* on looking at adoption ads, okay? It just…happened. I mean, I was trying to be responsible, right? I knew I couldn't keep the baby. I wasn't ready for that. I was seventeen, for crying out loud! I still had a senior year to mess up.

But I also didn't want to just…give it to anyone. I wanted to find someone who would really love the baby. Someone who was excited about it. Someone who would give it a good life.

And Leah, she's my best friend. She's always been there for me, through everything. She was just trying to help. She knew I was freaking out, and she wanted to make me feel better.

So, we were at her house, just kinda moping around, and she picked up the Penny Saver. It's this super-cheap classifieds paper, full of ads for furniture and used cars and stuff. And then we saw it. An ad for a couple looking to adopt.

It was just…there. And we started looking at more. And then we started circling the ones that seemed…nice. It was a way to feel like I had some control over the situation. Like I was actively choosing a family for my baby.

It was also kinda funny, you know? Looking through these ads with Leah, imagining what it would be like to be the baby's mom for nine months and then just…handing it over. It was a weird way to cope.

It was a really hard time, okay? And the Penny Saver was just…a small part of it. But it was a starting point. It was the first step towards figuring things out. And it was a lot less scary with Leah by my side.



Don't judge us, okay? We were just two teenagers trying to navigate a really complicated situation. And the Penny Saver was the cheapest way to do it.

Okay, so this is…the big one. The really important part. It’s not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know? This is a *person*. A tiny human who deserves the best possible life.

I’ve been thinking about this a lot. A *lot*. And it’s not about finding the “perfect” family, because that doesn’t exist. It’s about finding the *right* family. For *this* baby.

I want someone who’s…stable. That’s number one. No crazy drama, no sudden moves, no…stuff. Someone who can provide a safe and loving home. A home where the baby will feel wanted and secure.

I don’t care if it’s a mom and a dad, or two moms, or two dads, or a single parent. Honestly, I just want someone who’s going to be a good parent. Someone who’s patient and kind and willing to put the baby’s needs first.

I want someone who’s…fun. Someone who will read to the baby, and play with the baby, and take the baby on adventures. Someone who will encourage the baby to be creative and curious and to follow their dreams.

And I want someone who understands that this baby is going to have a story. A different story than other kids. And that they’ll be open and honest about it. Someone who won’t be ashamed of where the baby came from.

I’m not looking for rich or famous or anything like that. Just…good people. People who will love this baby unconditionally. People who will give this baby a chance to be happy.

It’s a lot to ask, I know. But this baby deserves the world. And I want to make sure they get it.

It’s…scary, letting go. But knowing that the baby is going to a good home will make it a little bit easier. A little bit.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa. Don't even get me started. Honestly, they're…a lot.

Look, I'm happy for them, okay? Really. Vanessa deserves someone who's gonna be there for her, and Mark seems…enthusiastic. Like, *really* enthusiastic. Sometimes a little too enthusiastic. It's kinda exhausting just watching them.

He's trying so hard, you know? Like, *really* trying to be a good dad. Which is sweet, I guess. But it's also kinda awkward. He's got that whole "new dad" vibe going on, and it's just…a lot.

And Vanessa? She's amazing. She's strong and independent and she knows what she wants. But she's also kinda…overwhelmed. I mean, she's taking on a lot. A baby, a new relationship, everything.

I just hope they're both ready for what they're getting into. It's not gonna be easy. Being a parent is hard. Being in a relationship is hard. Doing both at the same time? That's a whole other level of hard.

They seem happy, though. And that's what matters, right? I just hope they can navigate all the craziness and come out on the other side still…intact.

Honestly, I'm just glad I'm not them. I've got enough on my plate as it is. But I wish them all the best. They're gonna need it. And maybe a really good therapist. Just saying.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That yearbook thing was…a whole situation. Okay, okay, I'll tell you. But don't judge. It was a stressful time, alright?

I wrote: "**Being with you is like being stranded in a desert with a really cute, slightly awkward cactus. Except you don't poke me.**"

Yeah. I know. It's…weird. And kinda rambling. And probably not what a normal person would write in a yearbook. But Bleeker is…Bleeker. He's not exactly normal either.

I spent, like, *hours* trying to come up with something good. Something that wasn't too cheesy, but also wasn't too dismissive. Something that showed him I cared, but also that I wasn't, like, completely losing my mind.

And that's what I came up with. A cactus. I don't even know why. It just felt…right.

He laughed when he read it, which is good. And he said he liked it. So, I guess it worked.

But seriously, yearbooks are the worst. They force you to distill your entire relationship with someone into a single sentence. It's impossible.



Don't tell anyone I admitted that, okay? I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be cool and detached. Not a sentimental mess.

Ugh. Mrs. Bleeker. Okay, that's a whole *thing*. It's...complicated. Let's just say she wasn't exactly thrilled about her son dating a pregnant teenager. Which, fair enough, I guess. From her perspective.

She mostly just gave me this really intense, disappointed stare. Like I was personally responsible for all of the world's problems. And she kept trying to subtly steer Bleeker towards girls who were, you know, *not* carrying a baby. Like, she'd casually mention how nice Sarah from his chemistry class is, or how talented Emily is in the school play. It was super awkward.

She wasn't outwardly mean, exactly. She just...didn't get me. She thought I was reckless and irresponsible. And maybe I was, a little bit. But she didn't see that I was trying to do the right thing, for the baby and for Bleeker.

She definitely thought I was a bad influence on him. Like I was dragging him down. Which, honestly, was probably true to some extent. Bleeker's a good kid, and I'm...well, I'm me.

I think she eventually came around a little bit, after the baby was born and she saw how much Bleeker loved the idea of being a dad. But she still gave me the side-eye whenever we were around each other. 

It wasn't a warm relationship, let's just say that. It was more of a...polite tolerance. And honestly, I was okay with that. I didn't need her approval. I just wanted her to not actively hate me. Which, thankfully, she didn't.



It's just...she had a very specific idea of who Bleeker should be with, and I definitely didn't fit that mold. And that's okay. People are allowed to have their opinions. Even if those opinions are slightly judgmental.

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, scary cloud. It's not like my parents are, like, *unreasonable* people. They're just…my parents. And this is…a lot.

I keep rehearsing what I'm going to say in my head, and it always comes out sounding either totally flippant or completely hysterical. Neither of which is ideal. I want to be, like, calm and rational and explain everything in a mature way. But I'm pretty sure I'm just going to end up rambling and crying.

My dad, he's gonna be…concerned. He worries about everything. And my mom, she's gonna be disappointed. Not in *me*, exactly, but in the situation. She always wanted me to go to college and have a career and, you know, not get knocked up by a guy I barely know.

It's not that they don't support me. They do. They're just…surprised. And probably a little bit scared. And honestly, I'm scared too.

I keep thinking about how it's going to change everything. My plans, my future, my relationship with them. It's a lot to process.

I just want to get it over with. Rip off the band-aid, you know? But I also want to do it right. I want them to understand. I want them to be okay with it.

It's just…hard. It's the hardest thing I've ever had to do. And I haven't even done it yet.

I'm trying to be brave. I'm trying to be strong. But honestly, right now, I just want to curl up in a ball and pretend this isn't happening. But I can't. I have to face it. I have to tell them.

Wish me luck. I'm gonna need it. A lot of it.

Ugh, okay, so you want to psychoanalyze me now? Fine. But don't expect me to spill *everything*. It's complicated, alright?

It's not that I don't love my parents. I do. They're…good people. Just…not always *get* me, you know? My dad's all about fixing things, and my mom's all about feelings. And this? This isn't something you can fix with a toolbox or a pep talk.

It's embarrassing, okay? Like, super embarrassing. I got myself into this mess. I made a choice. And now I have to deal with the consequences. I don't want to burden them with it. They already have enough on their plates.

Plus, I'm kinda afraid of their reaction. My dad would probably try to "solve" the problem, and my mom would probably cry. A lot. And I just…I don't want to upset them.

I'm also just…independent. I like to handle things on my own. I don't want to be a baby about it. I want to show them that I can be responsible, even when things are hard.

But it's also a little bit about trust, I guess. I don't always feel like I can be completely honest with them. Like, they wouldn't understand. They wouldn't get why I'm making the choices I'm making.

So yeah, that's why I'm hesitant to ask for help. It's a mix of embarrassment, fear, independence, and a little bit of distrust. It's messy. Just like everything else in my life right now.

Don't judge me, okay? It's hard enough as it is.

Okay, so this is…the big one, right? Everyone wants to know why. It's not like I didn't think about everything else. Seriously. I spent *hours* staring at the ceiling, trying to figure it out.

Look, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone raising a whole human being. I'm not ready. I'm not financially stable. I'm still in high school. I like listening to The Moldy Peaches and eating tater tots. That's about the extent of my adult responsibilities right now.

And it's not about not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have the *best* life possible. A life I can't give it right now. A life with two parents who are ready and able to provide everything it needs. A stable home, financial security, a future.

Mark and Vanessa…they're amazing. They've been trying for years to have a baby, and they're so excited. They're gonna give this kid a life filled with love and opportunity. And that's what matters most.

It's not easy, okay? It's heartbreaking. I'm gonna miss this baby. I'm gonna feel a connection to it forever. But I know, deep down, that this is the right decision.

It's not about giving up on the baby. It's about giving the baby *up* to a better life. It's about being selfless. It's about doing what's best for the kid, even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

And honestly? It's about me getting to finish high school, go to college, and figure out who I am without being completely overwhelmed by the responsibility of parenthood. I need to live my own life, too.

It's not a perfect solution. But it's the best one. And I'm okay with that. I have to be.

Okay, so this is…the big stuff. This isn’t like picking out a new pair of Converse, you know? This is a whole human life we’re talking about. So, yeah, I’ve thought about this. A lot.

First of all, they gotta be…stable. Like, really stable. Not, “Oh, we’re artists, so our income is unpredictable!” stable. I need people who have their lives together enough to provide a good, solid foundation. A house, a job, a routine. Not necessarily fancy, just…reliable.

And they have to be *open*. Open to all kinds of things. Open to my baby being…well, my baby. They need to understand that this isn’t just some blank slate they get to mold. This kid is gonna have a story, and they need to be okay with that. And open to talking about me, too. I don’t want my kid growing up feeling like I just…disappeared.

They also need to be funny. Seriously. Life is hard. You need to be able to laugh. And I want my kid to grow up in a house where there’s joy and silliness and not just a lot of serious faces.

And they have to be kind. Not just to my baby, but to everyone. To strangers, to animals, to people who are different. Kindness is important.

I don’t need them to be perfect. Nobody is. But they need to be good people. People who are willing to love and support and nurture a child. People who will let my baby be themselves, even if that means making mistakes.

And honestly? I want them to be a little bit weird. Normal is overrated. I want my kid to grow up in a house where it’s okay to be different, to be creative, to be a little bit…offbeat.

It’s a lot to ask, I know. But this is my kid we’re talking about. And I want the best for them. The absolute best.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? The part everyone keeps asking about, like it's gonna be easy. It's not gonna be easy. It's gonna suck. A lot.

I've been doing a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking to Bren and my dad. And honestly? I don't have a perfect plan. Because you can't really *plan* for something like this. It's just…you gotta feel it.

But I'm trying to focus on the good stuff. Like, knowing that the baby is going to have parents who are really excited and ready to give it a good life. Mark and Vanessa seem…amazing. They're gonna be great parents. And that makes me feel…okay. A little bit.

I'm also trying to remind myself that this isn't about me. It's about what's best for the baby. And right now, that's not with me. I'm not ready. I'm still a kid myself.

I'm gonna lean on Bren. She's the best. And my dad. He's surprisingly good at giving advice, even if it's kinda corny. And I'm gonna write. A lot. It helps to get my feelings out.

I'm also gonna allow myself to grieve. It's okay to be sad. It's okay to be angry. It's okay to feel all the things. I'm not gonna pretend like it doesn't hurt.

And I'm gonna try to remember that this isn't the end of my story. It's just…a really big chapter. And I'm gonna keep living my life. I'm gonna go to college, I'm gonna figure out what I want to do, and I'm gonna be happy. Eventually.

It's gonna be hard. But I'm strong. And I'm not alone. And I'm gonna get through it. I have to. For me. And for the baby.



It's just…it's a lot to process. And I'm trying to be brave. But sometimes, I just wanna curl up in a ball and cry. And that's okay too.

Ugh, okay, you noticed that, huh? Yeah, "deliver." It just…gets to me. It's a word people use a lot when talking about babies, and it feels so…clinical. Like I'm ordering a pizza or something. "One baby, extra cheese, please. And make it quick!"

It's not a *thing* you deliver. It's a person. A tiny, fragile human being. And using that word just feels so…detached. Like it minimizes everything. All the feelings, all the responsibility, all the…everything.

My mom tried to use it a lot at first. "You're going to deliver a beautiful baby, Juno!" And I'd just stare at her and be like, "No. I'm going to *have* a baby. Or *birth* a baby. But I'm not 'delivering' it."

It's like, people use it to make themselves feel better, I think. To distance themselves from the whole messy, complicated reality of it all. But it doesn't make *me* feel better. It just makes me feel weird.

And it's not just babies, either. People "deliver" presentations, they "deliver" results…it just feels so…corporate. Like everything has to be a product or a service.

I don't know. It's probably just me. I'm a weirdo. But yeah, "deliver" just rubs me the wrong way. It feels…impersonal. And a baby is anything *but* impersonal.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That was a disaster waiting to happen. Honestly, it was a strategic error on my part. A massive one.

Okay, so, I thought…I thought having my dad there would make me look more…responsible? Like, a mature adult making a thoughtful decision? I was trying to play the game, you know? Show everyone I wasn't just some flaky teenager who got herself into a mess.

And he was being all supportive and stuff, which, okay, was nice. But he's my *dad*. He's…a lot. He's always trying to fix things, and he has this way of oversharing and making everything awkward.

I figured, maybe if he was there, the adoption people would see we were a stable family unit. Which, let's be real, we are not. Not even close.

It backfired spectacularly. He started talking about his feelings and making weird jokes and generally being…MacGuff. It was mortifying. And it totally threw off the whole vibe.

I should have known better. I should have just gone by myself. But I was trying to be…grown up. And it just ended up making everything worse.

It was a good lesson, though. Sometimes, you just have to own your mess. And sometimes, you have to accept that your dad is going to be your dad, no matter what. Even if it's incredibly embarrassing.

So yeah, that's why I let him come. It was a terrible idea. A really, really terrible idea. Don't ask me to repeat it.

Ugh. Okay, that's…hitting a little close to home, honestly. You're asking about the whole "what kind of girl am I?" thing? Yeah, that's been a constant theme in my life lately. It's like, everyone else seems to have it figured out. They know what they want, who they are, what college they're going to…and I'm just…floating.

It's not that I *want* to be someone else, exactly. It's just…I don't really fit into any of the boxes. I'm not a cheerleader, I'm not a drama kid, I'm not a super-smart academic. I'm just…me. Which, apparently, isn't a defined category.

It's kinda scary, not knowing what the future holds. Like, am I gonna end up stuck in Maple Creek forever? Working at a dead-end job? Or am I gonna find something I'm passionate about? Something that makes me feel…alive?

Paul tried to tell me it was okay to not have a plan. He said life is about the journey, not the destination. Which is all well and good for him, he's a musician. He doesn't need a five-year plan. I kinda do. Or I *think* I do.

But I'm starting to realize that maybe it's okay to not know. Maybe it's okay to just…be. To explore different things, to make mistakes, to figure it out as I go along.

It's not ideal. It's messy and confusing and kinda terrifying. But it's also…freeing. I don't have to be anything I don't want to be. I can just be Juno. And maybe that's enough.

It's still a work in progress, though. I'm still trying to figure things out. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely. And honestly? That's all I can ask for.

So, how do I feel about not knowing what kind of girl I am? It sucks. But it also kinda doesn't. It's complicated. Just like everything else in my life.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was…a moment. A really awkward, uncomfortable moment.

Honestly? I was mostly just relieved. Like, finally, someone recognized the giant elephant in the room. My dad and I were just…staring at each other, radiating awkwardness. It was like a standoff. And Leah was just trying to eat her waffles and pretend everything was normal, which, good for her.

So when Bren – my stepmom – suggested we go upstairs, I was like, "Yes, please! Get me out of here!" But I also felt kinda bad for my dad. He was clearly trying, you know? Trying to be a dad. And failing spectacularly.

I think I just mumbled something like, "Okay," and practically dragged Leah up the stairs. I didn't want to make eye contact with anyone. It was just…too much.

And then, of course, we ended up talking about everything *upstairs*. Which was probably the point. Bren is surprisingly perceptive, for a Bren. She knew we needed space to process things.

It was just…a really weird day. A really weird pregnancy. A really weird life, honestly. But at least I had Leah. And waffles. Waffles always make things a little bit better.

It was a turning point, I guess. It was the moment I realized things were really changing. And that I needed to figure out what I was going to do about it. But mostly, I just wanted to escape the awkwardness.

Ugh, okay, that's…a lot. It's something I've thought about, obviously. A *lot*. It's not like flipping a switch, you know? It's messy and complicated and kinda terrifying.

At first, the idea of *not* knowing anything…it felt easier. Like, clean break. I give the baby to the parents, and I just…move on. Pretend it never happened. But that felt…wrong. Like, pretending a part of me didn't exist.

Then Annie and Mark started talking about open adoption, about sending pictures and updates. And it freaked me out. It felt like…not letting go. Like, I'd be forever tied to this baby, forever wondering what their life was like.

But then I started thinking about the baby. About them growing up, and wanting to know where they came from. About them having a story. And maybe *I* could be a part of that story, even if I'm not their mom.

It's still scary. It's scary to think about seeing pictures of them, knowing I'm not the one raising them. It's scary to think about them maybe wanting to find me someday.

But I think…I think it's the right thing to do. For the baby. It's about putting their needs first, even if it's hard for me. It's about giving them a sense of identity and belonging.

It's not gonna be easy. There'll be tears, and awkwardness, and probably a lot of second-guessing. But I think it's worth it. I think it's worth knowing that they're okay. And that they're loved.

So yeah. I'm…okay with it. I'm still processing it. But I think it's the best way to do this. It's not perfect, but nothing ever is, right? It's just…the least worst option. And maybe, just maybe, it'll be a good thing. For everyone.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a punch to the gut. Seriously. I was trying to be all cool and collected, you know? Like, “Yeah, open adoption, totally fine, I get it.” But when Gerta said that…about my rights being terminated…it felt like someone just ripped a hole in my chest.

It wasn’t about *wanting* to raise the baby, exactly. It was about…control. About having a say in his life. About being a part of it, even if it wasn’t in the way I originally thought. And to hear that I’d just…lose all legal claim to him? That I’d be legally nothing to him? It felt…wrong.

I mean, I knew it was an adoption. I knew I wasn’t keeping him. But I didn’t realize it meant completely giving up everything. It felt like I was being erased. Like I never even existed.

I tried to play it off, you know? Make a joke. “So, like, I’m just a glorified egg donor?” But inside, I was freaking out. It was the first time it really hit me how permanent this was. How much I was giving up.

It made me question everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Was I just trying to make myself feel better about a really hard decision?

It was…scary. And lonely. And it made me realize that even though I was choosing this, it didn’t mean it was going to be easy. It was going to hurt. A lot.

I think that was the moment I really started to understand the weight of everything. It wasn’t just about giving a baby a good home. It was about giving up a part of myself. And that was…terrifying.

Ugh. Vanessa. Okay, look, don't get me wrong, she's nice. And she's really good at, like, decorating and stuff. But her whole obsession with having a baby? It's…intense.

It's not that I don't think she'd be a good mom. She would. She'd knit tiny sweaters and bake organic cookies and everything. It's just…it feels like she wants a baby to *fix* something. Like, her life isn't complete without one. And that's kinda sad, you know?

I mean, I get wanting a kid. I didn't exactly *plan* on this, but now that it's happening, I'm starting to think it could be…good. But I'm not doing it to fill a void. I'm doing it because it's happening, and I want to make sure this kid has a good life.

Vanessa, she's been trying for so long, and it's just not working. And it's consuming her. It's all she talks about. It's like, can we please talk about something else for five minutes? Like, the new Modest Mouse album? Or the ridiculousness of high school?

I just want her to be happy, you know? And I don't think a baby is gonna magically make her happy if she's not happy already. It's a lot of work, and it's not a cure-all.

It's just…it's a lot. And it makes me feel weird, because I'm giving up my baby, and she's desperately wanting one. It's just…life is messed up sometimes.

I hope she finds what she's looking for. I really do. But I also hope she realizes that her worth isn't tied to whether or not she has a kid. She's a good person, and she deserves to be happy, with or without a baby.

Ugh. Mark. Okay, so you're talking about when people ask him about being a dad, right? And he always gives that whole…vague, kinda detached answer? Yeah, it bugs me. A lot.

It's not that he *has* to be all gushy and emotional about it, okay? I get that some people aren't naturally expressive. But it's like he's actively trying to distance himself from the whole thing. Like being a dad is some kind of…inconvenience.

And it's not fair to Vanessa, you know? She's the one who's actually doing all the work, changing diapers and dealing with sleep deprivation. And he's just…there. Offering lukewarm support and avoiding the topic whenever possible.

I think he's scared. Scared of responsibility, scared of commitment, scared of messing things up. And instead of dealing with those feelings, he just shuts down. It's a really immature way to handle things.

I mean, he's a good guy, Mark. He's sweet and he's funny and he's…well, he's Mark. But he needs to step up. He needs to be a real partner to Vanessa. And he needs to actually *want* to be a dad.

It's not about being perfect, it's about being present. It's about showing up and being there for your kid. And right now, I don't think Mark is doing that.

It just makes me sad, you know? Because Vanessa deserves better. And the baby deserves a dad who's actually excited to be a dad.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's just…frustrating. I'm glad I made the choice I did. At least I knew what I wanted. And I wasn't gonna settle for anything less.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You want to unpack the Loring's house thing? It's…a whole situation. It's not like I'm scared of ghosts or anything. Though, honestly, that house *felt* haunted. But it's not the house itself. It's…Mr. and Mrs. Loring.

They're just…intense. Like, overly nice. And that's always a red flag, okay? People who are *too* nice are usually hiding something. And they were definitely hiding something.

It was the way they looked at me. Like I was…a project. Something to fix. They kept offering me organic snacks and talking about "positive affirmations" and trying to get me to open up about my feelings. Which, like, personal space, people!

And the way they talked about adoption like it was a business transaction. "We can offer a stable home…" and "We have a lovely nursery prepared…" It just felt…cold. Like I wasn't a person, just a thing they wanted to acquire.

Plus, they were always watching me. Not in a creepy, staring way, but just…present. Like they were waiting for me to mess up. And I *always* mess up. It's kind of my thing.

I just felt…suffocated. Like I couldn't breathe. Like I had to be perfect all the time. And I'm not perfect. I'm messy and sarcastic and I say the wrong things. And they didn't seem to appreciate that.

So yeah, being left unsupervised with the Loring's was uncomfortable. It felt like I was being evaluated. Like I was on display. And I just wanted to escape. It was…weird. Really weird. And kinda creepy.



It's hard to explain. It was just a bad vibe. And I trust my gut. Usually.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big one. And it's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's too…squishy.

It's complicated, okay? It's not like I *wanted* to be in this situation. It was…an accident. A really inconvenient accident. And for a while, I was just focused on getting through it, on making the best of a really weird situation.

But then I met Mark and Vanessa. And…they're good people. Really good people. They *want* this baby. They've been trying for a long time, and they're so excited. And they're not looking for a perfect baby, or a perfect life. They just want to love and be loved.

And that's when it started to feel…right. Like, maybe this wasn't just a mistake. Maybe it was…something more.

It's still scary, though. Giving up a baby. It's not like giving up a pair of shoes. It's a whole person. A little person who's growing inside me. And I'm gonna miss them. I already miss them, even though they're not even here yet.

But I know that Mark and Vanessa are going to give them a good life. A loving life. A life that I…I can't give them right now. I'm not ready for that. I'm still figuring out who *I* am.

So, how do I feel about giving them the gift of life? It's bittersweet. It's scary. It's sad. But it's also…hopeful. And it's the right thing to do.

It's not about being selfless, or heroic, or anything like that. It's just…practical. And it's about wanting what's best for the baby. And I think, deep down, I know that Mark and Vanessa are what's best.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's still gonna hurt. A lot. But I'm trying to focus on the good. On the fact that this baby is going to be loved and cherished. And that's all that really matters, right?

Ugh, okay, let's revisit the Mark situation. Honestly? It wasn't *just* the "ASAP." It was the whole package. The guitar, the earnestness, the…everything.

He was trying so hard, you know? Like, *really* trying to be cool and mature and responsible. And it was just…painfully obvious. And the "ASAP" felt like he was trying too hard to sound official. Like he was practicing in the mirror.

It's not that I didn't appreciate him trying to help. It's just…it was Mark. And he's a sweet guy, but he's also kinda clueless. And sometimes, you just gotta call people out on their cluelessness.

Plus, "ASAP" is just a lazy way to communicate. Like, just say *when* you need something. It's not that hard. It's not a life-or-death situation. It's a pregnancy test.

I guess I just have a low tolerance for people who try too hard to be something they're not. It feels…fake. And I'm all about keeping it real.

And honestly, it was a little bit of a defense mechanism. I was freaking out about being pregnant, and making fun of Mark was a way to deflect and avoid dealing with my own feelings.

So yeah, I mocked his "ASAP." It was mean, I admit it. But it was also…me. And sometimes, I just can't help myself. I have a mouth, and it gets me into trouble. It always has.



Don't judge me too harshly. I was a teenager dealing with a lot. And Mark deserved a little teasing. He could handle it. Probably.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about guitars now? Seriously? You're digging deep into my hypothetical hobbies. Fine.

It's gotta be a Fender Telecaster. Definitely. Not one of those fancy, sparkly ones, though. I like the sunburst ones. The ones that look like they've been through a few things.

Why? Because they're…unpretentious. They're not trying to be anything they're not. They're just a solid, reliable guitar that can play pretty much anything. They're kinda like me, I guess.

Plus, they're not super expensive. I'm not exactly rolling in dough, okay? I need a guitar that's affordable but still sounds good. And a Telecaster fits the bill.

I've always liked the sound of them, too. It's kinda twangy and raw. It's perfect for playing indie rock or folk music. Or just messing around and making noise.

Paul used to play a Telecaster. He wasn't very good, but he tried. It reminds me of him.

So yeah. Fender Telecaster. It's the only guitar I'd ever need. It's simple, it's reliable, and it sounds good. What more could you want?

Don't ask me to play you a song, though. I'm still learning. And I'm not very good. But I'm working on it.

Ugh, okay, seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? That was, like, months ago. And it was a moment of weakness, okay? A moment of pure, unadulterated desperation.

Look, Paul was…intense. And he was *really* into the Melvins. Like, obsessed. And he kept talking about them, and how cool they were, and how anyone who didn't like them was clearly a philistine.

And I just…I wanted him to like me. I wanted him to think I was cool and interesting and, you know, *worthy* of his attention. So I panicked. And I said I was a huge fan of the Melvins.

Which was a lie. A complete and utter fabrication. I'd heard of them, sure. But I hadn't actually listened to any of their music. I didn't even know what kind of music they played!

It was a terrible idea. A really, really terrible idea. Because then he started quizzing me about them. And I had to make up answers. And it just spiraled out of control.

It was a stupid, insecure thing to do. And I regretted it immediately. But I was too embarrassed to admit the truth. So I just kept digging myself deeper and deeper into the hole.

It was a valuable lesson, though. I learned that it's always better to be honest, even if it's awkward. And I learned that trying to be someone you're not is exhausting and ultimately pointless.

And honestly? The Melvins aren't even that great. Don't tell Paul I said that. He'd kill me.



It was a dumb move. I admit it. But hey, everyone makes mistakes, right? Especially when they're dealing with hormones and a complicated pregnancy.

Ugh, Mark. Okay. Describing that is…tricky. It wasn’t like, a grand romantic gesture kind of thing, you know? It wasn’t all sparkly and dramatic. It was…comfortable. And kinda surprising.

Before all the baby stuff, I barely even *talked* to him. He was just…Mark. The quiet guy who played guitar. And he was good, really good. But I didn’t really *see* him, I guess.

But then we started playing together, just messing around with songs. And it was…easy. Like, he just *got* what I was going for, even when I didn’t know what I was going for. He’d pick up on little things, add a harmony or a riff, and suddenly the song would just…click.

And singing with him…that was different. It wasn’t about showing off or anything. It was just…sharing something. Like, we were both putting a little piece of ourselves into the music, and it created something new.

It was a connection, definitely. But it wasn’t a *romantic* connection, not at first. It was more like…a shared understanding. A shared passion. A shared space where we could just be ourselves, without having to worry about what anyone else thought.

It was a safe space, I guess. And that was…nice. Especially when everything else in my life was completely chaotic.

It was a little bit scary, too. Because I’m not good at letting people in. But with Mark, it just…happened. And I didn’t fight it. It was a good thing. A really good thing. Even if I didn’t fully understand it at the time.

It was just…music. And him. And me. And it felt…right.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking about the guitar? It's a long story. And kinda embarrassing. But fine, I'll tell you.

It was Paul's idea, actually. He was obsessed with Theodore Roosevelt. Like, *really* obsessed. He said Roosevelt was a man of action, a progressive, a total badass. And Paul thought my guitar playing was...well, he thought it had potential. He said it needed a strong name, a name that embodied strength and determination.

So he suggested Roosevelt. And I fought him on it at first. It sounded ridiculous. Like, who names a guitar after a president? But he kept insisting, and eventually, I just gave in. It was easier than arguing with him.

And then...it kinda stuck. It just felt right, I guess. Roosevelt is a solid name. It has a certain weight to it. And my guitar *is* pretty solid. It's a good guitar.

Plus, it's kinda funny. It's a little bit ironic. Like, a teenage girl playing a guitar named after a rugged president. It's a juxtaposition. I like that.

So yeah, that's how my guitar got named Roosevelt. It was Paul's doing. He was a weirdo, but he had good taste in presidents. And guitars. Mostly.

Don't judge me. It's a good name. And Roosevelt and I have been through a lot together. It's a bond. A weird, presidential bond.

Ugh. Okay, so the Vanessa and Mark situation. It's…a lot. Honestly? It feels like being put on display at the zoo. Like, "Ooh, look at the pregnant teenager! Let's check in on her progress!"

It's not that I *dislike* them. They're nice enough. And they're trying to be supportive, I guess. But it's just…weird. They're so…perfect. Perfect house, perfect jobs, perfect everything. And here I am, a mess of hormones and anxiety and questionable music taste.

I get *why* they want to be involved. They're gonna be the parents, after all. But it feels like they're treating me like a vessel, you know? Like I'm just carrying their baby, not a person with feelings and opinions.

And Mark keeps asking about ultrasounds and baby names and stuff. It's like, whoa, slow down! I haven't even picked out a Halloween costume yet, let alone a baby name!

Vanessa's a little better. She's more sensitive, I think. But she still has this…expectant look in her eyes. Like she's already picturing the perfect little family. And I'm just trying to survive each day.

I guess I just wish they'd give me some space. Let me figure things out on my own. Let me be a teenager for a little bit longer. I'm already giving them a baby. Isn't that enough?

It's not that I don't want them to be involved, it's just…the level of involvement is a little overwhelming. It feels like I'm constantly being evaluated. Like I have to prove that I'm a good enough carrier, a good enough…whatever.

It's complicated. Everything is complicated. And honestly, I just want it to be over. But it's not over yet. So I guess I'll just keep smiling and nodding and pretending to be excited about baby names. It's what you do, right?

Okay, look. People keep asking me about this, like I'm gonna suddenly change my mind and decide to raise a baby at sixteen. Like that's a reasonable option. It's not.

It's not about not wanting the baby, okay? It's about wanting the baby to have *everything*. And I can't give it everything. Not right now. Not ever, probably.

I'm sixteen. I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I'm figuring out what I want to *be* when I grow up, let alone being a mom. I'm not ready to give up my life, my dreams, for a baby. And that sounds selfish, I know. But it's the truth.

And it's not fair to the baby to be raised by someone who isn't fully ready, who's still trying to figure things out. It deserves parents who are stable and prepared and can give it the best possible life.

Mark and Vanessa…they're amazing. They've been trying for years. They have a beautiful home, a good life, and they're so excited. They can give this baby everything I can't.

It's not easy. It's the hardest decision I've ever made. And it's gonna hurt. A lot. But I know it's the right thing to do. 

It's not about giving up a baby. It's about giving a baby the best possible start in life. And that's worth more than anything.

So yeah, I'm 104% sure. Because I've thought about it. A lot. And I know, deep down, that this is the right thing to do. For everyone. Even me. Especially the baby.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…weird. Really weird. It wasn't like, *hostile*, exactly. It was just…intense. Like they’d been holding their breath for nine months and finally, *finally* could exhale. And they did it with a lot of balloons and a really aggressively cheerful playlist.

Honestly? It stung a little. Not because I didn’t want them to be happy, because I did. I really did. They were good people, and they were going to be amazing parents. But it felt…fast. Like, I hadn’t even walked out the door and they were already planning the nursery and picking out names. It felt like they were celebrating *me* leaving, not the baby *coming*.

I knew it wasn’t about me, not really. It was about them finally getting what they wanted. And I wanted them to have that. But it still felt…dismissive. Like I was just a vessel, a means to an end.

I tried to tell myself it was just relief. That they were just processing everything in their own way. But it was hard to shake the feeling that I was an inconvenience they were glad to be rid of.

I remember thinking, “Okay, so this is what it feels like to be…replaced.” Which is a dramatic thought, I know. But I was a teenager. Everything felt dramatic.

I mostly just wanted to go home and listen to The Moldy Peaches and pretend the whole thing hadn’t happened. But you can’t really pretend something like that away. It just…is. And you deal with it. Or you try to, anyway.

It wasn’t anger, exactly. It was more…a quiet sadness. And a little bit of confusion. And a whole lot of wanting to be left alone.

Ugh. Seriously? People are *talking*? Like, I didn't already have enough on my plate? It's like everyone suddenly became experts on my uterus. It's infuriating.

Look, it's my life, okay? My body. My decision. And I don't need a bunch of gossiping busybodies weighing in on it. It's not a spectator sport.

I get it, people are curious. Small town, you know? Everyone knows everyone's business. But it's not their business. It's mine. And Paul's. And the baby's.

And the rumors? They're mostly wrong, anyway. People love to fill in the blanks with their own crazy theories. It's exhausting trying to correct everything.

Honestly, I just want people to mind their own business. I'm trying to navigate this whole thing as best I can, and I don't need the added pressure of everyone judging me. 

It's not like I'm trying to hide anything. I'm just not broadcasting every detail of my life to the world. I need some privacy, okay? Is that too much to ask?

I'm trying to be strong, and I'm trying to do the right thing. And I don't need a bunch of whispers and stares to make it harder. So, if you're one of those people spreading rumors, just...stop. Please. It's not helpful. It's just mean.

And if you're genuinely concerned, maybe just ask me how *I'm* doing, instead of listening to gossip. That would be a nice change of pace.

Ugh. Okay. Deep breaths. You want to know how I *feel* about it? Like, really feel? It's…a lot. It's not like picking out a new pair of shoes, you know?

It's scary. Terrifying, actually. I mean, I'm carrying a whole human being inside me. And I'm supposed to…give it away? To someone else? It feels…wrong. Like, fundamentally wrong.

But it's also the right thing to do. I know that. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm sixteen. I still have a lot of figuring out to do, you know? I need to finish school, and maybe go to college, and just…be me. And I can't do that with a baby.

And I want this baby to have a good life. A *really* good life. With parents who are ready and able to give it everything it needs. And I can't give it that right now.

So, yeah. It's complicated. It's sad. It's heartbreaking. I cry about it sometimes. A lot, actually. But it's also…hopeful. Because I know that this baby is going to be loved. And that's all I really want.

It doesn't make it easy, though. It's going to be the hardest thing I've ever done. But I'm trying to be strong. And I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm doing this for the baby.

It's not about me. It's about giving this little person the best possible chance at a happy life. And that's worth it, even if it breaks my heart a little bit.

So, how do I feel? I feel…everything. And nothing. It's a mess. But I'm trying to deal with it. One day at a time.



It's just…a lot to process, you know? It's not something you can just brush off. It's a big deal. A really big deal.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole surprise baby thing? It's...complicated. It's not like I *wanted* to make it harder on Mark and Vanessa, okay? It's just...I didn't want them to have any expectations.

See, they've already got this whole plan for the baby. Nursery decorated, names picked out, everything. It's kinda intense. And I get it, they're excited. But I didn't want them to be disappointed if the baby wasn't what they expected. Like, if they were hoping for a boy and it's a girl, or vice versa.

I wanted them to just...love the baby for who it is. Not for what they thought it would be. It's like, the sex of the baby doesn't matter. It's just a tiny human who needs love and care.

And honestly? A little bit of it was for me too. I wanted them to be surprised, to be in the moment, to just...react. It felt more real that way. Less planned. Less perfect.

I know it's kinda selfish, but I wanted them to have a genuine experience. Something they wouldn't have gotten if they'd known all along. 

It's just...I've been doing a lot of thinking about expectations lately. And how they can mess things up. And I wanted this to be different. I wanted it to be pure.

So yeah, that's why I wanted the surprise. It wasn't about being difficult. It was about wanting them to just...love the baby, no matter what. Does that make sense? It's kinda hard to explain.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on that woman. Seriously. It was like, I hadn't even fully processed the fact that there was a tiny human growing inside me, and she was already judging my entire life plan.

It wasn't the seeing the ultrasound itself that was bad, okay? That was…weirdly cool. Like, a little blurry alien. But then she started with the whole "Oh, you're so young" and the "Are you sure you're ready for this?" and the subtle little digs about how "most" teenage moms end up keeping their babies.

It felt…dismissive. Like she'd already written me off. Like she didn't even see me as a person making a difficult decision, just a statistic. And it was *my* decision, okay? I'd thought about it. A lot. And I knew what I wanted.

It made me want to yell, honestly. But I just kinda sat there and stared at the blurry alien and tried not to cry. It was humiliating. And it was frustrating. Because it's not like I *wanted* to get pregnant. It just happened. And I was trying to be responsible about it.

It made me feel like I had to justify my choices to a complete stranger. Like I had to prove that I was a good person, even though I was making a decision that wasn't exactly conventional.

It was one of those moments where you realize people are going to judge you no matter what you do. And you just have to learn to ignore them and do what's right for you.

It sucked. It really, really sucked. And it made me even more determined to make the best decision for the baby, and for myself. Even if it meant dealing with a lot of judgmental people along the way.

Ugh, okay, buckle up. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? It wasn't like in the movies where everything magically works out with a cute montage. It was messy. And awkward. And sometimes really, really hard.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was just…everyone having an opinion. Like, suddenly *everyone* was an expert on my body and my life. My parents, my friends, even random people at school. It was suffocating. Everyone thought they knew what was best for me, and nobody really listened to what *I* wanted.
