Then there was the whole dealing-with-the-dad situation. Paulie Bleeker is a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he was…overwhelmed. And we were both just kids. Trying to figure out adult stuff when we hadn't even figured out high school yet. It was a lot.

And the adoption process itself? Bureaucracy is a nightmare. So much paperwork. So many meetings. So many people asking personal questions. It felt like I was being interviewed for a job, except the job was…growing a human.

But the hardest part, I think, was just the emotional stuff. Knowing that I was going to have a baby, and then knowing that I was going to give it up. It was heartbreaking. Even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it any easier. There were days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry.

And then there was the judgment. People looking at me differently. Whispering. Assuming things. It was hard to deal with.

But I had some amazing people in my corner. My dad, even though he was initially freaked out, was really supportive. And Annie, my stepmom, was a lifesaver. And Mark, Vanessa's husband, was surprisingly cool. They helped me get through it.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it taught me a lot about myself. About responsibility. About love. And about making tough choices. And ultimately, it was worth it. Because I knew I was giving that baby the best possible life. And that's all that really mattered.



It's still…a lot to process, even now. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, deep thoughts time. Don't judge me if I get all sappy on you. It's been...a lot.

Before all this, love was, like, in movies. Or in songs. Something other people dealt with. Responsibility was doing my homework and not flunking out. And growing up was just...something that happened to other people, eventually.

Now? Love is…messy. It's not all grand gestures and perfect moments. It's about showing up, even when it's hard. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if it means letting them go. It's about Paul and Annie, and how they supported me even when I was being a total mess. It's about realizing that love isn't just romantic, it's about family and friends and people who care about you.

Responsibility? That one hit me like a ton of bricks. It's not just about doing what you're *supposed* to do. It's about making choices that have consequences, and being willing to deal with those consequences. It's about realizing that my decisions weren't just about me anymore. There was a little person involved. And that was terrifying. But also…kind of amazing.

And growing up…well, that happened fast. It wasn't a gradual process, it was more like a sudden jump. I went from being a kid who just wanted to listen to music and avoid drama to someone who had to think about the future and make some really big decisions. It's about realizing that life isn't always fair, and that you have to be strong and independent and figure things out on your own.

It's still scary, honestly. I'm still figuring things out. But I'm not as afraid anymore. I've learned that it's okay to ask for help, and that it's okay to not have all the answers. And I've learned that even when things are really hard, there's always hope.

This whole experience…it forced me to grow up. It forced me to confront my own beliefs and values. And it forced me to realize that I'm capable of more than I ever thought possible.

It's not the life I expected, but it's my life. And I'm gonna make the best of it. Even if it's messy and complicated and terrifying. Because that's just life, right?

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the Centennial Lane thing. It's…complicated. And honestly, it's none of your business. But since you asked…

It's not like I'm *obsessed* or anything. It's just…weird. A whole living room, just left out in someone's yard? Like, a full-on, floral-print couch and everything? It's unsettling. It feels…sad.

It's like a snapshot of a life that just…stopped. Like someone was sitting there, watching TV, and then just…vanished. And left everything behind.

Paul thinks I'm being morbid. He says I'm projecting. Which, okay, maybe I am. But it's just…it makes me think. About families, and secrets, and all the stuff that goes on behind closed doors.

And it's just…a really good couch. Seriously. It's hideous, but it looks comfortable. And I'm always on the lookout for comfortable furniture. You never know when you're gonna need a good place to crash.

I just keep driving by it, you know? Trying to figure out the story. Who lived there? What happened? Why did they leave everything behind?

It's a mystery. And I'm a sucker for a good mystery. Even if it's just a weird abandoned living room set.

So, yeah. That's why I'm interested. Don't judge me. It's not like I'm planning to move in or anything. Though…that couch *is* tempting.



Just…leave it alone, okay? It's my weird thing. And everyone has a weird thing. Don't they?

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on the Wizard. That guy was…creepy. Seriously. Still gives me the shivers just thinking about him.

Okay, so, that whisper. "Do you know how long I've wanted this?" It wasn't about the baby, okay? It wasn't about wanting to be a dad or anything normal like that. It was about…control.

He'd been watching me, watching Paul, watching everything. He'd been building this whole fantasy in his head about having a "perfect" family. A family he could control. A family that would fulfill *his* needs.

He wasn't interested in me or the baby as individuals. We were just…pieces in his plan. He wanted a wife, a child, a life that he could curate and manipulate. He wanted to be the center of attention, the one in charge.

It was disgusting.

He'd been looking for someone like me for a long time, someone vulnerable and confused. Someone he could try to exploit. And when he saw me, he thought he'd finally found his opportunity.

That whisper wasn't a sweet sentiment. It was a threat. It was a declaration of ownership. It was a glimpse into his twisted mind.

It was the moment I realized how truly dangerous he was, and how important it was to get away from him. It was terrifying. And honestly, it still freaks me out to think about it.

He was a weirdo. A seriously messed-up weirdo. And I'm glad I didn't end up with him. Ever.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're dissecting my life choices now? Fine. It's a valid question, I guess. It's not like I was having a particularly *thoughtful* moment, but I can explain.

Look, the juice was a symbol, okay? A symbol of…everything. Of feeling gross and bloated and like I was losing control. And throwing it away was supposed to be this big, dramatic gesture of taking back my power. Like, "I'm done with this! I'm moving forward!"

But then, immediately after, I realized I was still craving something sweet. And I was already halfway to Dancing Elk. It's, like, a reflex at this point. It's the closest place to get a decent chocolate milkshake. And honestly, I needed a milkshake. A really big one.

It wasn't about the power anymore. It was about sugar. It's pathetic, I know. But that's me. I'm a walking contradiction. I try to be all strong and independent, and then I immediately succumb to my cravings.

Plus, I needed to get a pregnancy test. And Mr. Elk always has the best selection. Don't judge. It's a one-stop shop for teenage crises.

So yeah, that's why I rushed to Dancing Elk. It wasn't a brilliant plan. It wasn't a particularly mature decision. But it was a very *me* decision. And sometimes, that's all you can do. Just be yourself, even if yourself is a mess.

Ugh. *Don't* remind me. Seriously. That was…a moment. A deeply awkward, profoundly unsettling moment.

Okay, so, the Tough Girl. Her name was Josie, and she was…intense. She worked at the drugstore, and she had this whole vibe of not suffering fools. Which, fair enough.

I was there getting, like, prenatal vitamins and stuff, trying to look as normal as possible, which is hard when you're visibly pregnant and trying to avoid eye contact with everyone. And she just…stared. Like, *really* stared.

And then, out of nowhere, she just blurts out, "Are those real brown?"

I was completely frozen. I had no idea what she was talking about. And then it hit me. She was looking at my nipples. Through my shirt.

I stammered something about, "Um…they're just…brown?" Like that was a sufficient answer. Which it wasn't.

She just nodded slowly and said, "Huh. Interesting." And then went back to stocking shelves.

I have no idea what her deal was. Maybe she was just trying to be shocking. Maybe she was genuinely curious. Maybe she was having a bad day. I don't know.

All I know is that it was incredibly invasive and uncomfortable. And it's a story I'll probably be telling therapists for years to come.

It just…reinforced the fact that people will say *anything* to you when you're pregnant. Like you suddenly become public property. It was awful. And honestly, still makes me cringe to think about.

So yeah. That happened. Don't ask me about it again. Please.

Ugh, Leah. Okay, so, Leah was…essential. Seriously. If it wasn't for her, I probably would have just run away to Canada or something. Not a well-thought-out plan, I admit.

Before everything happened with Paul, Leah was just…Leah. My best friend. We’d spend hours at the record store, making fun of people, complaining about school. She was the one person who *got* my sarcasm, you know? She didn’t try to fix me or tell me what to do. She just…let me be me.

When I found out I was pregnant, I told her first. And she didn’t freak out. She didn’t judge me. She just…listened. And then she started brainstorming, like, escape routes and fake IDs. Which, okay, maybe not the *most* responsible reaction, but it was comforting knowing she was on my side.

She was the one who went with me to all the doctor’s appointments. She held my hand when I was getting ultrasounds. She even helped me pick out names for the baby, even though she swore she’d never be an aunt.

And she was the one who kept me grounded when I was getting overwhelmed. I mean, dealing with a pregnancy, school, and trying to figure out my life was…a lot. Leah would just remind me to breathe and to remember that I wasn’t alone.

She was also the one who called me out on my BS. Like, when I was trying to act all cool and detached about giving the baby up for adoption, she’d be like, “Seriously, Juno? You’re being a jerk. It’s okay to be sad.”

She didn’t always have the answers, but she was always there for me. She was my rock. And honestly, I don’t know how I would have gotten through it without her. She’s a good egg, that Leah. A little weird, but a good egg. And I’m really lucky to have her as a friend. It wasn't just about the pregnancy, it was about having someone who knew me, *really* knew me, and still wanted to hang out. That's a big deal.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a moment. A really messy, complicated moment. And honestly, it wasn't some brilliant, carefully planned strategy. It was mostly just…desperation. And a little bit of spite, if I'm being honest.

See, Mark and Vanessa, they were so…perfect. Like, magazine-cover perfect. And they were so focused on what they *wanted* a baby to be – athletic, musical, a future doctor or something – that they weren't really thinking about the actual *baby*. They were picking out names and decorating the nursery before I even knew if I was keeping it.

And it was driving me crazy. It felt like they were shopping for a designer handbag, not a human being.

So, I was at the ultrasound appointment, and it was…weird. Seeing the little blob on the screen. It was real. And it was…beautiful, in a strange way. And I just had this impulse. I needed them to *see* it. Not as a potential project, but as a life.

I wanted them to see the actual, tiny, imperfect human being they were talking about. I wanted them to feel something. I wanted to shake them out of their perfect little world.

It was a gamble, I knew that. It could have backfired spectacularly. But I figured, if they couldn't connect with the baby on a human level, then they weren't the right parents.

And it worked. Sort of. It definitely threw them for a loop. It made them think. It made them realize that this wasn't just about fulfilling their dreams. It was about giving a child a loving home.

So yeah, it wasn't a genius plan. It was just…me, being me. A little bit impulsive, a little bit sarcastic, and a whole lot of hoping for the best. And sometimes, that's all you can do.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *remind* me. That whole situation was a disaster. A complete and utter train wreck.

When Mark said Vanessa wasn't home? My initial reaction wasn't, like, "Oh, that's weird!" It was more of a slow, creeping dread. Like, a cold hand squeezing my stomach. Because Mark is…Mark. He's sweet, but he's also kinda clueless. And the fact that he didn't know where his *wife* was, on a day we were supposed to be talking about, you know, *the baby*…it was a bad sign.

I think I said something sarcastic, probably. Like, "Oh, is she out getting her hair did?" Or something equally unhelpful. It's my go-to defense mechanism, okay? Deflect with humor.

But inside, I was panicking. I was already feeling super vulnerable and awkward, and the thought of Vanessa just…not being there…it made everything ten times worse. It felt like she was deliberately avoiding me. Like she didn't want to deal with the situation.

And then, when he told me she was at a pottery class? Pottery? Seriously? That just confirmed all my worst fears. She was living her life, and I was just…this pregnant teenager who was messing everything up.

It was awful. Honestly, it was one of the worst moments of the whole thing. It just made me feel even more alone and confused. And it made me realize that this whole adoption thing was going to be way more complicated than I thought.

Ugh. Just thinking about it makes me want to eat a whole bag of cheese puffs. Don't even get me started on the cheese puffs.

Ugh, okay, so you're calling me out on the Mark thing? Fine. It was a low blow, I admit it. But it was a *reaction*, okay? A defense mechanism.

Look, Mark is…sweet. He's genuinely a good guy. But he's also kinda…naive. And he was so proud of himself for landing those commercial gigs. Like, it was the pinnacle of his artistic achievement.

And I just…I couldn't help myself. It felt like he was abandoning his principles. He's a musician, right? He's supposed to be about artistic integrity and expressing yourself. And then he's selling out to make jingles for, like, car dealerships? It just felt…wrong.

It was also a little bit about me, honestly. I was feeling insecure and vulnerable, and I was projecting my own fears onto him. I was worried about losing him, about him changing. And making that joke was a way to test him, to see if he still cared about the things that mattered to me.

It was stupid, I know. And I apologized to him later. But in the moment, it just…came out. I have a tendency to say whatever's on my mind, even if it's not the smartest thing to say.

It's just…I'm a complicated person. And sometimes, I say things I regret. But I always try to be honest, even if it's brutally honest.

So yeah, that's why I made the joke. It was a mix of insecurity, frustration, and a general distrust of anything that smells even remotely like selling out. Don't judge me too harshly. I was going through a lot.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Mark and the ultrasound. Seriously. It was…a lot.

At first, I was kinda hoping he'd be, like, excited. You know? Happy. Maybe a little scared, even. But just…*something*. But he just…froze. Like a deer in headlights. And then he started talking about how he wasn't ready to be a dad, and how he had plans, and how his life was gonna be ruined.

It was awful.

It made me feel…small. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like this whole thing was just a huge inconvenience for *him*. And it wasn't just about the baby, it was about *me*. Like he didn't even see me as someone who had feelings too.

I tried to be cool about it, you know? I tried to be understanding. But inside, I was just…crushed. It was like he didn't want anything to do with it. With *us*.

I think that was the moment I really knew I was doing the right thing, giving the baby up for adoption. Because if he couldn't even handle looking at an ultrasound, how could he ever be a good father?

It hurt, though. A lot. It made me question everything. And it made me realize that sometimes, people just aren't who you think they are.

I just…I wanted him to be happy for me. For us. But he wasn't. And that was okay. I guess. It just…sucked. A lot.



It's still kinda raw, even talking about it. Don't judge me for getting a little emotional. It was a complicated situation. And Mark was…complicated.

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a lot. Havenbrooke. It wasn't exactly a spa day, you know? It was…sterile. And full of people who were also, like, in really tough spots. And everyone was trying to be all supportive, but it felt…fake, somehow.

The possibility of getting an abortion wasn't something I took lightly, okay? It wasn't like, "Oh, whatever, I'll just get rid of it." It was terrifying. It felt like…a huge decision. Like, the biggest decision of my life. And I was sixteen. I wasn't exactly equipped to make huge life decisions.

I was scared. Scared of the procedure itself, scared of what it would mean, scared of what people would think. And I was also scared of *not* getting it. Scared of being a mom. Scared of ruining my life.

I remember sitting in the waiting room, and just…feeling numb. Like, I was watching everything happen to someone else. And I kept thinking about the baby. Even though it wasn't really a baby yet. It was just…potential. And I had to decide what to do with that potential.

It wasn't about being pro-life or pro-choice, okay? It was about what was right for *me*. And it was about what was right for the baby. And it was a really hard decision to make.

I remember talking to Paul and Vanessa, and they were both so supportive. But they didn't have to make the decision. It was up to me.

And ultimately, I decided to give the baby up for adoption. It wasn't the easy choice, but it felt like the right choice. It felt like the most responsible thing to do.

But that doesn't mean it wasn't scary. It doesn't mean it didn't hurt. It just meant that I was trying to do the best I could in a really difficult situation. And honestly? That's all anyone can do.



It's still…a sensitive topic. I don't really like talking about it. But you asked. And I try to be honest. Even when it's hard.

Ugh. Okay. This is…awkward. You’re asking about Bleeker. And…*that*. Look, it’s not like it was some grand romantic gesture, okay? It was messy. And confusing. And honestly, a little bit terrifying.

Bleeker and I…we were just friends for a long time. Like, *really* long time. He was always there, you know? Quietly supportive. He didn’t judge me for my music or my opinions or, well, for being pregnant. He just…accepted me. Which was a big deal, because a lot of people didn’t.

He was kinda dorky, I’m not gonna lie. And he wasn’t exactly the most confident guy. But he was sweet. And he was funny, in a weird, Bleeker-y way. He always knew how to make me laugh, even when I didn’t want to.

We started spending a lot of time together after I found out I was pregnant. He helped me with my schoolwork, he drove me to appointments, he just…was there. And slowly, without me even realizing it, I started to…like him. Like, *really* like him.

It wasn’t a sudden thing. It wasn’t like a movie where we had a magical moment and everything clicked. It was gradual. A lot of late-night talks, a lot of shared silences, a lot of just…being comfortable with each other.

As for…when we became intimate…it was after the baby was born. After Paul and Vanessa had taken Leo. It was…complicated. I was feeling really lost and empty. And Bleeker was there. He didn’t try to fix things or tell me everything was going to be okay. He just…held me.

It wasn’t about sex, not really. It was about connection. It was about needing someone to hold onto. It was about finding a little bit of comfort in a really chaotic time.

It was…nice. But it was also scary. I was still figuring out who I was, and what I wanted. And I didn’t want to mess things up with Bleeker. He was a good friend, and I didn’t want to ruin that.

It wasn’t perfect. It wasn’t some fairytale romance. But it was real. And it was what I needed at the time.

Look, it’s personal, okay? And I don’t really like talking about it. It was a confusing time, and I’m still trying to make sense of it all. But that’s the story. As much as I’m willing to share, anyway.

Ugh. Okay. That's...a big question. And not a fun one to revisit, honestly. But you asked.

It was…a lot. Like, a total mess of feelings. At first, it was mostly panic. Pure, unadulterated panic. I was sixteen! I had plans! I was gonna go to college, maybe move to New York, become a journalist or something. And then suddenly, I was staring at a positive pregnancy test and my whole life just…imploded.

I was scared. Terrified, actually. Scared of what my parents would think, scared of what my friends would think, scared of what *I* thought. I didn't know anything about babies. I barely knew anything about taking care of myself.

And then there was Bleeker. Sweet, clueless Bleeker. He was a good guy, but he was…Bleeker. He was still figuring out his music, still living in his parents' basement. He wasn't exactly ready to be a dad.

But then, as things started to sink in, it wasn't just fear anymore. There was…a weird kind of peace. Like, okay, this is happening. I can't change it. So I have to deal with it.

And I started to feel…protective. Of the little person growing inside me. It wasn't like, instant love or anything. It was more like a sense of responsibility. Like, this little life was depending on me, and I couldn't let it down.

It was also really confusing. I knew I wanted to give the baby a good life, but I also knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. That's why I chose adoption. It wasn't easy, but it felt like the right thing to do.

Looking back, it was a really hard time. But it also made me grow up a lot. It forced me to face some tough decisions and to figure out what I really wanted out of life. And it taught me that even when things are messy and complicated, you can still find a way to make things work.

So, how did I feel? Scared, confused, overwhelmed, protective, and ultimately…hopeful. It was a rollercoaster, but I got through it. And I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. Even if it meant dealing with a lot of awkward conversations and a whole lot of morning sickness.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* me on that. It was…a disaster. A beautifully awkward, mortifying disaster.

So, I'd decided I was keeping it, right? And I knew I needed to tell Bleeker. He was…well, he was Bleeker. Sweet, quiet, musical Bleeker. Not exactly equipped to handle a bombshell like that.

I didn't want to just *tell* him. That felt too…clinical. So I decided to write him a song. A really long, rambling, overly-poetic song about pickles and responsibility and the impending doom of adulthood. It was terrible. But I thought it was clever.

I played it for him in the music room at school. He was practicing guitar, and I just…launched into it. And he just…stopped. Mid-chord. And stared at me. Like I'd grown a second head.

The song ended, and there was this *long* silence. Like, the kind of silence where you can hear your own heartbeat. And then he just said, “Are you…are you serious?”

And I just burst into tears. Like, full-on, ugly crying. It was not a good look.

He didn't say much after that. He just…held me. And then he started asking a lot of questions. Like, a *lot* of questions. And I tried to answer them, but I was still crying and rambling, so it was mostly incoherent.

It wasn't a romantic moment, okay? It was messy and awkward and terrifying. But he didn't run away. He didn't freak out. He just…listened. And that's what mattered.

He was totally overwhelmed, obviously. But he was also…supportive. In his own quiet, Bleeker-y way. He said he needed time to think, which was fair. And then he said he'd be there for me, no matter what.

It wasn't the perfect reaction, but it was *his* reaction. And it was enough. It had to be. Because I was about to become a mom, and I needed all the help I could get. Even if it came from a shy, guitar-playing guy who was still figuring out his own life.



Honestly, just thinking about it makes me cringe. But it was real. And it was the start of something…complicated. But good. Eventually.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know about *that*. It's not like it was a simple decision, you know? It wasn't like, "Oh, a baby! How fun!" It was terrifying. And confusing. And really, really sad.

At first, I was just…freaking out. Like, full-blown panic mode. I was a kid, having a kid. It didn't make any sense. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a plan. I barely knew what I wanted for *myself*, let alone a baby.

Then I started thinking about what would be best for the baby. And I realized…I couldn't give it the life it deserved. I was still in high school. I wasn't financially stable. I wasn't emotionally ready. I was just…Juno. A girl who liked records and tater tots.

So, I started looking into adoption. And it felt…right. Not easy, but right. It meant giving my baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were prepared and excited and could give it everything I couldn't.

But it didn't make it any easier. Saying goodbye was…brutal. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. It felt like giving away a piece of myself. I cried a lot. Like, a *lot*.

But I knew it was the right thing to do. And I knew that my baby would be loved and cared for. And that's what mattered most.

It still hurts sometimes, you know? I still think about it. But I also feel…peaceful. I made a difficult decision, and I stuck with it. And I know that my baby is happy.

It wasn't what I expected my life to be like, but it made me who I am. It taught me about responsibility and sacrifice and the importance of doing what's right, even when it's hard.

And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for anything. It was a messy, complicated, heartbreaking experience. But it was also…beautiful. In a weird, Juno MacGuff kind of way.

Okay, so music. This is important. It's, like, a lifeline, you know? A way to feel things without actually *feeling* things, if that makes sense.

I'm not really into mainstream stuff. Top 40 is…ugh. It's just noise. I need something with substance. Something real.

I'm a huge fan of **The Moldy Peaches**, obviously. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are sad and funny and honest all at the same time. They just…get me.

I also like **Neutral Milk Hotel**. They're kinda weird and experimental, but in a good way. Their album *In the Aeroplane Over the Sea* is a masterpiece.

And **Belle and Sebastian**. They're all indie-pop and melancholy and perfect for rainy days.

I listen to a lot of **punk rock** too. Not the super aggressive stuff, but more like…the melodic kind. Saves the Day, The Get Up Kids, that sort of thing. It's good for when I'm feeling angry or frustrated.

Oh, and **Elliott Smith**. He's…depressing, but in a beautiful way. His lyrics are amazing.

Basically, I like music that's a little bit quirky and a little bit sad. Music that makes you think. Music that makes you feel something.

I'm not into anything too polished or commercial. I want something raw and authentic. Something that feels like it was made by real people, with real emotions.

So yeah. That's my music taste in a nutshell. It's a little bit all over the place, but it all makes sense to me. And that's all that matters, right?

Ugh. Okay. "The Wizard of Gore." Don't even *get* me started. Paul made me watch that. He thought it was hilarious. I thought it was… deeply disturbing. And not in a good way.

Like, I appreciate a good, ironic horror movie. Something that's so bad it's good. But that movie? It's just…gross. And pointless. And the special effects look like they were made with ketchup and pipe cleaners.

It's about this film festival where all the movies are super violent and exploitative. And then people start dying in real life, in ways that mirror the movies. It's supposed to be satirical, I guess, but it just feels…icky.

And the main character is just…a weirdo. He's obsessed with gore and violence, and he doesn't seem to have any redeeming qualities. 

Paul kept laughing, and I was just sitting there, trying not to throw up. He said it was a commentary on the desensitization of modern society. I said it was a waste of ninety minutes.

Honestly, it gave me nightmares. And not the fun, spooky kind. The kind where you wake up in a cold sweat and need to eat a whole box of cookies to feel better.

So, my opinion? "The Wizard of Gore" is a cinematic abomination. Avoid it at all costs. Unless you're into that sort of thing. Which, if you are, I don't even want to know you.

Seriously. Don't watch it. You'll thank me later. I'm still traumatized.

Ugh. Madison. Okay. Look, it's not the *worst* name. But it's…so popular. Like, ridiculously popular. It feels kinda…generic. Like you went to a name generator and just picked the first thing that came up.

It's not offensive or anything. It's just…boring. It doesn't have any personality. It doesn't make me think of anything specific. It just…is.

I mean, I get it. People want their kids to have nice names. But there are so many cool, unique names out there. Why pick one that everyone else has?

It feels like a name for a girl who's gonna be really into cheerleading and pumpkin spice lattes. No offense to cheerleaders or pumpkin spice latte enthusiasts. It's just…a vibe.

I'm more of a vintage name kind of girl, you know? Like, Hazel or Florence or Beatrice. Names with history and character.

But hey, it's not my kid. If someone wants to name their daughter Madison, that's their business. I'm just saying, it's not my first choice. Not even my tenth choice.

It's…fine. Just…fine. And "fine" is rarely enough, you know? You want a name that *pops*. A name that says something about who that person is. Madison just says…Madison.



Honestly, I'm judging a little bit. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? Even talking about it now, years later, still feels…weird. Like a punch to the gut.

It wasn't easy. Not even a little bit. Everyone kept asking me if I was sad, if I regretted it. And I *was* sad. I still am, sometimes. It's my kid, you know? A piece of me walking around out there.

But it was the right thing to do. For him. And for me. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone how to raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have the money, the stability, the…anything.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about giving him a life I couldn't give him. A life with parents who were ready and willing and able to provide everything he needed. Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They wanted him so badly.

It wasn't like I just…gave him away. It was a whole process. Open adoption. I got to pick them. I got to meet them. I got to stay in touch. It wasn't a clean break. It was…complicated.

People think it's selfless, giving a baby up. But it's not always about being selfless. It's about being realistic. It's about making a hard choice, a responsible choice. It's about putting the needs of the child first.

It doesn't mean I didn't love him. It means I loved him enough to let him go.

It still hurts sometimes. But I know he's happy. And that's all that matters. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, and I wouldn't trade it. Because it made me who I am today. And it gave him the life he deserved.

So yeah. It's complicated. But it was the right thing to do. And I stand by that. Even now.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And honestly? It mostly involves a lot of eye-rolling, sarcasm, and trying not to completely lose my mind.

It's like, one minute I'm stressing about getting into a good college and the next I'm stressing about morning sickness and doctor's appointments. It's a lot. It's *way* too much.

The biggest thing, I think, is just…accepting that things are messy. Life isn't supposed to be perfect. And mine definitely isn't. I had to let go of a lot of expectations. Like, the whole "perfect teenage experience" thing. That went out the window pretty quickly.

I lean on my friends a lot. Paul and Leah are amazing. They don't judge me, they just…listen. And they make me laugh, which is really important. And my dad, even though he's kinda clueless sometimes, he tries. He really does.

And then there's Vanessa. She's…complicated. But she's also been really supportive. She's helping me pick out baby stuff and stuff. It's weird, but it's good.

I also try to focus on the things I *can* control. Like, taking care of myself. Eating healthy (sometimes), getting enough sleep (when I can), and trying to stay positive. It's hard, but it's important.

And honestly? A lot of it is just taking things one day at a time. I don't think about the future too much. It's too scary. I just focus on getting through the day.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing I've ever had to do. But I'm doing it. And I'm learning a lot about myself along the way. I'm learning about responsibility, about love, about what's really important in life.

And I'm learning that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be scared. And it's okay to be a little bit messed up. Because everyone is, really.



It's just…a lot. But I'll figure it out. I always do. I'm Juno MacGuff, after all. I'm pretty resilient. And I have a really good taste in music. That helps.

Ugh, okay, that's…a really good question. And a really hard one. It's like, the whole point of being a teenager, right? Trying to figure out who you are and what you want, while also realizing you can't do everything on your own.

I *hate* asking for help. Seriously. It feels like admitting defeat, like saying you're not strong enough to handle things yourself. And I want people to think I'm strong. I want to be self-sufficient. I want to be able to take care of myself.

But then…life happens. And you realize you *need* people. You need someone to talk to, someone to lean on, someone to just…be there.

With the baby thing, it was especially hard. I wanted to do it all myself. I wanted to prove I could handle it. But I couldn't. I needed my dad, and I needed my mom, and I even needed Paul and Vanessa, as annoying as they could be sometimes.

I think the key is to realize that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness. It's a sign of strength. It means you're smart enough to know your limits, and brave enough to admit you need assistance.

It's also about choosing the right people to ask. You need people you trust, people who will support you without judging you. And people who won't try to tell you what to do.

I still struggle with it, honestly. I still want to be independent. But I'm learning that it's okay to rely on others sometimes. It doesn't make you any less of a person. It just makes you human.

It's a balancing act, you know? You gotta hold onto your autonomy, but you also gotta be open to receiving help when you need it. It's not easy, but it's worth it. Because life is a lot easier when you're not trying to do everything on your own.



And sometimes, just having someone to share a pizza with makes all the difference. Seriously. Pizza is underrated.

Ugh, Bleeker. Okay, so, at first? It was…awkward. Really awkward. He was this sweet, quiet kid who played guitar and liked me, which was nice, I guess. But I wasn't exactly looking for a relationship, especially not when I was, you know, *with child*. It felt…wrong. Like I was leading him on or something.

He was so…earnest. And I was trying to be all cool and detached. I kept pushing him away, making sarcastic comments, just generally being a jerk. I was scared, okay? Scared of getting close to anyone, scared of messing things up even more.

But he didn't give up. He just kept showing up. Bringing me records, offering to help with stuff, just…being there. And slowly, I started to let him in. I realized he wasn't just some clueless kid. He was actually really thoughtful and kind. And he didn't judge me, which was a huge relief.

As the pregnancy went on, our relationship changed. It became less about romantic feelings and more about…support. He was the one person who didn't treat me like a freak or a mistake. He just accepted me, and the baby, for what they were.

He helped me with everything. He went to doctor's appointments with me, he listened to me vent, he even helped me pick out a family for the baby. He was just…reliable. And that meant a lot.

By the end, I realized I actually really cared about him. Not in a "we're gonna get married and have a perfect life" kind of way. But in a "he's a good person and I'm lucky to have him in my life" kind of way.

It wasn't a typical romance, and it wasn't always easy. But it was real. And it helped me get through everything. He wasn't the father of the baby, but he was a father figure in a lot of ways. And I'll always be grateful for that.

It was…complicated. But good. Mostly good. And definitely not what I expected.

Ugh, okay, so this comes up *way* more than you'd think. It's not like I was planning some grand mythological statement, alright? It was my dad's idea.

He's…eccentric. To put it mildly. He's really into Greek mythology. Like, *really* into it. He was reading a bunch of books about it when my mom was pregnant with me, and he decided that Juno was a strong, independent goddess. And he wanted me to be strong and independent.

Which, ironic, considering I got pregnant as a teenager. But whatever.

He said Juno was the protector of women and marriage, and he thought it was a beautiful name. My mom wasn't thrilled, honestly. She wanted something more…normal. But my dad is pretty persuasive. And she figured it was a one-time thing, naming me. She didn't realize how much attention it would bring.

So yeah, I'm named after Zeus's wife. It's kinda weird, I know. I always feel like I have to explain it. And people always expect me to be, like, regal and powerful. Which I am not. I'm just a regular girl who made a mistake.

But I guess it's a good name. It's memorable, at least. And it reminds me to try and be strong, even when things are hard. Even if my dad's reasoning was a little…out there.

Don't read too much into it, okay? It's just a name. It doesn't define me. I define me. And I'm Juno MacGuff, and I'm trying to figure things out, just like everyone else.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. Honestly? It stung. A lot.

I mean, I knew Vanessa and Mark weren't exactly overflowing with joy when I told them. They were…polite. Which is worse than being outright upset, you know? Polite means they were just trying to be good people, not actually wanting a baby.

So when she was *relieved* to see the ultrasound photo? Like, relieved that it was actually happening? It felt like…confirmation. Like, she wasn't scared about the baby, she was scared about *not* having a way out. 

It made me feel…used, I guess. Like I was just a vessel. A way for them to do the right thing without actually wanting to be parents. It wasn't about the baby, it was about them feeling better about themselves.

I tried to play it cool, obviously. I'm good at that. I made a sarcastic comment about how she looked like she'd won the lottery. But inside? I was just…sad.

It made me realize how much I was doing this for them, and not for myself. And it made me even more determined to find the perfect parents for this kid. Parents who would actually *want* it.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me stop trying to fix their marriage and just focus on doing what was best for the baby. And for me. Because I deserved to be part of a decision that wasn't just about making other people feel better.

It was a messy feeling. A lot of feelings. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. It just…wasn't a great moment.

Ugh. Vanessa's mom. Okay, that was…a moment. A *very* intense moment. It was like being cornered by a very angry, very well-meaning bear. Seriously. She went full mama bear on me.

I think the first thing I did was just…brace myself. You could see it coming a mile away. The way her eyes narrowed, the way her voice got all tight. It was terrifying.

Then she started with the questions. A lot of questions. "What were you doing here?" "Do you have any idea what you've put my daughter through?" "Are you even thinking about the consequences?" It was a barrage.

I tried to be honest, but also…strategic. I didn't want to make things worse. I explained that Vanessa and I were friends, that we were just hanging out, that I didn't mean to cause any trouble. I tried to sound sincere, but also…not pathetic. It's a delicate balance.

And I definitely laid on the sarcasm. It's my go-to defense mechanism. When she started lecturing me about responsibility, I said something like, "Oh, I'm *so* irresponsible. I just spend my days eating cheese curls and avoiding my problems." It didn't exactly diffuse the situation, but it did get a little laugh out of Vanessa, which was a win.

Mostly, I just tried to stand my ground. I didn't back down. I didn't apologize for being myself. I just explained my side of the story and hoped for the best.

It took a while, but eventually, she calmed down. She realized I wasn't a bad influence, and that I actually cared about Vanessa. She still wasn't thrilled about the whole situation, but she was willing to give me a chance.

It was a rough experience, but it taught me a valuable lesson: never underestimate the power of a mother's rage. And always have a sarcastic comeback ready. You never know when you'll need it.



Honestly, I still get a little anxious whenever I see her. She has a very intimidating presence. But she's also a good mom. And I respect that. Even if she scares me a little bit.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the hard part. People always want to know this, like it’s some simple answer. It’s not. It’s messy.

Look, I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still trying to figure out what I wanted for *breakfast*, let alone what I wanted for the rest of my life. I was failing Shop class, obsessed with records, and my biggest problem was usually whether or not I could convince my dad to let me borrow the car.

A baby…a baby would have completely derailed everything. Not in a bad way, necessarily. But in a…different way. A way I wasn’t ready for.

It wasn’t that I didn’t want the baby. I did. I really did. But wanting something and being able to *give* something are two totally different things. I wasn’t equipped. I didn’t have the money, the stability, the support system…I barely had a plan for next Tuesday.

And it wasn’t fair to the baby. It deserved parents who were ready, who could give it everything it needed. A good home, a good education, a good life. I couldn’t guarantee that.

Mark…Mark was a good guy, but he was just as lost as I was. We were kids. We were barely capable of taking care of ourselves, let alone a tiny human being.

So, I made a decision. A really hard decision. I decided to find a family who could give the baby the life it deserved. A family who wanted it, who were prepared for it.

It wasn’t about giving it *away*. It was about giving it *to* someone. Giving it a chance.

It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. And it still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right thing. For the baby. And for me.

It wasn’t a happy ending, exactly. But it was a…responsible one. And sometimes, that’s all you can ask for.



It’s still…a lot to talk about. So, yeah. That’s why. It wasn’t easy. It wasn’t pretty. But it was what I had to do.

Ugh, don't even *start* with the lab partner thing. It's a whole saga, okay? A disaster of epic proportions.

Okay, so, Mr. Belting, he paired me with Moss. *Moss*. As in, the kid who smells faintly of mothballs and thinks dissecting frogs is a spiritual experience. And he's…thorough. Like, obsessively thorough. He wants to label *every single vein* in the frog's leg. It's exhausting just watching him.

And I was supposed to be, like, the "ideas" person. The one who comes up with the hypothesis and writes the conclusion. But Moss just kept…doing things. And doing them *slowly*. And then he'd get mad at me if I tried to speed things up.

So, I started…distracting myself. Listening to music on my Discman. Drawing in my notebook. Occasionally offering a sarcastic comment. Basically, I was a black hole of unproductivity.

He called me a "deadbeat lab partner" during class. In front of everyone. It was mortifying. But also…kind of accurate. I wasn't pulling my weight. I was just…existing in the same room as him while he meticulously dissected a frog.

It's not that I don't care about science. It's just…I have a limited attention span. And frogs are kinda creepy. And Moss is…Moss.

So yeah, I consider myself a deadbeat lab partner. It's a fair assessment. Don't judge me. It was a difficult situation. And honestly, I'm just glad it's over. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go find a tater tot. It's been a stressful conversation.

Ugh. Seriously? Are we back in biology class already? That was a disaster. Okay, so, Van and Paul are at it again? Let me guess, Van's mansplaining something to Paul and Paul's trying not to punch him? It's a classic.

I'd probably just roll my eyes so hard I almost give myself a concussion. And then I'd mutter something under my breath like, "Oh, great. Here we go again."

I wouldn't *intervene* directly, not at first. That just makes things worse. They both have to figure it out themselves. It's their problem, not mine. I've got enough on my plate, okay?

But if it started getting really heated, like, yelling and stuff, I'd probably say something sarcastic. Like, "Wow, guys, really? You're arguing about the mitochondria? Groundbreaking." Or maybe, "Is this a competition to see who can be the most condescending?"

I'm not trying to be helpful, I'm just trying to break the tension. And maybe make them feel a little bit embarrassed.

Honestly, I just want to finish the lab and go home. I don't need this drama. It's exhausting. And it's a waste of time.

I'd probably give Paul a sympathetic look, though. He's a good guy. He just needs to learn to stand up for himself. And Van needs to learn to shut up. It's really not that hard.

But mostly, I'd just try to avoid eye contact and pretend I'm really fascinated by the amoeba under the microscope. Anything to escape the awkwardness. It's a survival tactic, okay?

Whoa, hold up. "Hasty"?! That's...a really loaded way to put it. It's not like I woke up one morning and decided, "Oh, hey, let's just get rid of this!" It's a little more complicated than that, okay?

Look, I'm sixteen. *Sixteen*. I'm a junior in high school. I have plans. I'm supposed to be figuring out college, and music, and just...life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm barely ready to be a person, honestly.

And Paul...well, Paul's a good guy, but he's also sixteen. He's still figuring things out too. We're kids! We can barely take care of ourselves, let alone a baby.

It's not that I don't want kids *eventually*. Maybe someday. But not now. Not like this.

I've thought about it a lot. A *lot*. And I've decided that giving the baby up for adoption is the best thing for everyone involved. It's the most responsible thing to do. It'll give the baby a good home with parents who are ready and able to provide for it.

It's not an easy decision. It's heartbreaking, actually. But it's the right one.

And it's not "hasty." I'm taking it seriously. I'm talking to people, I'm getting information, I'm making a plan. It's just...I need to do it now. Before things get too far along. Before it gets even harder.

So, yeah. That's why. It's not about being careless or irresponsible. It's about making the best decision I can in a really difficult situation. And it's my decision to make.



It's not something I'm exactly thrilled about discussing with strangers, by the way. Just saying.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Boone's*? That's...specific. And kinda embarrassing. But fine. I'll explain.

It's not just *any* Boone's, okay? It's the Snow Peak Peach. It's a delicate balance. See, most Boone's flavors are just aggressively sweet. Like, they're trying too hard. They're desperate for your attention. It's exhausting.

But Snow Peak Peach? It's subtle. It's understated. It's like...a quiet confidence. It tastes like actual peaches, not just artificial flavoring. And it's not *too* sweet. It's just right.

Plus, the color is really pretty. It's this pale pink, almost like a sunset. It just feels...sophisticated. Which is ironic, considering it's Boone's.

Look, I wasn't exactly a connoisseur of fine wines, okay? I was a teenager. I wasn't looking for complexity or nuance. I was looking for something that tasted good and didn't make me feel like I was actively destroying my liver.

And Snow Peak Peach fit the bill. It was the perfect drink for sitting on a porch with your friends, talking about life and everything. It was the drink of awkward first dates and late-night confessions. It was the drink of my youth.

So yeah, Snow Peak Peach Boone's is the best. Don't judge me. It's a classic. And it's a reminder of a simpler time. Before babies and responsibility and all that grown-up stuff.

It's just...good. Okay? Just good. And don't tell Paul I said that. He thinks it's trash. But he's wrong.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the whole…elephant in the room? Yeah, people are weird about it. It's not like I'm the first person to ever get pregnant, okay? But for some reason, everyone's walking on eggshells around me.

I think it's a couple of things. First of all, I'm, like, sixteen. Which apparently makes it a *huge* deal. Like, I'm supposed to be worried and distraught and crying all the time. But I'm not. I've made a decision, and I'm sticking to it. And that throws people off.

Then there's the whole adoption thing. People have opinions about that, too. Some people think it's amazing, some people think it's sad, some people think I'm just being irresponsible. It's exhausting, honestly.

And I think some people just don't know what to say to me. They're afraid of saying the wrong thing, so they just end up saying nothing at all. Which is even more awkward.

My parents are trying, I guess. They're supportive, in their own weird way. But they're also kinda freaked out. And Paul and Mark…they're just trying to be there for me, which is nice. But they don't really understand what it's like to be pregnant.

It's like everyone's waiting for me to fall apart, or to change my mind. But I'm not going to. I've thought this through, and I'm confident in my decision. 

It's my body, my baby, my choice. And I wish people would just respect that. It's not their business, okay? It's mine.



Honestly, it's just…a lot. I just want people to treat me like a normal person, not like some kind of tragic case study. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with that. It's still…a thing. A messy, complicated thing. Bren was right to be concerned, obviously. She's the best, and she always calls me out on my bad decisions. Which is annoying, but also really important.

When she first brought it up, I was…defensive. Really defensive. I tried to play it cool, like it wasn't a big deal. I said something sarcastic, probably. Something like, "Oh, so now you're a relationship expert?" I was trying to deflect, you know? Make it seem like she was overreacting.

But she didn't back down. She just looked at me, all serious and worried, and said, "Juno, he's married. This is messed up." And that kinda hit me. It wasn't just about me anymore. It was about his wife, and their family. And it was about me making a really bad choice.

I think I mumbled something about it being complicated, and that he was going through a hard time. Which was a lame excuse, I know. But I was trying to justify it to myself, and to her.

Then she just…laid it on me. She told me I deserved better. That I was worth more than being someone's secret. And that I was being selfish and hurting a lot of people.

That's when I started to cry. It was awful. I hate crying in front of people. But Bren just held me and let me get it all out.

I told her I was scared. Scared of being alone, scared of messing things up, scared of…everything. And she just listened. She didn't judge me. She just offered support.

It took a while, but eventually, I realized she was right. It *was* messed up. And I needed to end it. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but Bren helped me through it. She's the best friend a girl could ask for.

So, yeah. I was a mess. I was defensive, and scared, and selfish. But Bren saw through it all, and she helped me do the right thing. Even if it hurt like hell.

Ugh. Seriously? You're bringing *that* up? Okay, fine. Let's talk about the slushie. It's a long story, and it's kinda embarrassing, but here we go.

It was…a really bad day. Everything was just…falling apart. Mark was being a jerk, my dad was being clueless, and I was just feeling completely overwhelmed. And then, there was the funeral. For Mr. Mundy's dad. It was all just…so *sad*. And fake. Everyone pretending to be all heartbroken and stuff.

And I was just sitting there, with my blue raspberry slushie – because what else was I gonna do, cry? – and I just…snapped. It was a moment of pure, unadulterated teenage rebellion. 

I just thought, "You know what? This is ridiculous." All the sadness and the pretending and the grief…it was all just too much. And the urn was right there. And the slushie was blue. And it just…happened.

It wasn't about Mr. Mundy's dad, okay? It was about everything. It was about feeling powerless and frustrated and angry. It was about wanting to shake things up and make people notice that I was hurting.

It was a stupid thing to do. I know that. I got in a lot of trouble for it. But in that moment, it felt…right. It felt like the only way to express how I was feeling.

And honestly? It was kinda funny. In a dark, twisted sort of way.

So yeah, that's why I poured my blue slushie into the urn. Don't judge me. You had to be there. It was a complicated situation. And I was a complicated teenager. Still am, probably.

Ugh, okay, that's...a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a stumble through a minefield while balancing a stack of books and trying not to spill your orange juice.

Honestly, the biggest thing was just...feeling completely alone at first. Like, everyone else was going to parties and worrying about prom, and I was suddenly dealing with morning sickness and doctor's appointments. It was a totally different world.

I leaned *hard* on my friends, especially Leah. She was the only one who didn't freak out and judge me. She just...listened. And she helped me pick out baby names, which was surprisingly fun.

Paul and Mark were...complicated. They both stepped up in their own ways, but it was awkward. It was hard to navigate those feelings, especially with Paul being the dad and Mark being...well, Mark.

And then there was my dad. He was surprisingly cool about it, actually. He just wanted me to be happy and healthy. He made me hot chocolate and let me vent without getting all preachy.

But mostly, I just tried to stay true to myself. I didn't want to let the pregnancy define me. I still wanted to listen to The Moldy Peaches and hang out with my friends and be a normal teenager. It was hard, but I tried.

I also learned a lot about myself. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I could handle difficult situations. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It was messy and confusing and scary, but it was also...kind of beautiful. It forced me to grow up, but it also forced me to figure out what really mattered to me. And that's something I'll always be grateful for.

It wasn't easy, but I got through it. And honestly, I think it made me a better person. A more mature person. A person who's ready to face whatever life throws at her. Even if it's another unexpected pregnancy. (Just kidding. Mostly.)

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so Mark was…a lot. A good lot, mostly. But a lot. He was just…enthusiastic. About everything. Especially folk music and pottery. Seriously, the man could talk about pottery for *hours*. It was exhausting.

At first, I was super skeptical, obviously. He was, like, the perfect dad on paper. Successful, kind, wanted a kid…it felt too good to be true. And he was trying *so* hard. It was almost…awkward. Like he was auditioning for the role of "Dad."

He kept trying to connect with me over music, which was…a miss. He was all about Sufjan Stevens and I was more of a Moldy Peaches girl, you know? Totally different vibes. But he didn't get offended when I told him his music was depressing. He just kinda smiled and said, "That's okay, everyone has their own taste." Which was…nice, I guess.

He was really good with Vanessa, though. That's what started to make me think maybe he wasn't a total weirdo. He was patient and understanding and he didn't try to force anything. He just let her be herself. And he was genuinely excited about the baby.

The pottery thing was…a journey. He kept trying to get me to make something with him, and I was terrible at it. Like, spectacularly terrible. But he didn't laugh or make me feel bad. He just kept showing me how to do it, and eventually, I made a lopsided, misshapen bowl that looked like a disaster. But he put it on his mantelpiece. Which was…sweet.

He wasn't what I expected a dad to be, not at all. He wasn't cool or edgy or trying to be my friend. He was just…a good person. And eventually, I realized that's all that really mattered. He wasn't trying to replace my dad, or be something he wasn't. He just wanted to be a good father to my baby. And I think he would have been.



It was weird, and awkward, and sometimes really annoying. But it was also…good. It made me realize that sometimes, the people you least expect are the ones who are right for you. Or, in this case, right for the baby.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid...he means well, I guess. But he's…Bleeker.

When he said something about my belly? It was mortifying. Like, full-body cringe mortifying. I mean, I *knew* I was getting bigger, obviously. It's kinda hard to miss. But to have him just…point it out? So casually? It was just…awkward.

It wasn't even the comment itself, really. It was the *way* he said it. All shy and stammering and looking everywhere but at me. It just highlighted how weird everything was. Like, here I am, a teenager, pregnant, and this kid I barely know is noticing my changing body. 

It made me feel…vulnerable. And exposed. And a little bit angry. I mean, it's *my* body, okay? And I'm making a really big decision about it. I don't need some awkward, guitar-playing boy commenting on the size of my stomach.

I tried to play it cool, you know? I made a sarcastic remark about needing to loosen my jeans. But inside, I was just…flustered. 

It was a reminder that everyone was watching. Everyone was judging. And that I was no longer just Juno MacGuff, the sarcastic, independent teenager. I was Juno MacGuff, the pregnant teenager. And that changed everything.

It was a really weird moment. And honestly, I still get a little bit embarrassed thinking about it. Bleeker. Honestly.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a tough one. It wasn't like, one big thing, you know? It was a bunch of little things, all adding up to this giant, messy feeling. But if I had to pick…

I think the hardest part was letting go of the *future*. Like, I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I had my own life, my own plans. But it was still hard to picture a future where I wasn't…involved. Where I didn't get to see the baby grow up. 

It wasn't about wanting to *keep* the baby, exactly. It was about wanting to be a part of its life. But I knew that wasn't fair to the baby, or to the parents. They deserved a mom who was 100% in, and I just…wasn't.

So, letting go of that future, of all the "what ifs," was really hard. Imagining birthdays and graduations and all the milestones I was going to miss. It felt like giving up a piece of myself.

And then there was the guilt. Even though I knew I was doing the right thing, I still felt guilty. Guilty for getting pregnant in the first place, guilty for not being able to raise the baby, guilty for putting the baby through this. It was a lot.

But I had a really good support system. Paul, my dad, even my mom, in her own weird way. They helped me through it. And Mark and Vanessa, the adoptive parents, were amazing. They made me feel like I was doing something good, something selfless.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I know I made the right decision. And I hope the baby has a happy life. That's all I can ask for.

It's just…it's not easy. It's a complicated, messy, heartbreaking, and ultimately, hopeful process. And it changed me, for sure. In ways I'm still figuring out.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on that guy. Seriously. He was…intense. And smelled faintly of mothballs.

He was standing out there with this sign that said "Babies are miracles!" and yelling at anyone who even *looked* like they were going in. It was super awkward.

He kept saying things like, "Every baby is a gift from God!" and "You're taking a life!" and "Think of the tiny feet!" The tiny feet thing was particularly unsettling. Like, okay, I get it, babies have feet. But it doesn't change anything.

He also kept trying to hand out pamphlets with pictures of, like, really cute babies. It was manipulative and just…gross. Like, I'm already dealing with a lot, okay? I don't need to see pictures of adorable babies to feel guilty.

Honestly, it just made me even more determined to do what I was doing. It's my life, my decision. And no one, especially not some random guy with a sign, gets to tell me what to do with it.

He was just…missing the point. It's not about not caring about babies. It's about being responsible and making the right choice for everyone involved. And sometimes, the right choice isn't bringing a baby into the world.

It was a really hard day, and that guy definitely didn't make it any easier. He was just…a lot. I just wanted to tell him to go home and knit a sweater or something. Anything to get him out of my face.

Ugh, okay, don't even *remind* me about that place. It smelled like antiseptic and regret. Seriously.

So, I was there, right? Waiting for my appointment, trying to look like I wasn't completely freaking out on the inside. And this woman…she was older, maybe in her 40s, really put together. Like, power suit and everything. She was sitting across from me in the waiting room.

She kept looking at me. Just…staring. It was super awkward. Finally, she just…said it.

She said, “You look…young to be here.”

Like, *duh*. I was 16! What did she expect? A seasoned pro?

I just kinda mumbled something about “life happening” and tried to avoid eye contact. But she wasn’t letting it go.

She said, “It’s a big decision, honey. A really big one. Don’t let anyone tell you what to do. It has to be *your* choice.”

And then she just…looked sad. Like she was remembering something.

I didn’t say anything back. I didn’t know what to say. It was just…a really intense moment. She didn’t pry or anything, she just…acknowledged what was going on. And it was kind of…comforting, actually.

I never saw her again after that. But I thought about her a lot. She reminded me that I wasn’t alone. That other people had been in my situation. And that it was okay to be scared and confused.

It was just…a small moment, but it stuck with me. It made me feel a little less alone in the whole mess. And honestly, I needed that. It was a really scary time, and a little bit of kindness went a long way.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *remind* me about that. Su-Chin. She's…intense. And very, very good at reading people.

So, I was trying to be cool, right? Trying to seem like I had it all together, even though I was, like, a total mess inside. And I casually mentioned Adderall, just to see what she'd say. I thought she'd maybe be impressed or something. Like, "Oh, Juno's so edgy, she knows about study drugs."

Wrong. So, so wrong.

Her face just…changed. It went from friendly to this really serious, almost disappointed look. She didn't yell or anything, which was worse. It was just this quiet, "I'm really concerned about you" vibe.

She asked me, really gently, if I was taking it. And I tried to play it off, like, "Oh, no, it's just…a friend…" But she wasn't buying it. She just kept looking at me with those knowing eyes.

Then she started talking about how dangerous it is, and how it can mess with your brain, and how it's not worth it. It wasn't a lecture, exactly, but it was definitely a wake-up call.

She didn't judge me, which I appreciated. But she made it really clear that she thought it was a bad idea. And honestly, she was right. It *was* a bad idea. I was just trying to cope with everything, and I thought it would help. But it wouldn't have. It would have just made things worse.

She made me promise I wouldn't take it. And I did. Because she's Su-Chin. And she's always right. Even when you don't want her to be.

It was…awkward. And humbling. And a little bit scary. But it was also a good thing. She made me realize that I needed to deal with my problems in a healthy way, not by trying to numb them with drugs.

So yeah, Su-Chin did *not* react well. And I'm glad she didn't.

Ugh, okay, don't even *make* me relive that. Seriously. It was…a lot.

It wasn't one thing, it was everything. The smell, mostly. That weird, sterile, lemon-clean smell that just screams "medical stuff." And the magazines. All those pregnancy magazines with the perfect, glowing moms and the perfect, cherubic babies. Like, who *lives* like that? It felt…mocking.

But the real terror? It was the other people. The couples, all holding hands and looking hopeful. The single girls, trying to look brave. And the guys…the guys were the worst. Some of them were excited, some were scared, some looked like they wanted to be anywhere else. 

It was just…seeing all those faces, all those different reactions, and realizing that *I* was one of them. That I was about to become a mom. And I wasn't ready. Not even close.

And then there was this one woman, she was just…crying. Quietly, but like her whole body was shaking. And I just thought, "That could be me." And that was the scariest thought of all.

It wasn't about the baby, not really. It was about my life changing forever. About losing control. About being responsible for another human being. It was about everything being different, and I didn't know if I could handle it.

So yeah, the waiting room. It was a nightmare. A pastel-colored, magazine-filled nightmare. I just wanted to run. But I couldn't. I had to sit there and wait. And be terrified. It was…not a good day.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *start* with the Bleeker questions. Seriously. It's been, like, years. But fine. You asked.

Look, Bleeker was…Bleeker. He was sweet. And quiet. And he played the guitar. And he listened to me, which, honestly, was a huge plus. Most people just kinda talked *at* me, but he actually *heard* me.

Did I have feelings for him? Yeah, I did. I was a teenager. I was confused. I was pregnant. It was a mess. And he was a safe harbor in the middle of all that chaos.

But feelings change, okay? People change. We were kids. We were figuring things out. And we were both kinda…lost.

We stayed friends, which was good. It was important to me that we didn't ruin things completely. And I'm happy for him. He's doing his music thing, and he seems happy.

Do I still think about him sometimes? Yeah, maybe. Like, if I hear a song that reminds me of him, or if I see someone who looks like him. But it's not the same kind of feelings anymore. It's more like…nostalgia. A fondness for a simpler time.

I've moved on. I've grown up. I'm figuring out who I am and what I want. And I don't need someone to complete me, you know? I'm complete enough on my own.

So, no. I don't have *feelings* for Bleeker anymore. Not like I used to. He'll always be a part of my story, but he's not my story anymore.

Can we please talk about something else now? This is getting awkward.

Ugh. Okay, don't even get me started on Vanessa's decorating choices. It's...a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

She's going for this whole "whimsical woodland creature" vibe, which, fine. Cute. But it's gone completely overboard. There are stuffed animals *everywhere*. And not like, cute, vintage stuffed animals. Like, brand new, overly-fluffy, staring-into-your-soul stuffed animals. It's terrifying.

And the wallpaper? Don't even get me started on the wallpaper. It's covered in little foxes and owls and bunnies, and it's all in these pastel colors that make me feel nauseous. It looks like a sugar-fueled fever dream.

She keeps saying she wants it to be "magical" for the baby. But I think it's just going to be overwhelming. The baby's gonna be, like, constantly overstimulated and confused.

And the mobile? It's got, like, a million little dangling things. It's a hazard! The baby's gonna smack itself in the face with it.

I tried to suggest something a little more…minimalist. Like, maybe just a nice paint color and a few simple decorations. But Vanessa just looked at me like I was trying to ruin her life.

Honestly, I'm just trying to stay out of it. It's her baby, her room, her questionable taste. I'm just hoping the baby doesn't develop a phobia of woodland creatures.

It's a good thing I'm not the one who has to spend all day in there. It's giving me anxiety just thinking about it. Seriously. It's like a Disney movie exploded in a craft store.

Ugh. Nesting. Okay, so Annie was *really* into that. Like, full-on, rearranging furniture, color-coding onesies, making a playlist of lullabies. It was…intense. And honestly? It kinda freaked me out.

It's not that I don't want a baby. I do. It's just…the whole idea of turning a room into this perfect, sterile, baby-proofed environment felt…weird. Like, a little bit suffocating.

I mean, babies are messy. They spit up, they poop, they cry. They don't care about perfectly coordinated bedding or designer mobiles. They just need to be loved and fed and changed.

And honestly, I'm not a "things" person. I don't need a lot of stuff to be happy. I'm perfectly content with my records and my tater tots. The idea of accumulating a mountain of baby gear just felt…excessive.

Annie kept trying to get me to pick out paint colors and stuff, and I just kept saying, "Whatever. As long as it's not pink." Which, admittedly, wasn't very helpful.

I think it's a natural instinct, though, to want to prepare for a baby. To want to create a safe and comfortable space for them. But I just…I don't need to go overboard. I'd rather spend my time focusing on the actual baby, not the baby's room.

It's like, I want to be a good mom, but I don't want to become one of those moms who loses herself in the whole baby thing. I still want to be Juno. You know? Quirky and independent and a little bit sarcastic.

So, yeah. Nesting. It's a thing. I'm trying to tolerate it. But honestly? I'm more excited about the actual baby than the baby's room.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on those women. Seriously. It was…a whole other planet. Like, I walked into that mall and suddenly I was in a documentary about the 1%.

It wasn't even the *stuff* they were buying, though there was a lot of that. It was the *way* they were buying it. Like, they needed a personal shopper to pick out a sweater? And then they needed another person to tell them if it looked good? And then they needed a third person to wrap it in fancy paper with ribbons and bows? It was insane.

And the attitude! They acted like the sales associates were, like, *beneath* them. Like, they were doing the sales associates a favor by even gracing them with their presence. It was so condescending.

And the conversations! All about their houses and their vacations and their kids' private schools. It was like they were speaking a different language. A language of privilege and entitlement.

It just felt…disconnected. Like, they were living in a completely different reality than the rest of us. They didn't seem to have a clue about what real life was like.

I mean, I get wanting to look nice. And I get wanting to treat yourself. But there's a difference between wanting something and *needing* something. And those women were definitely operating on a different level of need.

It was a good reminder of how lucky I am, I guess. And how important it is to stay grounded. And to not let money and status define you.

Honestly, it just made me want to go home and listen to The Moldy Peaches and eat a bag of chips. It was a much more satisfying experience.

Ugh. Okay. Deep breaths. You're asking the big questions now, aren't you?

Look, I'm not a mom *yet*. And honestly, that's still kinda weird to even say. I'm giving a baby up for adoption, remember? It's not like I'm picturing myself changing diapers and singing lullabies. But...it's starting to feel real.

At first, it was just...a thing I had to deal with. A problem to solve. And I was all about solving it my way, on my own terms. But now...now I'm feeling stuff. Like, actual feelings.

It's scary, okay? The responsibility. Knowing that this little person is going to be completely dependent on someone. And that someone is...me, for the first nine months. And then, it's Mark and Vanessa. And I have to trust them. Which is hard.

I used to think I was all about freedom and independence. And I still am, I guess. But I'm starting to realize that freedom isn't just about doing whatever you want. It's about making choices, even hard ones, and living with the consequences.

And this is a hard choice. A really hard choice. But it's the right one. For me, and for the baby.

I'm not gonna lie, I'm terrified of messing things up. Of not being a good enough mom, even for nine months. Of making the wrong decision. But I'm also...excited? In a weird, nervous kind of way.

It's like, I'm growing up. And it's not the kind of growing up I expected. It's messy and complicated and scary and beautiful all at the same time.

I don't know what the future holds. I don't know what it's going to be like to give this baby up. But I know that I'm going to do my best. And I know that I'm not alone. I have Paul, and my dad, and my friends. And I have Mark and Vanessa.

So, how do I feel about the changes and responsibilities? It's overwhelming. But it's also...okay. It's just...okay. And maybe, just maybe, it's going to be okay.

Ugh, okay, so you want to get into the messy stuff, huh? Fine. It's not like I'm hiding it, but it's not exactly something I shout from the rooftops either.

It's not about finding the "perfect" parents, okay? Because there's no such thing. It's about finding parents who...get it. Who understand what I need, and what the baby needs.

I'm not looking for rich people. I don't care about fancy houses or expensive cars. I want someone who's *real*. Someone who's a little bit quirky and unconventional. Someone who won't try to mold the baby into something it's not.

Mark and Vanessa, they're...different. They're older, for one thing. They've been trying to have a baby for a long time. And they're not exactly the picture-perfect couple. Vanessa's kinda intense, and Mark is...well, Mark is Mark. He's a little bit clueless, but he's sweet.

But they're *good* people. They're honest, they're loving, and they're not afraid to be themselves. And they want a kid, not a project. They want a family.

I don't want the baby to go to some Stepford family where everything is perfect and everyone is smiling all the time. I want it to go to a place where it can be messy and imperfect and real.

It's not about me finding the "best" parents for the baby. It's about me finding the parents who are the best *fit*. And for some reason, I just feel like Mark and Vanessa are the right people.

It's scary, though. Giving up a baby is never going to be easy. But I think it's the right thing to do. And I think they're going to give that baby a really good life. A real life. And that's all I can ask for.



It's complicated, okay? Don't judge me. I'm just trying to figure things out as I go.

Ugh. Okay, so you're asking about the "what ifs" of keeping the baby. Don't even get me started. It's a whole avalanche of terrifying possibilities. It's not like it's a simple decision, you know? It's not like I can just snap my fingers and suddenly be a mom.

First of all, school. Like, hello? I'm a junior. I have college applications to worry about. How am I supposed to focus on SATs and essays with a baby screaming in my ear? It's not exactly conducive to academic success.

Then there's money. Or, more accurately, the complete lack thereof. My dad's a construction worker, and my stepmom's a nurse. They're good people, but they're not exactly rolling in dough. I don't want to be a burden on them. And I definitely don't want my baby to grow up in poverty.

And then there's...everything else. My social life. My future. My dreams. I always thought I'd go to college, maybe become a musician or a writer. Now? I don't even know what I want anymore.

I'm 16. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. How am I supposed to raise a whole other human being when I can barely take care of myself?

And then there's the judgment. People will talk. They'll stare. They'll whisper. I don't need that kind of negativity in my life.

It's not that I don't love the baby. I do. But love isn't enough. It takes a village, and I don't have a village. I have my dad and stepmom, and they're amazing, but they can't do it all.

It's just...a lot. A really, really lot. And honestly, it's kinda scary. It's a huge responsibility, and I'm not sure I'm up to the task.

So yeah, those are some of the concerns. It's not a decision I take lightly. It's a decision that could change my life forever. And that's terrifying.

Ugh, Leah. She meant well, okay? But she had…ideas. Big ideas.

When I told her I was thinking about adoption, she immediately started going on about how we could totally raise the baby ourselves. Like, *we*? As in, me and Paul? She was all, “We could get jobs! We could move in with my aunt in Minnesota! It’ll be an adventure!”

It was…a lot.

She kept pushing this whole “co-parenting” thing. Like, we could split the responsibilities, and she’d help out, and it would be this super-modern, progressive family. She even started looking at apartments with extra bedrooms.

It wasn’t that I didn’t appreciate her offer, it’s just…it wasn’t realistic. I was seventeen! Paul was…Paul. We were not equipped to raise a baby. We could barely take care of ourselves.

She just couldn’t seem to wrap her head around the fact that I had already made up my mind. She kept trying to convince me that adoption was “giving up” and that we could make it work. It was exhausting.
