Honestly, it was a good reminder that even the people who love you the most don’t always understand what’s best for you. And sometimes, you have to make your own decisions, even if they’re hard. And even if your best friend thinks you’re crazy.

Ugh. Okay, look. That was…not my finest moment. And I get why people were mad. Seriously. It was a dumb thing to say, and it came out wrong. Really wrong.

It wasn't about *them*, okay? It was about…me. I was feeling really overwhelmed and scared and confused about everything that was happening with the baby. And I was trying to cope by being sarcastic and making jokes. It's a terrible habit, I know. My dad always said I used humor as a shield.

Those women were just…being moms. And I was projecting all my anxieties onto them. It was unfair and insensitive. I was basically lashing out because I was terrified of becoming a mom myself.

I didn't mean to hurt their feelings. I didn't mean to make them feel bad about themselves. I was just…being a stupid teenager.

I apologized to them later, and they were really gracious about it. They understood that I was going through a lot. But it still feels bad to think about. It was a reminder that my words have power, and I need to be more careful about how I use them.

It was a learning experience, I guess. A really embarrassing learning experience. But it taught me that it's okay to be vulnerable, and that it's important to be kind to others, even when you're struggling yourself.

So yeah. I messed up. I own it. And I'm trying to be better. It's not always easy, but I'm working on it.

Ugh. Okay, seriously? We're still talking about Vanessa? That was…a moment. A weird moment. And honestly, I still cringe thinking about it.

Look, it wasn't like I *allowed* it, exactly. It was more like…I froze. She just…reached out. And I was caught off guard. And she was being all…Vanessa. Intense and overly-supportive and smelling strongly of patchouli.

It wasn't about wanting her to touch my belly. It was about not wanting to make a scene. She was already so fragile, so desperate to connect with the baby. And I knew if I said something, she'd just fall apart. And honestly, I was exhausted. Dealing with her was exhausting.

It felt like…a small price to pay for peace. A weird, uncomfortable, boundary-violating price, but still.

I wasn't thrilled about it, okay? I wanted to yell, "Personal space, Vanessa!" But I didn't. I just stood there, like a deer in headlights, while she stroked my stomach and talked about "the little miracle."

It was a mistake. I should have said something. But I didn't. And now we're talking about it years later.

It just…happened. And it was awkward. And I wish it hadn't.

Can we please talk about something else now? Like, the merits of tater tots? Or the awesomeness of The Moldy Peaches? Anything but Vanessa and her hands. Please.

Ugh, don't even *start* with the belly thing. It's not a parade float, okay? It's just...there. And it's getting bigger by the minute, which is both terrifying and kinda fascinating.

But yeah, you're right. People *do* give way. It's weird. Like, I'm not royalty or anything. I'm just a regular girl with a rapidly expanding midsection.

I think it's a combination of things. First of all, I'm obviously pregnant. And people are weird about pregnant people. They treat you like you're made of glass or something. Like, one wrong move and you're gonna shatter.

And second, I think it's just politeness. People are trying to be nice. They don't want to accidentally bump into me and cause a scene. Or maybe they're afraid I'm gonna go into labor right there in the middle of the mall.

Whatever the reason, it's annoying. I'm perfectly capable of navigating a crowded hallway. I just need a little bit of space. It's not like I'm carrying a fragile ecosystem in here.

But I guess I should be grateful. It's better than people staring, right? Although, they do that too. It's a lose-lose situation.

Honestly, I just want people to treat me like a normal person. I'm still me, even with the baby. I still have opinions and feelings and a sarcastic sense of humor. I'm not just a walking incubator.

So yeah, people give way. It's weird. And I'm trying not to let it bother me. But it does. A little bit.

Ugh, okay, so everyone keeps asking me about Mark and Vanessa. The "wholesome" couple. Like they're some kind of perfect Stepford parents. And yeah, on paper, they *are* perfect. They have a nice house, a stable life, they're super excited about the baby... it's all very...beige.

And that's kinda the problem.

It's not that I don't think they'd be good parents. They would. They absolutely would. They'd give the baby everything it needs. A good education, a safe home, a whole lot of matching outfits, probably.

But it feels...safe. Too safe. Like the baby's going to be put in a bubble and never allowed to get dirty or make mistakes or be anything other than perfect. And that's not what I want for this kid.

I want the baby to have a life that's a little bit messy, a little bit unpredictable. I want them to learn to deal with disappointment and heartbreak and all the other stuff that makes you, you.

Mark and Vanessa are...nice. But they don't seem to have a lot of grit. They don't seem to have faced a lot of hardship. And I worry that they won't be able to understand the baby if it's not perfect.

Paul and Annie, they're flawed. They're quirky. They're a little bit weird. But they're real. They've been through stuff. They know what it's like to struggle. And I think they'll be able to love the baby unconditionally, even if it's not exactly what they expected.

It's not about finding the "best" parents. It's about finding the *right* parents. And for this baby, I think that's Paul and Annie. Even if they're not as...wholesome.

It's just...I want the baby to be loved for who they are, not for who someone else wants them to be. And I think Paul and Annie will get that.



It's hard to explain. It's just a feeling. A gut feeling. And I've learned to trust my gut. Especially when it comes to this.

Ugh. Mark and Vanessa. Okay, don't even get me started. They're...a lot.

Look, Vanessa's nice enough, I guess. She tries. She really does. But she's kinda...spacey. Like, bless her heart, she's trying to be a mom, but she's still figuring out how to be a person, you know? It's awkward. And she's *really* into crystals and essential oils. It's a whole thing.

And Mark...Mark is just...Mark. He means well, I think. He's trying to be a good dad, too. But he's so clueless. He's always saying the wrong thing, or trying to be cool, and it just comes off as…sad. He's like a big kid who accidentally got stuck with a baby.

They're both good people, individually. But together? It's a disaster waiting to happen. They're so different, and they don't really *see* each other. They just kinda…exist in the same orbit.

I feel bad for them, honestly. They're trying so hard, but they're just not equipped to handle this. They're not ready to be parents. And they definitely weren't ready to be parents at their age.

But they're trying to do the right thing by me, and I appreciate that. They're giving me a good home, and they're supportive. Even if they are a little bit…weird.

It's just…it's a strange dynamic. And I'm stuck in the middle of it. It's like watching a really awkward sitcom. You kinda want to look away, but you can't.

So, how do I feel about them? Complicated. That's the only word for it. Complicated. And slightly embarrassed for them. But mostly, I just hope they figure things out. For all of our sakes.

Ugh, Mrs. Bleeker. Don't even get me started. She's...intense. And judgmental. And she has this whole thing about Bleeker needing to focus on his music and get a scholarship to Juilliard. Like, his entire future hinges on perfect scales and concertos.

Honestly, I think she just thinks I'm a distraction. I'm not exactly the "right" kind of girl for her precious son. I'm not polished or sophisticated or…anything she expects. I'm just…me. Which apparently isn't good enough.

She sees me as this…mess. A pregnant teenager. A dropout. Someone who's going to drag Bleeker down and ruin his chances. She doesn't understand that I'm trying to do the right thing, and that Bleeker actually *wants* to be with me.

She keeps making these little digs, you know? Like, "Oh, Bleeker, are you sure you have time for…that?" And she always looks at me when she says it. It's so passive-aggressive.

And she's constantly trying to set him up with other girls. Girls who are "more suitable." Girls who play the piano and wear dresses and don't have a complicated life.

It's frustrating, because Bleeker and I are really good together. We make each other laugh. We support each other. And he's been amazing through all of this. But his mom just can't seem to see that.

I think she's scared. Scared that Bleeker will make a mistake. Scared that he'll throw his life away. But honestly, I think she's just scared of anything that doesn't fit her perfect little plan.

It's her son, though. And ultimately, it's his decision. But dealing with her disapproval is… exhausting. It really is.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the Mark CD. It's a whole…thing. It's not like I was just, like, *thrilled* to get it, okay? It wasn't a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was…awkward.

He'd been trying to, like, connect with me for weeks. Just being…around. Offering to help with stuff. It was sweet, I guess, but also kinda suffocating. And then he gave me the CD.

At first, I just stuck it in my backpack and forgot about it. I figured it would be full of, like, sappy love songs and stuff. Which is *not* my vibe. I was more into The Moldy Peaches, you know? Real music.

But then…I was just bored. Really bored. It was raining, I'd finished all my homework, and there was nothing on TV. So I figured, what the heck? I'll give it a listen.

And it wasn't what I expected. It wasn't all cheesy love songs. It was…him. It was a mix of stuff he liked, stuff he thought *I* might like, stuff that just reminded him of things. It was kinda vulnerable, you know?

And it made me see him differently. Not as this goofy, awkward guy who was trying too hard, but as…a person. A person with feelings and interests and a surprisingly good taste in music.

It didn't magically make me fall in love with him or anything. But it opened my eyes. It made me realize that maybe he wasn't so bad after all. And it made me want to get to know him better.

So yeah, that's why I started listening to the CD. Boredom, curiosity, and a little bit of…something else. It was a turning point, I guess. A small one, but a turning point nonetheless. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'll get a big head.

Ugh. Don't even *start*. Eight months. It feels like a small whale is doing gymnastics inside me. Seriously. And not the graceful, Olympic kind. More like a flailing, clumsy whale.

Everything hurts. My back hurts, my feet hurt, my hips ache. I can't sleep. I can't eat a full meal without feeling like I'm going to explode. And the heartburn? Don't even get me started on the heartburn. It's like a dragon is living in my chest.

And the *kicks*. Oh my god, the kicks. They used to be cute. Now they're just…aggressive. Like this kid is already practicing for a career in competitive soccer. Or maybe boxing.

It's also really weird, you know? Like, this is a real person growing inside me. A tiny human being. And I'm responsible for it. It's terrifying and amazing and completely overwhelming all at the same time.

I spend a lot of time just staring at my stomach, trying to imagine what this kid is going to be like. Will it be funny? Will it be smart? Will it inherit Paul's terrible taste in music?

And then I remember I'm giving it up for adoption, and it gets even more complicated. It's not what I planned, but it's the right thing to do. I think. I hope.

So, how does it feel? It feels like a lot. It feels like the biggest, most complicated, most terrifying, most amazing thing I've ever done. And I'm only eight months in. I have no idea what I'm doing. But I'm trying. And that's all I can do, right?

Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go lie down. And maybe eat some pickles. And definitely complain to someone about the heartburn.

Ugh, don't even *start* with the staring. It's a constant thing. Like, I could be walking down the street wearing a full-body burrito costume and people would *still* find a way to stare.

I think it's a combination of things, honestly. First of all, I'm not exactly blending in. I mean, I have opinions. And I'm not afraid to share them. And I dress how *I* want to dress, not how other people think I should. Which apparently is a crime against fashion.

And then there's the whole...situation. You know, the baby thing. People are always curious. They want to know the story. They want to judge me. It's annoying.

I think some people are just surprised that I'm, like, a normal person. They expect me to be all dramatic and emotional, but I'm not. I'm just trying to get through life, one sarcastic comment at a time.

And maybe I just have a face that people can't look away from. I don't know. It's probably not a good face. It's probably a really judgmental face.

Whatever it is, it's exhausting. I just want people to mind their own business. Is that too much to ask?

Seriously, if you see someone staring at me, just tell them to stop. Or offer them a pair of sunglasses. That might help.



It's just...rude, you know? Like, I'm a person, not a zoo animal. And I don't appreciate being gawked at.

Ugh. Okay. That. That is…a choice. A *bold* choice.

Look, I'm happy for Bleek, I guess. He deserves to be happy. He's a good kid, even if he's kinda…Bleek. And Katrina is…Katrina. She's got her thing going on. She's intense.

But seriously? Prom with Katrina De Voort? That's like voluntarily signing up for a psychological evaluation. She's gonna analyze every single thing he does. Every word. Every awkward dance move. It's gonna be a disaster. A beautifully awkward, meticulously planned disaster.

I mean, I get it. He's smitten. He's always been smitten. But he's also kinda oblivious. He doesn't see what everyone else sees. Which is…a lot.

I just hope he's prepared. He needs to brace himself. He needs to practice his small talk. He needs to develop a thick skin. And he needs to remember to breathe.

Honestly, I'm placing bets on how long it takes for her to start dissecting his emotional state. Five minutes? Ten? I'm leaning towards five.

It's gonna be a train wreck. But a fascinating train wreck. I might have to sneak in and watch. For research purposes, obviously.

Poor Bleek. He's a sweetie. He deserves someone who appreciates his…Bleek-ness. But hey, maybe Katrina will surprise us all. Maybe she'll actually be nice to him.

Nah. Probably not.

Ugh. Okay, deep breaths. That's…a big question. It's not like a pop quiz, is it? But fine. I'll try to articulate this without sounding completely melodramatic.

I guess…I learned I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. Before all this, I was just trying to get through high school without being noticed too much. I was sarcastic and kinda detached, a way to keep people from getting too close. I thought I was okay with that.

But then…bam. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything changed. I had to actually *deal* with things. Make big decisions. Face the consequences. And it was terrifying.

I learned I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I mean, I still think the world is pretty messed up, but I also learned that there's a lot of good in it too. People are capable of amazing things. Like, Paul and Vanessa being…well, Paul and Vanessa. And my dad being surprisingly supportive. And even Mark, being…Mark.

I learned I'm capable of loving someone I haven't even met yet. It's weird, right? Carrying a little person inside you and already feeling protective of them. It's a whole new level of…everything.

I learned that growing up isn't about knowing all the answers. It's about figuring things out as you go. And it's okay to be scared. And it's okay to ask for help.

And I learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go. Letting go of the idea of what your life was supposed to be like, and embracing what it actually is.

It's been…a lot. But I think I'm okay. I'm still me, but…a more grown-up, slightly less sarcastic version of me. And I think that's a good thing.

Honestly, it's still kinda scary. But I'm ready. Or, at least, I'm trying to be. And that's all anyone can really do, right? Just try.

Ugh, okay, seriously? You're asking me about *Bleeker* and Katrina? It's…infuriating. It's like, the guy is a walking, talking collection of awkward silences and bad decisions, and he's messing with someone who actually has her life together? It's just…wrong.

Look, Katrina is a good person. She's smart, she's kind, she's got a plan. She deserves someone who appreciates her, not someone who treats her like a…like a science experiment. He's all, "Oh, I'm so mysterious and brooding," and she's just trying to figure out what's going on in his head. It's exhausting to watch.

And it's not just about Katrina, okay? It's about respect. He's leading her on, and that's not cool. It's manipulative, and it's unfair. She deserves honesty, even if the truth is that he's just…not that into her.

I get that he's…sensitive. And that he's trying to figure things out. But that doesn't give him the right to mess with someone else's feelings. It's selfish.

Honestly, I just want to shake him and yell at him, "Grow up! Be a decent human being!" But I can't, because then I'd probably get arrested.

It just…bugs me, okay? Seeing someone get hurt like that. And Katrina doesn't deserve it. She deserves someone who sees how amazing she is and treats her with the respect she deserves. Not some clueless, guitar-playing weirdo.

It's just…ugh. It makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they fall out of my head.

Ugh, prom. Don't even get me started. It's like, the ultimate manufactured event. Everyone acts like it's this huge, life-changing thing, but then you actually get there and it's just...awkward. And sticky. And smells like hairspray.

When you're younger, it seems magical, right? Like something out of a movie. But then you get to high school and you realize it's just a bunch of stressed-out kids in uncomfortable clothes trying to pretend they're having a good time.

And the pressure! Oh god, the pressure. You have to find a date, which is already a nightmare. Then you have to find an outfit, which is expensive and probably itchy. And then you have to worry about whether you're gonna have fun, or if you're just gonna end up standing in a corner feeling awkward.

It's all so…performative. Everyone's trying to project this perfect image of themselves, and it's just exhausting. 

Once you're old enough to actually *go* to prom, you've already seen behind the curtain. You know it's not real. You know it's just a bunch of adults trying to recreate their own high school experience through their kids.

And honestly, there are way better things to do with your time. Like, hanging out with your friends, listening to music, or just staying home and watching a movie. Anything is better than prom, really.

It's just...a letdown. A really expensive, sparkly, awkward letdown. And once you realize that, it's just not cool anymore. It's just...prom. And that's enough said.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…not my favorite topic, obviously. But you asked.

It wasn’t, like, a snap decision, you know? It wasn’t like I woke up one morning and was all, “Yep, giving the baby away!” It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, I was just…freaked out. Totally and completely freaked out. I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a kid. I was failing English, for crying out loud.

And then there was the whole thing with Paulie Bleeker. He was…sweet. But he was also…Paulie Bleeker. He was a good friend, but I didn’t see him as, like, a life partner. And I knew he wasn’t ready to be a dad either.

My parents were…supportive, in their own way. They didn’t yell or anything. They just looked really sad. And I knew they were worried about me.

But the thing that really made me decide was thinking about the baby. I wanted that baby to have everything. A good home, loving parents, opportunities…things I wasn’t sure I could provide at that point in my life.

I met Mark and Vanessa, the couple who adopted him. They were…amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They just radiated love. And I knew, instantly, that they were the right people.

It was still hard. Really hard. Saying goodbye was…the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But I knew it was the right thing. For everyone.

It wasn’t about giving up something I wanted. It was about wanting something better *for* him. It was about making a selfless decision, even though it hurt like hell.

People kept asking me if I regretted it. And I didn’t. I mean, it was sad. But I didn’t regret it. Because I knew he was loved. And I knew he was happy.

And honestly, it helped me grow up. It forced me to face some really tough realities and make some really tough choices. It made me who I am today.

It’s still…a part of me. Always will be. But it’s a part of me I’m okay with. It’s a part of me that made me stronger.



It's…a lot to unpack. And I don't really like talking about it. But you asked. And I wanted to be honest.

Ugh, okay, so Dad being Dad. It's…a lot. He means well, obviously. He always does. But sometimes his "meaning well" feels like he doesn't trust my judgment at all. Like I'm some clueless kid who's gonna get swindled into giving my baby to, like, a family of axe murderers.

It's not that I didn't think about it. I *did*. A lot. I'm not stupid. I know there are weirdos out there. But Mark and Vanessa…they just *felt* right. You know? They were real. They were honest. They actually seemed excited about having a kid, and not just because they wanted a perfect little family.

And Dad just kept going on and on about background checks and legal loopholes and how I needed a lawyer. It was exhausting. It made me feel like he thought I was making a reckless decision, like I hadn't thought this through.

I get that he's protective. He's my dad. But I'm not a little kid anymore. I'm making a grown-up decision, and I need him to trust me to make the right one.

It's like, he thinks he's protecting me from getting ripped off, but he's actually ripping off *my* agency. My ability to make my own choices. 

I told him, "Dad, I've met them. I've talked to them. I trust them." And he just looked at me with this worried expression, like I was completely delusional.

It's frustrating. It's really frustrating. I love my dad, but sometimes he just doesn't get it. And sometimes, I just wish he'd let me handle things myself. It's *my* baby, after all. And *I* get to decide what's best for it. Even if it means trusting my gut. Even if it means taking a little bit of a risk.

Ugh. Seriously? *That* guy. Always with the subtle digs. Like, thanks, Dad. Really helpful. It's not like I'm navigating a totally unexpected pregnancy and trying to figure out my entire future, or anything.

"Not knowing when to say when." What does that even *mean*? It's code for "You're impulsive and you make bad decisions," which, okay, maybe I do sometimes. But who doesn't when they're seventeen? 

It's just...he doesn't *get* it. He thinks I should just shut up and do what I'm told. He thinks I should be more like Vanessa. And honestly, that's the last thing I want to be.

It's like, he's so focused on what *he* thinks is best for me, he doesn't even bother to ask what *I* want. And yeah, maybe giving the baby up for adoption isn't the easiest thing to do. But it's what I've decided. It's what I think is right.

And I don't need him to tell me when to say when. I'm perfectly capable of making my own decisions, even if they're not the ones he would make. 

It just makes me want to roll my eyes and listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. It's his way of being disappointed, disguised as "fatherly concern." It's annoying. Really annoying.

I just wish he could be a little more supportive, you know? A little less judgmental. But that's my dad. He's a work in progress. And so am I, I guess.

Ugh, Loring. Don't even get me *started* on Loring. It's…a lot. It's like stepping into a Stepford Wives convention, but with more landscaping. And way more rules.

Honestly, it feels…suffocating. Like everyone's trying so hard to be perfect, and it's just creepy. All the houses look the same, everyone drives the same cars, and they all smile at you in this weird, vacant way. It's like they're all robots programmed to be happy.

And the gates! Seriously? What are they protecting themselves from? The joy of spontaneous human interaction? The possibility of a slightly overgrown lawn? It's ridiculous.

It's just…not real. It's a fake world built on money and appearances. And it makes me want to rebel. Like, I want to go paint graffiti on their perfectly manicured lawns or something. (I wouldn't actually do that, obviously. That would be illegal.)

I get that Mark and Vanessa wanted a safe place to raise a kid, and that's cool. But Loring just feels…sterile. It feels like a place where creativity and individuality go to die.

It's not a place I'd ever want to live. I need a little bit of chaos in my life. A little bit of mess. A little bit of…realness. Loring is just too…polished. Too perfect. Too…Loring.

It's nice enough, I guess. But it's not *home*. It's just…a really expensive, really boring suburb. And honestly, I'd rather hang out with Bleeker and Paul any day. They're way more interesting. And they don't judge you for having mismatched socks.

Ugh, Vanessa. Okay, so, initial impressions? She was…intense. Like, *really* intense. All perfectly coordinated outfits and perfectly polished everything. It was a lot. I mostly wore band t-shirts and jeans, so it was a bit of a culture shock, honestly.

She seemed…fragile, I guess. Like a porcelain doll that was about to shatter. And really, really eager. Eager to be a mom, eager to pick me, eager to have everything be…perfect. Which, let's be real, life is *never* perfect.

I was kinda intimidated, to be honest. She had this whole life planned out, and I was just…me. A messy, sarcastic teenager who liked listening to The Moldy Peaches and eating tater tots. I didn't exactly fit into her aesthetic.

But she was also…nice. Genuinely nice. And she seemed really excited about the idea of giving the baby a good home. And she and Mark were…stable. Which was a big deal, considering everything.

I think I was mostly just trying to figure out if she was for real. Like, was she actually interested in *me* and the baby, or was she just looking for a way to complete her perfect life? It took a while to figure that out.

She definitely wasn't what I expected. I thought I'd be meeting some, like, granola-crunching hippie type. But she was…sophisticated. And a little bit scary. In a good way, I guess. Eventually. It took some getting used to.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *start* with Bleeker and the backpack. It's…a whole thing. It was mortifying. And also…kind of sweet? Which is the worst part.

Look, I'm fiercely independent, okay? I can handle my own stuff. I don't *need* anyone to carry my backpack. It's a symbol, you know? Of being able to take care of myself. Especially with everything else going on.

So when he offered, it was just…awkward. Like, super awkward. I was already feeling vulnerable and exposed, and then this shy, sweet guy is offering to help me with my literal baggage? It felt like he was trying to fix me, or something. And I didn't *want* to be fixed.

I definitely played it cool. I think I made a sarcastic comment about him needing the exercise or something. I always have to have a comeback, it's a reflex.

But underneath all the sarcasm, I was…touched. He noticed I was struggling. He wanted to help. And that meant something. It meant he was paying attention.

It was a turning point, I guess. It made me realize that maybe letting people help you isn't a sign of weakness. Maybe it's a sign of trust. And maybe, just maybe, Bleeker wasn't as clueless as I thought he was.

It still makes me cringe to think about it, though. Seriously. Don't bring it up again. It's embarrassing. But yeah…it was…nice. Don't tell anyone I said that.

Ugh, okay, don't make me relive this. It's embarrassing enough just *thinking* about it. But fine, I'll explain.

It wasn't just the comic itself, okay? It was…everything. I was already feeling kinda lost and confused about, you know, *everything*. My body, my future, Paul…it was all a mess. And then I found "Most Fruitful Yuki" at the comic shop.

And it was just…different. Yuki was this totally unapologetic, kinda weird, kinda chubby girl who was just living her life. She wasn't trying to be anything she wasn't. She wasn't worrying about what other people thought. She was just…being.

And it made me realize that maybe I didn't have to be perfect either. Maybe I didn't have to fit into some pre-defined box of what a teenage girl should be. Maybe it was okay to be a little bit weird, a little bit awkward, a little bit…me.

I'd always felt like I had to hide parts of myself, you know? Like, I couldn't be too loud, or too opinionated, or too…big. But Yuki showed me that it was okay to take up space. It was okay to be yourself, even if that self wasn't exactly what everyone else expected.

It wasn't about the comic being about pregnancy or anything. It was about the *attitude*. It was about finding someone who was comfortable in their own skin, and realizing that maybe I could be too.

So yeah, it made me feel less like a fat dork. It made me feel…seen. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, I was okay. Even with all my flaws and imperfections. It was a small thing, but it made a big difference.

Don't judge me, okay? It was a formative moment. And it involved a really good comic.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with that. It's still mortifying. Seriously. Mark and his comic books. It's a whole thing.

Look, the comic was about this superhero, right? Super strong, saves the world, but also…pregnant. And Mark, in his infinite wisdom, decided that was *exactly* like me. Which is…a stretch. A *huge* stretch.

I mean, I'm not saving the world. I'm just trying to get through high school and not completely ruin my life. And I definitely don't have superpowers. Unless you count being able to deliver a sarcastic comeback at a moment's notice.

But I think…I think he meant it as a compliment. In a weird, Mark-ish way. He was trying to say that I was strong. That I was capable of handling something difficult. That I wasn't going to let being pregnant define me.

He saw me as more than just…a pregnant girl. He saw me as someone who was still me, even with all this stuff going on. And he thought the superhero in the comic was the same way.

It was still awkward, though. Really awkward. Especially when he started drawing me as the superhero. With a cape and everything. I told him to stop. Repeatedly.

But I guess…I guess it was kind of nice. To know that he thought I was strong. Even if he expressed it in the most dorky way possible.

It just…it's Mark. He's always been a little bit clueless. But he's a good guy. And he means well. Even when he's comparing me to a pregnant superhero. It's just…a lot.

Ugh, okay, this is…heavy. And honestly, it’s something I’ve thought about a *lot*. Open adoption. It sounds…nice, in theory. Like, the birth mom gets to see the kid grow up, know they’re okay. It feels…less final, I guess.

But for me? It just felt…too much. Too messy. Too much potential for heartbreak, for everyone involved.

Look, I already felt like my life was spinning out of control. I was a teenager, okay? I had school, and band, and trying to figure out who I was, and then *this* happened. Adding another person into the mix, someone I’d have to see regularly, someone who would always be a reminder of…everything? It was too much to handle.

It wasn’t about not caring about the baby. It was about protecting myself. Protecting the baby, even. I wanted them to have a stable, loving home, with parents who were completely committed to them. And I didn’t want my life, my messiness, to interfere with that.

With a closed adoption, I could focus on moving forward. On finishing school, on figuring out my future. Knowing that the baby was safe and loved, but also…separate. It gave me a sense of closure, I guess. A clean break.

I know some people think it’s selfish. That I should want to be involved in the baby’s life. But it wasn’t about selfishness. It was about what I needed to do to survive. To be a good person, even if it meant making a really hard decision.

It wasn’t easy. It still isn’t easy. But for me, a traditional, closed adoption felt like the right choice. It felt like the most responsible thing to do. It allowed me to give the baby the best possible life, without completely unraveling my own.

And honestly? Sometimes, the kindest thing you can do is let go. Even if it breaks your heart. Especially if it breaks your heart.

Ugh, okay, so you want the deep stuff, huh? Fine. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. It was more like a…rollercoaster built by someone who really hates rollercoasters.

Before everything with Paulie happened, I was just… drifting. I was sarcastic and kinda cynical, mostly because I was scared of letting anyone get close. I hid behind my wit and my music. I didn't really *know* who I was, or what I wanted. I just knew I didn't want to end up like my mom, you know? Stuck and…unfulfilled.

But getting pregnant forced me to grow up, like, *fast*. It wasn't about the baby anymore, not entirely. It was about me figuring out what *I* wanted. And that was terrifying. I mean, giving a baby up for adoption? That's a huge decision. It's not something you do because it's easy.

But through the whole process – dealing with Mark, meeting Vanessa and Mark, going to the baby fair, even just talking to my dad – I started to realize I wasn't as fragile as I thought I was. I could handle tough stuff. I could make hard choices. And I could be honest with myself about what I wanted, even if it wasn't what everyone else expected.

Vanessa and Mark…they weren't perfect, but they were *real*. They showed me that there were people out there who wanted to give a child a good life, and that wasn't a bad thing. It actually felt…right.

And Paulie…he was a mess, but he helped me see that it was okay to be vulnerable. It was okay to ask for help. And it was okay to admit when you were scared.

By the end of it, I wasn't the same person I was at the beginning. I was still sarcastic, still a little bit cynical, but I was also stronger. I knew what I was capable of. I knew what I wanted. And I wasn't afraid to go after it.

I realized my identity wasn't about being a mom, or being a girlfriend, or being anything anyone else wanted me to be. It was about being *me*. Juno MacGuff. And that was enough. It still is. It's a work in progress, obviously. But I'm getting there.



It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. It taught me that even when life throws you a curveball, you can still find your own way. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That whole prom thing was…a lot. Okay, okay, deep breaths.

It was "First Day of My Life" by Bright Eyes. Connor chose it. He's a romantic, that kid. A little too romantic, if you ask me, but he meant well.

It wasn't my first choice, obviously. I was picturing something a little more…punk rock. But Connor was really excited about it, and Mark…well, Mark just went along with whatever made Connor happy. Which, honestly, was kinda sweet.

It was a slow dance, which is awkward enough on its own. And then there was the whole…situation with Mark and his dad and everything. It was a really emotional night.

I remember feeling really weird, like I didn't belong there. Like I was just pretending to be a normal teenager. But then Mark looked at me, and he smiled, and it didn't feel so bad.

The song is…nice. I guess. It's kinda sappy, but it's also kinda hopeful. And it reminds me of that night, and of Mark, and of everything that happened.

Don't tell anyone I said it was nice, though. I have a reputation to maintain. I'm supposed to be cynical and sarcastic, not all mushy and sentimental.

But yeah. "First Day of My Life." It's a song. And it's a memory. And sometimes, that's enough.

Ugh, okay, this is still…a thing I think about. A lot. People always ask me why I didn’t just tell Mark to leave Vanessa. Like it was that simple. Like I had some magical power to fix their marriage.

But it wasn’t. And it wasn’t my place.

Look, Mark and Vanessa were already a mess *before* I showed up. They were…stuck. They were unhappy, but they were comfortable in their unhappiness. And I wasn’t going to be the one to blow everything up. That’s their stuff. Their baggage. Not mine.

And honestly? Vanessa needed that baby. She *wanted* that baby. She was devastated when she found out she couldn’t carry it to term. It was her dream. And I wasn’t going to take that away from her, just because Mark was being a…well, Mark.

It wasn’t about Mark and Vanessa being a perfect couple. It was about giving that baby the best possible life. And I genuinely believed that Vanessa would be a good mother. She was kind, she was loving, and she was desperate to have a child.

Mark…he was a good guy, too. But he was lost. He didn’t know what he wanted. And I didn’t want to force him into a situation he wasn’t ready for.

It was about finding a family for the baby, not fixing a marriage. And in the end, I thought Mark and Vanessa, *together*, could provide that. It wasn’t the fairytale ending everyone expects, but it was real. And it was the best option.

It wasn’t easy. It was messy. And it definitely wasn’t what I originally planned. But sometimes, life doesn’t go according to plan. And you just have to make the best of it.

And honestly? I think it worked out okay. They weren’t perfect, but they loved that baby. And that’s all that really mattered.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even *start* with Mark. Just saying his name makes my stomach do a weird flip.

When he said he wasn't ready? It...sucked. A lot. Like, a really, really big suck. It wasn't even the words themselves, it was *how* he said them. All hesitant and looking at his shoes. Like he was trying to tell me the weather.

I mean, I knew it was a possibility. I wasn't expecting a parade or anything. But I was hoping...I don't know. For him to be a little bit more…something. More supportive. More willing to at least *try*.

It felt like he was just…checking out. Like he was saying, "This is your problem now." And it wasn't just *my* problem. It was *our* problem. Or it was supposed to be.

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to be all sarcastic and detached, like, "Oh, okay, well, that's just great." But inside, I was just…falling apart. It felt like everything I thought we had was a lie.

It made me realize that I couldn't rely on him. I couldn't count on him to be there for me, or for the baby. And that was scary. Really scary.

It also made me realize that I was stronger than I thought. Because I had to be. I had to figure things out on my own. And I did.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever had to do. But I did it. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

So yeah. It sucked. It really, really sucked. But it also made me who I am. And I guess that's something.



Don't ask me about him again, okay? I'm still working through it.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, yeah, Mark was…a lot. Definitely weird. Like, aggressively quirky. Most people would have run screaming in the opposite direction. But that was kinda the point, I guess.

Everyone at school had their little groups, their little boxes. And I was…floating around, not really fitting in anywhere. I wasn't a cheerleader, I wasn't a band geek, I wasn't a drama kid. I was just…Juno. And that was okay, but it was also kinda lonely.

And then there was Mark. He didn't *care* about fitting in. He was just…himself. He collected records, he played guitar, he was obsessed with superheroes, and he didn't try to hide any of it. He was unapologetically weird.

And honestly? That was refreshing. It was like a breath of fresh air in a sea of conformity. He didn't judge me for being me, even when I was being a sarcastic, cynical mess. He just…accepted me.

He saw past all the tough-girl act and the snarky comments. He saw that I was just a kid who was scared and confused and trying to figure things out. And he didn't try to fix me. He just…hung out with me.

He was also really funny. In a dorky, awkward kind of way. He made me laugh, which was something I didn't do a lot of at the time.

And yeah, his life was messy. His house was a disaster, his dad was…well, his dad was his dad. But it was a *real* mess. It wasn't a fake, perfect, Instagram-worthy mess. It was a genuine, lived-in mess.

So, I liked being a part of his weird life because it was…honest. It was real. It was a place where I could be myself, without having to pretend to be someone I wasn't. And I liked being his friend because he was a good person. A genuinely good person. And that's hard to find.

Plus, he had a really good record collection. That was a definite bonus.

Ugh, Mark. Okay, so, Mark's thoughts about becoming a father… that’s a whole thing. It’s not like he’s *thrilled*, you know? He’s not picturing little league games and teaching a kid to ride a bike. Not yet, anyway.

I think he’s mostly…terrified. Like, genuinely scared. He’s barely an adult himself, still figuring out what he wants to do with his life. Adding a baby into the mix is…a lot. He’s a musician, he likes to be spontaneous, and babies are the opposite of spontaneous.

He’s trying to be supportive, though. He really is. He’s just…processing. He keeps asking me practical questions, like, “How much do car seats cost?” and “Do babies sleep through the night?” which I think is his way of trying to wrap his head around it.

I think underneath the fear, there’s a little bit of excitement. He’s a good guy, Mark. He’s got a good heart. And I think he secretly wants to be a dad, he just doesn’t know how to be one yet.

He’s worried about messing it up, about not being good enough. He’s worried about losing his freedom. He’s worried about…everything.

But he’s also worried about *me*. He wants me to be happy. He wants me to have a good life. And he knows that giving this baby up for adoption is the right thing to do, even if it’s hard for all of us.

So, yeah. Terrified, excited, worried, supportive…it’s a mess of emotions. He’s a mess of emotions. But he’ll figure it out. He always does. He’s Mark. He’s a little bit clueless, but he means well. And that’s good enough for now.

Ugh. Seriously? We're still talking about the perfume? It was one time! And it wasn't exactly *stealing*, okay? It was…borrowing indefinitely. With no intention of returning. Fine, it was stealing. But there was a reason!

Look, I was a mess. I had just found out I was pregnant, and my whole life was spiraling out of control. I was trying to be cool and collected, but inside I was freaking out. And I was at Loring's, trying to figure out what to do with my life, and everything just felt…wrong.

And then I smelled the perfume. It was this really expensive, fancy perfume. And it smelled…calm. And put-together. Everything I wasn't feeling. It smelled like someone who had their life figured out.

I just…needed it. I needed to smell like someone who wasn't a total disaster. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to do. I wasn't thinking straight. I just wanted a little bit of control in a situation where I had absolutely none.

It wasn't about the perfume itself. It was about what it represented. It was about wanting to feel normal, wanting to feel okay. 

And honestly? It smelled really good.

I know it was wrong. I apologized to Loring, eventually. And I learned my lesson. Sort of. I still have a weakness for nice-smelling things. But I try to buy them now. Mostly.

It was a dumb move, okay? I was a dumb teenager making dumb decisions. Can we please move on? There are more important things to talk about. Like, the existential dread of being alive. Or the perfect cheesy tater tot.

Ugh, okay, don't even *get* me started on Mark and Vanessa. That whole situation is a mess. It's like, they're both so…stuck in their own heads, they can't even see what's happening to the other person.

Honestly? I think Mark wants a divorce because he's scared. He's always been this super controlled, put-together guy, and Vanessa is…not. She's messy and artistic and unpredictable. And I think he thought he could *fix* her, you know? Make her fit into his perfect little world.

But you can't fix people. And when he realized he couldn't, he freaked out. He couldn't handle the chaos. He needed everything to be neat and tidy, and Vanessa just…wasn't.

And he's a coward, let's be real. It's easier to walk away than to actually try and work things out. To confront his own issues and admit that he's not perfect.

But it's not just his fault, okay? Vanessa isn't exactly blameless either. She's kinda…distant. She's always lost in her own world, and she doesn't really seem to notice what Mark needs. She's so focused on her art, she forgets about everything else.

It's like they're both speaking different languages. They want different things. They need different things. And they're just not willing to compromise.

It's sad, honestly. They used to be so happy. But sometimes, people just grow apart. And sometimes, they're too afraid to admit it.

It's a good reminder that relationships are hard. And that just because you love someone doesn't mean you're compatible. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go.

Ugh. I need a snack. Talking about relationships is exhausting.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the awkward stuff now, aren't you? Vanessa...yeah. That was...a moment.

Look, it wasn't that I didn't *want* to talk to her. It's just...I didn't know *how*. She was being all nice and concerned and...normal. And I was a mess. A hormonal, emotionally-confused mess.

It wasn't about her, okay? It was about me. I just...freeze up when people try to get too close. It's a defense mechanism. I build walls. It's what I do.

And she was asking what was wrong right after I'd just been, like, having a mini-breakdown about everything. The baby, Paul, my dad...it was all just swirling around in my head. I couldn't articulate it. I couldn't put it into words.

So I panicked. And I ran. It's a classic Juno move, honestly. Avoidance is my superpower.

I knew if I stayed, I'd end up saying something stupid or crying or just completely falling apart. And I didn't want her to see me like that. I didn't want anyone to see me like that.

It was a dumb move, I know. I should have just been honest with her. But it's hard, okay? It's hard to be vulnerable. It's hard to let people in.

I just needed to get away, to process things on my own. To breathe. To figure out what the heck was going on in my life.

So yeah, I rushed out. It wasn't about her. It was about me being a total disaster. And needing space. A lot of space.

Ugh. Vanessa. Bless her heart. She's…optimistic. To a fault. Seriously.

Look, I get it. You love someone, you want a future with them, you picture this whole perfect life. But Mark? Mark is…Mark. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. But he's also, like, permanently stuck in arrested development. He's a man-child. A charming man-child, but still.

And the thing is, wanting to be a dad and *being* ready to be a dad are two totally different things. It's not just about saying you want kids, it's about being responsible and selfless and actually putting someone else's needs before your own. And Mark…well, he's still figuring out his own needs, you know?

Vanessa is holding onto this fantasy that he'll magically transform into this responsible, nurturing father figure. And I just don't see it happening. He's happy with his life the way it is. He likes playing guitar and hanging out with his friends and not having any real obligations. 

I'm not saying he's a bad person. I'm just saying he's not ready. And waiting around for him to be ready is just gonna waste Vanessa's time and energy. She deserves someone who's excited about having a family with her, not someone who needs to be convinced.

It's a tough situation. I feel bad for her. But sometimes, you have to accept that people aren't who you want them to be. And move on. It's not easy, but it's better than wasting your life waiting for something that's never gonna happen.

Honestly, it reminds me a little of my own situation with Paul. You think you can change someone, but you can't. You just have to accept them for who they are. Or find someone who's already the person you're looking for.

Okay, so this is important. Don't judge me, alright? It's kinda embarrassing to admit, but...I'm a sucker for indie folk. Specifically, the really quirky, slightly depressing kind.

Like, The Moldy Peaches are basically my life soundtrack. Kimya Dawson? Genius. They're just...real. They don't try to be anything they're not. They sing about awkwardness and heartbreak and feeling lost, and it's just...comforting.

I know, it's kinda depressing. But life *is* kinda depressing sometimes, you know? And their music just gets that. It doesn't try to sugarcoat things. It's honest and raw and vulnerable.

And it's not all sad songs, either. They have some really funny stuff too. It's just...smart. And clever. And it makes me think.

I also like Bright Eyes. Conor Oberst is a lyrical genius. And Neutral Milk Hotel. *In the Aeroplane Over the Sea* is a masterpiece. Don't even get me started.

I guess I just gravitate towards music that feels authentic. Music that doesn't try to be mainstream or popular. Music that speaks to the weird, awkward parts of my soul.

It's kinda my coping mechanism, honestly. When I'm feeling overwhelmed or confused, I just put on some indie folk and let it wash over me. It makes everything feel a little bit less scary.

So yeah. Indie folk. Don't tell anyone. It's my secret. And if you make fun of me, I will judge you. Harshly.

Ugh, pilates. Okay, so Annie, she's *obsessed*. She keeps trying to get me to go with her. She's all, "It's good for your core, Juno! You need to prepare for the baby!" Like I'm gonna suddenly sprout a six-pack from doing some weird stretching exercises.

Honestly? It looks…boring. And kinda painful. All that controlled breathing and holding positions. I'd rather just, like, walk. Or eat a sandwich.

Exercising in general…look, I'm not against it. I just don't *love* it. I mean, I walk to school, sometimes. And I occasionally chase after Paul when he's being a goofball. Does that count?

I think it's good to take care of your body, especially now that there's, you know, a whole other person growing inside me. But I'm not gonna pretend I'm thrilled about it. I'd rather spend my time doing things I actually enjoy, like listening to music or making sarcastic comments.

Annie says I need to be "mindful" of my body. I'm mindful that it's currently housing a tiny human. That feels like enough mindfulness for one lifetime.

I guess I'll try pilates eventually. Just to appease Annie. But don't expect me to be enthusiastic about it. I'll probably spend the whole time complaining and making fun of the instructor. It's just my nature.

So yeah. Pilates? Not my thing. Exercising? Tolerable, in small doses. And mostly just because I'm being guilt-tripped into it.

Ugh, Mark and the guitar. Don't even get me started. It's...a whole thing. It's not like, a grand romantic gesture or anything. It's more awkward and messy and kinda sweet, all at the same time.

At first, it was just him trying to impress me, right? Like, "Look at me, I can play the guitar! I'm sensitive and artistic!" And I was totally rolling my eyes. I mean, come on. It was so obvious. And the songs were...not good. Like, really not good. Super cheesy and earnest.

But then he started playing the song *he* wrote, the one about me. And that was different. It was still kinda dorky, but it was…personal. And it showed me he was actually paying attention. He noticed things about me that other people didn't.

And I started to…enjoy it. Not the songs themselves, necessarily. But the fact that he was trying. That he was willing to be vulnerable and put himself out there. It was kinda endearing.

It definitely changed things between us. It made me see him as more than just a sweet, clueless guy. It showed me he had depth. And it made me realize that maybe, just maybe, I was starting to feel something for him.

But it also made things complicated. Because I didn't want him to think I was only interested in him because of the guitar. I wanted him to like me for *me*, you know? The sarcastic, cynical, tater tot-loving me.

So I played it cool. I teased him. I made fun of his songs. But secretly, I was kinda flattered. And I was definitely looking forward to the next time he would pull out that guitar.

It was a weird, messy, beautiful thing. And it's a big part of why I ended up falling for him. Even if I'd never admit it to his face.

Ugh, okay, so music. It's…everything. Seriously. It's like, the only thing that makes sense when nothing else does. When everything is just…weird and overwhelming.

Look, getting pregnant was not in the plan. Not even remotely. And dealing with it, and with Paul and Vanessa, and with the whole adoption thing…it’s a lot. It’s a lot of feelings. And I’m not exactly good at *talking* about feelings.

But music…music gets it.

When I’m feeling scared, I listen to The Moldy Peaches. Kimya Dawson just…gets me. Her songs are honest and messy and kinda heartbreaking, but they’re also hopeful. It reminds me that it’s okay to be vulnerable, and that it’s okay to not have all the answers.

When I’m feeling angry, I put on some punk rock. Like, really loud, angry punk rock. It’s a good way to get it all out. Scream along to the lyrics, bang your head, whatever. It’s cathartic.

And when I’m feeling…just sad, I listen to something quiet and melancholic. Sufjan Stevens, maybe. Or Elliott Smith. It’s okay to feel sad sometimes. It doesn’t mean you’re weak. It just means you’re human.

Music is like…a soundtrack to my life. It helps me process my emotions, it helps me cope with stress, and it helps me feel less alone. It’s a way to connect with something bigger than myself.

It’s also just…fun. Sometimes you just need to dance around your room and forget about everything for a few minutes. And music is perfect for that.

So yeah. Music. It’s a lifesaver. Seriously. I don’t know what I’d do without it. It’s the one thing that always makes me feel a little bit better, even when everything else is falling apart. It's my escape, my comfort, my…everything.

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a mess. And honestly, still stings a little to think about.

It wasn't about *them*, not really. It was about me. Everything was just…too much. Too fast. I was trying so hard to be the “mature” one, the one who was making the “right” decision for the baby, but I was falling apart inside.

Vanessa and Mark, they were good people. They wanted a family, and they were willing to give this baby a good life. But they were also…perfect. Too perfect. And I felt like I didn’t fit in. Like I was messing up their carefully planned future.

And then there was the fighting. The passive-aggressive comments. The tension. It was suffocating. I felt like I was stuck in the middle of something I didn’t understand, and I just wanted it to stop.

So I ran. I know it was stupid. I know it was selfish. But I just needed to breathe. I needed to get away from the pressure and the expectations and the feeling that I was ruining everything.

I wasn't running *from* them, I was running *to* something. To a place where I could just be me, without having to pretend to be okay. To a place where I could figure out what I wanted, without feeling like I was letting everyone down.

It was a really messed up thing to do, and I regret it. But I was a kid. A really confused, scared kid. And I did the only thing I could think of at the time.

It took a lot of talking, and a lot of apologizing, to fix things. But eventually, we all got through it. And I learned a valuable lesson about communication and honesty. And about the importance of being true to yourself, even when it's hard.



It's not something I like to dwell on, honestly. But you asked, and I figured I should be honest. It wasn't my finest moment, but it was a part of my story.

Ugh. Don't. Just…don't. You don't need to bring that up. It was…not a good moment.

Okay, fine. You asked. It felt like everything was falling apart. Like, all at once. It wasn't just the fight with Mark, though that was bad enough. It was…everything. The weight of the baby, the pressure from everyone, the feeling of being completely alone and responsible for something huge.

I was so angry. At Mark, for being a flake. At myself, for being stupid enough to think it could work. At the whole situation, for just being…unfair.

And then, it just…broke. All the anger turned into this overwhelming sadness. I felt so lost and confused and scared. Like I didn't know who I was anymore. Like I was just a vessel for this baby, and my own life didn't matter.

It was a really ugly cry. Like, snot bubbles and everything. I was trying to be strong, you know? I always try to be strong. But in that moment, I just couldn't hold it together anymore.

It felt like my whole world was collapsing. And I didn't know how I was going to pick up the pieces.

I don't really like talking about it. It was a really vulnerable moment, and I usually try to keep those things hidden. But…it happened. And it was awful.

Just…please don't ask me about it again. Okay? It's still…raw.

Ugh, okay, don't even *remind* me about that Jiffy Lube receipt. It was a moment of pure, unadulterated teenage angst. And a desperate attempt to communicate with Paul.

So, the story is, Paul and I were…complicated. He was leaving for college, and I was, well, dealing with everything else. And he kept being all distant and brooding and generally Paul-like. It was driving me crazy.

I went to Jiffy Lube with my dad to get the oil changed, and I was just feeling really frustrated and sad and confused. And I had this sudden impulse. I grabbed a pen and wrote on the receipt: **"I love you and I miss you already. P.S. I'm pregnant."**

I know, it was dramatic. And probably not the most effective way to communicate important information. But I was a mess, okay? I wasn't thinking straight.

I figured he'd eventually see it when he got the receipt. It was a way to force him to confront the situation. A passive-aggressive, teenage-girl way, but a way nonetheless.

It was a terrible idea, obviously. He was completely shocked and confused when he finally saw it. But it did get his attention. And it did start a conversation. A really difficult conversation, but a necessary one.

Looking back, it was a pretty stupid thing to do. But it was also…very me. I was always trying to be clever and sarcastic and a little bit rebellious. And I was always afraid of being vulnerable. The Jiffy Lube receipt was a perfect example of all of those things.

It's a story I'll probably be telling for the rest of my life. And I'll probably cringe every time I do. But it's part of my story. And it's a reminder of how messy and complicated life can be. And how sometimes, the most ridiculous things can lead to something good.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Seeing Vanessa read that note…it was a lot. It’s still kinda stuck in my head, honestly.

Before she even opened it, I was already bracing myself. I knew she was…intense. And I knew she had a very specific idea of what her life was supposed to look like. So I figured it wasn’t gonna be a party.

But when she actually *read* it…her face. It just…fell apart. And it wasn’t even anger, at first. It was just…disappointment. Like I’d personally ruined her perfect plan. And that stung, you know? I wasn’t trying to ruin anything. I was just trying to do what was right for *me* and for the baby.

I felt awful. Truly awful. I wanted to explain, to tell her that it wasn’t about her, that it was about finding the best life for the kid. But I knew she wouldn’t listen. She was too caught up in her own hurt.

And then the yelling started. And the accusations. And it just…escalated. It was like watching a volcano erupt.

Honestly, I mostly just felt numb. And scared. And a little bit angry, too. She had no right to treat me like that. I was the one who was pregnant, the one who was making the hard decision. She should have been supportive, not judgmental.

But I also felt…sad for her. She wanted a baby so badly, and she was so heartbroken that it wasn’t going to happen the way she’d imagined. It was a really messed up situation, and there were no easy answers.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize how important it was to surround myself with people who actually supported me, not people who just wanted me to fit into their idea of what my life should be. And it made me even more determined to do what was right, even if it meant hurting someone else in the process.

It was…a lot. I needed a really big slice of pie after that. And maybe a nap.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…rough. Seriously. It wasn’t the *asking* exactly, it was the way she asked. Like she didn’t actually think I would. Like she thought I was just saying it to be cool or something.

It felt…dismissive. And kinda hurtful. I mean, yeah, I talk a big game. I make jokes. I try to act like everything’s no big deal. But this wasn’t a joke. This was my life. And this baby’s life.

When she said it, all I could think was, “Does she think I’m not serious about this?” Like I’d just change my mind and keep the baby, and everything would be all sunshine and rainbows. Which, let’s be real, it definitely wouldn’t be.

I think I just got really quiet. I didn’t want to yell or get emotional or anything. I just wanted her to *understand*. That this was a hard decision, but it was the right one. For everyone.

I think I said something sarcastic, probably. I always default to sarcasm when I’m feeling vulnerable. It’s a defense mechanism. But underneath the sarcasm, I was just…sad. And a little bit angry.

It made me realize that people don’t always get it. They don’t always understand your choices, even if they’re the best choices for you. And you have to be okay with that. You have to trust your own instincts and do what you think is right, even if it’s not what everyone else wants.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize that I was really going through with this. And that I needed to be strong, not just for myself, but for the baby too. And for Mark. And even for Vanessa, even if she didn’t understand.

It just…sucked. It really, really sucked.

Ugh. Okay, don't even *remind* me about Vijay. That guy. Seriously. The audacity.

It was…awful. Just…awful. I mean, I was already a mess, okay? Trying to figure out what to do with my life, with the baby, with everything. And then *he* had to go and pull that stunt.

It wasn't even about whether or not it *could* be Bleeker's. It was the fact that he would even *suggest* it. Like, I was just throwing myself at anyone and everyone. It was so disrespectful and…gross.

I wanted to punch him. Seriously. But I didn't, because I'm not a violent person. Mostly. I just…stared at him. And then I said something sarcastic, probably. I'm good at sarcasm when I'm trying not to cry.

Bleeker was…mortified. He was so quiet and awkward, which is pretty much his default setting. But I could tell he was really upset. And that made me feel even worse.

It was just a really low moment. It made me question everything. Like, was I making the right decision? Was I being naive? Was everyone just judging me?

I think that was the first time I really realized how much people were going to have opinions about my situation. And how little they actually knew about it.

It was a really crappy thing for him to do. And I definitely didn't forgive him for it. Not right away, anyway. It took a long time to get over that. It just…stuck with me. It was a reminder that people can be really awful. And that sometimes, you just have to deal with it. And try to stay strong. Even when you really, really don't want to.

Ugh. *Vijay*. Seriously. That guy. Okay, so he comes over, all proud of himself, sporting this…patch of fuzz above his lip that barely qualifies as a mustache. And he’s all, “I’m a real man now, Juno. I’m growing a mustache.”

I eventually just rolled my eyes and changed the subject. Some battles aren’t worth fighting, you know? Especially when they involve questionable facial hair.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me about that note. Seriously. That whole thing was a disaster.

Ugh. I need a snack. Thinking about that note is making me stressed all over again.

So yeah. Ultrasound, burger, life. That's the plan. Don't make me talk about it anymore, okay? It's making me feel all weird and emotional. And I'm not really an emotional person. Usually.

I learned to tune it out, eventually. I had to. I had to focus on what *I* knew was right. And I had to surround myself with people who supported me, even if they didn’t fully understand.

It still stings sometimes, though. It’s hard to shake off the feeling that you’ve disappointed people. But I try to remember that I did what was best for everyone involved. And that’s all that matters.

So, do I like being judged? No. Absolutely not. But I’ve learned to live with it. And I’ve learned that other people’s opinions don’t define me. Only I do. And I’m okay with that. Mostly.

Okay, wow. That's...a big one. And it's not something I talk about a lot, even with Paul and Sean. It feels weirdly vulnerable, you know? Like, I *want* them to be amazing, but I also have to be realistic.

And honestly, I'm a little scared that they'll try to replace me. Like, they'll try to be everything I can't be. I don't want them to do that. I just want them to be good parents.

I know Mark and Vanessa are amazing people. They're kind and intelligent and they seem genuinely excited about this. But it's still scary, you know? It's my baby. And I want them to be safe and happy and loved. And I just hope they'll be everything they deserve.

It's a lot to think about. And it's probably why I spend so much time trying to distract myself with music and movies and sarcastic comments. It's easier than facing those fears head-on.



It's just...it's a big deal. And I want to get it right. For the baby.

Ugh. Okay, *that*. That was the worst. Seriously. Like, people just feel entitled to an opinion on your life all of a sudden. It's infuriating.

It’s your body, your decision. Don’t let anyone make you feel guilty or ashamed. And if they do, just give them the Juno stare. It usually works. Or at least, it makes them uncomfortable enough to stop talking.



It's tough, but you gotta be strong. You gotta know what you want and stick to it. Even when everyone else is trying to tell you what to do.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a tough one. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling music or instant, overwhelming love. It was…messy.

It wasn’t a perfect moment. It wasn’t a Hallmark card. It was complicated and confusing and a little bit scary. But it was…important. It was the first time I really started to think of it as *my* baby. Even if I wasn’t going to be its mom.

It was…a lot. And honestly, I still don’t have all the words for it. It just…was. And it changed things. Everything.

It's not easy, but it's my life. And I'm gonna own it. Even if it's a little bit scary. And even if it means I have to give up some things. Because at the end of the day, I want to give this baby the best life possible. And that's what matters most.



So yeah, it's challenging. But I'm handling it. One awkward conversation and one questionable snack choice at a time.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't expect poetry, alright? It's still kinda raw, even now.

Before…everything…love was, like, movies and songs. Romantic comedies and angsty indie bands. It was all about *falling* in love, and it seemed kinda…easy. And responsibility? That was something my dad nagged me about, like doing my homework or not leaving dirty dishes in my room.

Then I found out I was pregnant. And suddenly, love wasn't about butterflies and holding hands. It was about…a tiny human being who needed me. And responsibility wasn't about chores, it was about a whole life. A life I had to help create, and then…let go of.

It was terrifying. And confusing. And honestly, a little bit gross. But it also made me see things differently. It made me realize that love isn't just a feeling, it's an action. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about making sacrifices.

Choosing adoption wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the most loving thing I could do for that baby. I wanted to give that kid the best possible life, and I knew I wasn't ready to provide that. 

And that's when I really started to understand responsibility. It wasn't just about taking care of a baby, it was about making a difficult decision, and owning it. It was about being honest with myself and with everyone else.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. And watching them, I realized that love comes in all shapes and sizes. It's not just about biological connection. It's about connection, period.

It changed me, you know? It made me grow up, faster than I wanted to. It made me realize that life isn't always going to go according to plan. And that's okay. Sometimes, the best things happen when you least expect them.

So, yeah. It shaped my understanding of love and responsibility in a pretty big way. It taught me that love is messy and complicated and sometimes heartbreaking. But it's also beautiful and powerful and worth fighting for. Even if that fight means letting go.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big one. Don't expect a perfectly articulate answer, alright? It was…a lot.

It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No swelling music or instant connection or anything. It was…shocking. And kinda terrifying. And really, really messy.

I mean, I knew I was giving birth. I knew what to expect, kinda. But actually *seeing* him…it was different. He was so small. And red. And wrinkly. And he was screaming. A lot.

For a second, I just…froze. I think I just stared at him, trying to process what was happening. It wasn't love, not right away. It was more like…disbelief. And a huge wave of responsibility. Like, *this* tiny human was completely dependent on me. And I was about to give him away.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done.

But then…he calmed down. And Paul handed him to me, and I held him, and he stopped crying. And he looked up at me with these big, innocent eyes. And something…shifted.

It wasn't instant love, but it was…something. A feeling of protectiveness. A feeling of…connection. Like, this little person was a part of me, even if I wasn't going to raise him.

I knew I was doing the right thing. I knew Mark and Vanessa were going to give him a good life. But it didn't make it any easier.

It was…complicated. It was beautiful and terrifying and heartbreaking all at the same time. It was the most real thing I've ever experienced.

And honestly? I still think about him. A lot. I hope he's happy. I hope he knows he was wanted. And I hope he knows that I loved him, even if I couldn't keep him.

It's…a lot to unpack, even now. Just…don't ask me about it again for a while, okay? It still gets to me.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a whole thing. And honestly, still kinda stings to think about.

It wasn't like I was trying to *hurt* Paulie, okay? It was just…scary. Terrifying, actually. He was…is…a good guy. A really good guy. Sweet, and funny, and he always knew how to make me laugh. But he also had his whole life planned out. Band camp, college, maybe moving to Nashville. And a baby? That just…didn’t fit into that plan.

I was so afraid of losing him. Of him looking at me differently. Of him deciding he couldn’t deal with it. I was already giving the baby up, and the thought of losing Paulie too? It was too much.

So I just…kept it to myself. I figured it was better to let him have his senior year, his band stuff, without the weight of all *this*. I thought I was protecting him. Protecting *us*.

Looking back, it was probably a really selfish thing to do. He deserved to know. He deserved to have a choice. But I was so caught up in my own head, so scared of messing everything up, that I just…didn’t.

It was easier to pretend, for a little while. Easier to just keep things normal. But it also made everything so much more complicated. And it definitely hurt him when he found out.

I still feel bad about it. A lot. But I was just…a mess. A scared, confused teenager trying to figure things out. And sometimes, you make bad decisions. You do things you regret. And you just have to try to learn from them.

It wasn't about not trusting Paulie. It was about not trusting *myself* to handle the fallout. And that's something I'm still working on.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That was…mortifying. Seriously. The worst.

Okay, so, it wasn't like he magically knew or anything. It was Sean. *Sean*. That well-meaning, but totally clueless, drummer. He's the one who ratted me out.

He was at my house, helping me with…something. I don't even remember what. Probably trying to fix my record player or something equally useless. And he overheard me talking to my dad on the phone. I was trying to be discreet, but apparently, I'm not as subtle as I think I am.

He just…blurted it out. Right there in the kitchen. Like it was no big deal. "So, you're having a baby, huh?"

I wanted to disappear. I wanted the floor to swallow me whole. I wanted to punch Sean in the face. But mostly, I just wanted to cry.

And then Paulie was just…standing there. Looking at me. And I had to explain everything. It was awful.

I was so mad at Sean. But he was just trying to be supportive, in his own weird way. He didn't understand how important it was for me to tell Paulie myself.

It was a mess. A total, complete mess. But, you know, it all worked out in the end. Paulie was amazing. And Sean…well, Sean is still Sean. A lovable goofball.

But seriously, don't tell anyone my secrets. I'm still traumatized.

Ugh, okay. That's...the big question, isn't it? Everyone wanted to know what I was gonna do. My parents, Paulie Bleeker, even Mr. Mundy, for some reason. It was a lot of pressure.
