So, adoption just…made sense. It wasn't easy, though. It was really hard. Saying goodbye to that little kid…that was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I knew it was the right thing.

I wanted to find parents who were…cool. Who would let the baby be themselves. And I found them. Mark and Vanessa. They were perfect. They were quirky and kind and they just…got it.

It wasn't about giving up a baby. It was about giving a baby the best possible life. And it was about making a choice that was right for me, too. It was about taking control of my own future.

It was messy and complicated and scary. But it was also…empowering. I made a decision, and I stuck with it. And that's something I can be proud of.

It wasn't a perfect solution, but it was *my* solution. And that's what mattered.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with Bleeker. Seriously. That whole thing was…a mess.

Okay, so, when he said he didn't want to see the baby? It felt like someone punched me in the stomach. And not like a little tap, either. Like a full-on, Mike Tyson-level punch.

I mean, I knew he was…Bleeker. Kind of a space cadet. Not exactly the most emotionally available guy. But I thought, you know, maybe once the baby was actually *here*, he'd step up. That he'd want to be involved.

But no. He just…didn't. He said he wasn't ready. That he was still figuring things out. That he needed to focus on his music.

It wasn't about the baby, it was about *him*. It always was.

And it wasn't even the fact that he didn't want to be a dad. It was the way he said it. Like it was nothing. Like the baby was just…an inconvenience.

I was so angry. And so hurt. And so confused. I mean, I was giving a baby up for adoption, which was already the hardest thing I'd ever done. And then the guy who was supposed to be on my side just…bailed.

It made me question everything. About him, about myself, about the whole situation. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being stupid? Was I just a total mess?

I tried to be cool about it. I tried to act like it didn't bother me. But inside, I was falling apart.

It took a long time to get over that. And honestly, I still think about it sometimes. It just…sucked. It really, really sucked. And it made me realize that you can't rely on anyone but yourself. Which, you know, is a valuable lesson. But still. Bleeker. Ugh.

Ugh. Okay. That. That was…a lot.

It was…weird. Really weird. Like, I’d spent nine months carrying this kid, right? Feeling it kick, craving weird food combinations, dealing with morning sickness that was definitely *not* just in the morning. It was…intimate. Even if it wasn’t, like, a planned intimacy.

And then, suddenly, it was over. And there was Vanessa.

She looked…a mess. Seriously. Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing, like, a stained sweatshirt, and she had this goofy, sleep-deprived grin on her face. She was surrounded by baby stuff – blankets, bottles, diapers – and it was all kinda…chaotic.

And the baby…oh, the baby. It was so small. And perfect. And Vanessa was just…glowing. Like she’d won the lottery and found a lifetime supply of chocolate.

It was supposed to be sad, right? I was supposed to be heartbroken. And there was a little bit of that, I guess. A little pang of…loss. But it wasn’t what I expected.

It was more…relief. And happiness. For her. Seeing her so genuinely happy, even amidst the chaos, it was…good. It was what I wanted. I wanted the baby to have a good home, with people who would love it and take care of it. And Vanessa and Mark? They were those people.

It was like…I’d built something amazing, and then I’d handed it over to someone who could appreciate it even more. It was a weird kind of pride. And a weird kind of letting go.

I remember just standing there, watching them, and thinking, “Okay. This is right.” Even if it was messy and disorganized and totally overwhelming. It was right. And that was enough.

It didn’t magically erase everything, you know? It didn’t make everything perfect. But it made it…okay. It made it feel like I’d made the right decision. And honestly? That was all that mattered.

Ugh, okay, don't even *start* with the "Anyone Else But You" thing. It's…complicated. And kinda embarrassing. But fine, you asked.

That song…it was everything. And nothing. It was the soundtrack to all the awkwardness and the confusion and the…well, the everything with Bleeker.

See, it wasn't about *wanting* to be with anyone else. It was about being so terrified of ruining the friendship that we pretended we were okay with just being friends, even though it was clearly a disaster. Like, a slow-motion train wreck of unrequited feelings.

The song is all about pretending, about putting on a show. And that's exactly what we were doing. We were pretending to be cool with just hanging out, with just being friends, when really, we both wanted more. But we were too scared to admit it.

It was a safety net, I guess. A way to avoid the risk of getting hurt. But it also kept us stuck. It kept us from being honest with each other.

And then, at the end, when we finally *did* admit it…the song felt different. It wasn't about pretending anymore. It was about finally letting go of the fear and just being ourselves.

It's a cheesy song, I know. But it perfectly captured the messiness of our relationship. It was a reminder that sometimes, the hardest thing to do is to be honest with yourself and with the people you care about.

So yeah, "Anyone Else But You" is significant. It's a reminder of all the stupid things we did, all the time we wasted, and all the feelings we tried to ignore. But it's also a reminder that sometimes, even the messiest relationships can lead to something good.

Just…don't tell Bleeker I said any of this. He'll never let me live it down.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about the whole baby shower thing? It's...awkward. Really awkward. It's not like I *want* a baby shower, okay? It's just...people feel like they *should* throw one. It's tradition. But it's a weird tradition when the person having the baby is actively giving it *away*.

I think people are unsure because they don't really know how to handle it. It's not a typical situation. Usually, a baby shower is about celebrating a new mom and getting ready for a baby she's going to raise. But I'm not raising this baby. Mark and Vanessa are.

So, it's like, are they celebrating me? Or are they celebrating Mark and Vanessa? And is it okay to celebrate a baby that I'm choosing to give up? It's a lot to unpack.

I think some people are also worried about hurting my feelings. They don't want to make me feel like I'm not a "real" mom. But honestly, I already know I'm not going to be a mom. That's the whole point.

And then there's the whole "adoption" thing. Some people are still weird about adoption. They don't understand it. They think it's sad. And they don't want to bring that sadness into a baby shower.

It's just...complicated. I get why people are hesitant. It's a sensitive situation. I just wish they would either commit to throwing a shower or just forget about it. This half-hearted, tiptoeing around is way more stressful than actually planning a party.

Honestly, I'd rather just have a quiet night in with a pizza and a good movie. But that's not what people want, is it? They want to celebrate. And I guess that's okay. Just...make it quick. And don't make me wear a frilly dress.

Ugh, okay, Bren. Seriously. She's got this whole "responsible adult" thing down, which is fine, I guess. Someone's gotta do it. But she's also kinda…smothering. And she definitely thinks I'm incapable of making my own decisions.

Look, Mark was just being nice, okay? He knew I liked The Moldy Peaches, and he burned me a CD. It's not like he was offering me, like, drugs or something. It was a *CD*. And the movies? He just let me borrow them. It wasn't a big deal.

But Bren sees it as…grooming, I think is the word she used. Like, he was trying to manipulate me or something. Which is ridiculous. Mark's a little clueless, yeah, but he's not evil. He's just…a guy.

I think she's projecting, honestly. She's got her own stuff going on with her husband, and she's worried about me making the same mistakes. She's trying to protect me, I get that. But it feels like she doesn't trust me to make my own choices.

She thinks I'm still a little kid, and I'm not. I'm pregnant, for crying out loud! I'm about to be a mom. I think I can handle a few movies and a CD.

It's just…she's always been so controlling. And I'm trying to figure out who I am and what I want, and it's hard when someone's constantly telling you what to do.

I told her it wasn't a big deal, and that I can think for myself. But she just gave me that look. You know the one. The "I'm disappointed in you" look. It's the worst.

I guess she just wants me to be safe. But sometimes, being safe means taking risks. And sometimes, it means making your own mistakes. And I need to be allowed to do that. Even if Bren doesn't like it.

Ugh, okay, so you're asking about my mom. Bren. She's...a lot. And she has this *thing* about me being naive. Like, I'm still twelve, even though I'm clearly not. It's infuriating.

She thinks I don't understand marriage because, and I quote, "You've never had a real relationship, Juno. You just read books and listen to records." Which, okay, rude. Books and records are important! They're how I learn about the world!

But I think it's more than that. She and my stepdad, Mark, have a...complicated relationship. They've been through a lot. And she's projecting all her baggage onto me. She thinks if she warns me about all the pitfalls of marriage, I'll somehow avoid them. 

It's like she thinks marriage is this minefield of disappointment and compromise, and she's trying to protect me from getting blown up. Which, I appreciate the sentiment, I guess. But it's also really condescending.

She also thinks I'm too idealistic. I believe in love and happy endings and all that stuff. And she thinks that's just...silly. She thinks real life is messy and complicated and that you have to be realistic.

But I think you can be realistic *and* hopeful. You can acknowledge that things are going to be hard, but still believe that they can be good. 

And honestly, I think she's scared. Scared that I'll make the same mistakes she did. Scared that I'll get hurt. 

So, yeah. That's why she thinks I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage. Because she's projecting her own fears and insecurities onto me. And because she just doesn't get me. It's a mom thing, I guess.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the hard part. It’s not like I woke up one morning and was all, “Oh, yeah, adoption! Great plan!” It was…messy. And scary. And a lot of thinking.

Mark…well, Mark wasn’t exactly stepping up. He was a good guy, but he was…Mark. He was still figuring things out too. And honestly, I didn’t want to tie him down. He had his own dreams.

Then I met Vanessa and Mark. They were…amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They had a beautiful home and a loving relationship. They just…radiated goodness. And I knew, instantly, that they would be incredible parents.

And honestly? Knowing that little kid is going to be loved and cared for…that makes it a little bit easier. It doesn’t erase the pain, but it makes it…worth it.

It’s complicated. It’s not a happy story, exactly. But it’s my story. And I’m okay with it. Mostly.

Ugh. Okay, deep breaths. That's...a big question. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a stumble through a minefield of hormones and awkward conversations. But yeah, I learned a lot. About life, about people, and mostly, about myself.

I also learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. I put up a lot of walls, you know? A lot of sarcasm and snark. But underneath all that, I actually care a lot. About people, about doing the right thing, about making the world a little bit better.

And I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about the people who love you and support you, no matter what. My dad, Vanessa, even Paul and Annie…they were all amazing. They helped me through everything, and I couldn't have done it without them.

I also realized I didn't have all the answers. I thought I was so smart and independent, but I was just a kid. And it was okay to ask for help. It was okay to be vulnerable.

It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking, but it was also…beautiful. It forced me to grow up, to face my fears, and to figure out what I really wanted out of life. 

I still don't have it all figured out, obviously. But I'm a little bit closer now. And I'm okay with that. I'm okay with being a work in progress. Because that's what life is, right? A constant process of learning and growing and figuring things out. And sometimes, it takes a little bit of unexpected pregnancy to get you there.

Ugh, okay, Vanessa and Mark. That was…a lot. At first, it was just…weird. They were, like, a perfect couple. All Pottery Barn and organic snacks. And me? I was a pregnant teenager who liked tater tots and listening to The Moldy Peaches. We didn't exactly have a lot in common.

I think I initially saw them as…obstacles. Like, people I had to deal with to get through this whole thing. I was trying to be cool and detached, you know? Like, "Okay, I'm giving you a baby. Let's just get this over with."

But then, as things went on, it started to change. They weren't just this perfect couple. They were…people. Flawed people. They argued, they worried, they were scared. And they were *really* excited about becoming parents.

Vanessa, she was the one who really broke through my shell, I think. She was so open and honest, and she didn't try to pretend she had all the answers. She just wanted to make sure I was okay. She listened to me, even when I was being a sarcastic mess. And she didn't judge me.

Mark was a little harder to read at first. He was more reserved. But he was also incredibly kind and supportive. He built me a rocking chair for the baby. A *rocking chair*. That was…a big deal.

I started to see them not as the "adoptive parents," but as…Vanessa and Mark. People who were going to love this baby and give it a good life. And I started to feel…protective of them. Like, I wanted them to be happy.

It wasn't like I suddenly wanted to be their daughter or anything. That would be weird. But I did develop a real connection with them. A respect. And a fondness.

By the end of the process, it was…bittersweet. I was happy for them, but it was also hard to let go. It was like saying goodbye to friends. And in a way, they were.

It changed me, too. It made me realize that families come in all shapes and sizes. And that love is what really matters. It wasn't the family *I* expected, but it was a family nonetheless. And it was a good one.



It's still kinda hard to talk about, honestly. It was a really emotional time. But it was also a really important one. It taught me a lot about myself, and about the world.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a heavy one. You're going straight for the gut, aren't you?

Regrets? Yeah. I have a few. Not, like, huge, life-altering regrets. But little things. Things I replay in my head sometimes when I can't sleep.

I regret not telling Paul sooner. I was so scared, and I just…froze. It made things so much harder on both of us. And I regret some of the things I said to him, especially when we were fighting. I was a mess, and I took it out on him. He didn't deserve that.

I also regret being so…dismissive of my parents at first. I thought I had everything figured out, and I didn't want their help. But they were actually really supportive, in their own weird way. And I should have let them in sooner.

But mostly, I don't regret my decision to give the baby up for adoption. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, and it still hurts sometimes. But I knew it was the right thing to do. Mark and Vanessa were amazing, and they gave the baby a life I couldn't have provided.

I guess what I regret is the pain. The pain I caused myself, the pain I caused Paul, the pain I caused my parents. I wish things had been easier. But life isn't easy, is it?

It's weird, though. Even with the regrets, I wouldn't change anything. Because everything that happened made me who I am today. And I'm…okay with that. Mostly.

It's just…sometimes I wonder what things would have been like if I'd made different choices. But then I remember that you can't change the past. You can only learn from it. And try to do better in the future.

So yeah. Regrets. But also…growth. And a little bit of peace. It's complicated. Like everything else in life.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big one. It's not something I talk about a lot, even now. It still feels…raw, sometimes.

It wasn't easy, obviously. People think it was this brave, selfless thing, and it was, I guess. But it was also the hardest thing I've ever done. Saying goodbye to that little kid…it felt like a piece of me was being ripped away.

It's…a lot to unpack. I don't usually get this vulnerable. But you asked. And it's important to remember that even when things are hard, there's always hope. And that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the ones that lead to the greatest growth.

Okay, wow. That's...a big one. If I could go back and talk to myself, right when I found out...it wouldn't be easy. But here's what I'd say. And what I'd say to any girl going through something similar.

First of all: **it's okay to be scared.** Like, really scared. It's a huge thing, and it's okay to freak out. Don't let anyone tell you to just "calm down" or "be responsible" right away. You need to feel your feelings.

Second: **you are not alone.** Even if it feels like it. There are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust. Your mom, a friend, a teacher, a counselor…anyone. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: **you have options.** And they're *your* options. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you don't want to do. Whether that's keeping the baby, giving it up for adoption, or something else…it's your decision. And it's okay to take your time and figure out what's right for you.

Fourth: **it's not your fault.** Seriously. Don't beat yourself up about it. Things happen. It doesn't make you a bad person.

Fifth: **be kind to yourself.** This is going to be hard. There will be good days and bad days. And you're going to need to take care of yourself. Eat well, get enough sleep, and do things that make you happy.

And finally: **you are stronger than you think.** You're going to get through this. It's not going to be easy, but you're going to get through it. And you're going to come out on the other side a stronger, more resilient person.

It's not a fairytale. It's messy and complicated and sometimes really painful. But it's also a chance to learn and grow and figure out who you are. And that's a pretty powerful thing.

Just remember, you're not defined by this. You're still you. And you deserve to be happy.

Ugh, okay, so the blog. Yeah. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't like I *planned* to document my entire life for the internet, okay? It just…happened.

It started with Leah. She was all, "You *have* to write this down, Juno! It's like, a modern-day tragedy! A teen pregnancy! It's gold!" And Leah is dramatic, to say the least. But she had a point. It *was* kinda crazy.

I was just trying to navigate everything, you know? School, Paul, Annie, the whole adoption thing…it was a lot. And I needed a way to process it all. Talking to my dad was good, but he's…my dad. He doesn't always *get* it.

So I started writing. Just for myself, at first. It was a way to vent, to make sense of things, to be honest about how I was feeling. And then Leah convinced me to make it public. She said it could help other people. Which sounded kinda cheesy, but also…maybe she was right.

It was scary, putting myself out there like that. I got some weird comments, obviously. But I also got messages from other girls who were going through similar things. And that made it worth it.

It was a way to connect with people, to feel less alone. And it was a way to take control of my own story. Everyone was already talking about my pregnancy, but I wanted to tell it *my* way.

So yeah, that's how the blog started. It wasn't about fame or attention. It was about survival. And maybe, just maybe, about helping someone else along the way. It was a way to make something good out of a really complicated situation. And honestly? It was kinda therapeutic.

Ugh, okay, deep question. Don't make me get all sentimental on you. But fine. If I *had* to pick one thing…the biggest lesson…it wasn’t about babies, or even about giving a baby up. It was about…owning your own stuff.

Like, before all this happened, I was just kinda drifting. Trying to be cool, trying to be funny, trying to avoid anything that felt too real. I was good at saying what I *thought* people wanted to hear, not what I actually thought.

But getting pregnant…that forced me to face things. To make a decision. A really big decision. And it wasn’t easy. It was scary and messy and confusing.

But I realized that no matter what I chose, I had to own it. I had to take responsibility for my actions and for my life. I couldn’t blame anyone else. I couldn’t pretend it didn’t happen.

And that applied to everything, not just the pregnancy. It applied to my relationships, my friendships, my future. 

It’s easy to let other people define you, to tell you what to do, to tell you who to be. But you gotta figure out what *you* want. And then you gotta go for it, even if it’s scary. Even if it’s unpopular.

So yeah. Owning your own stuff. That’s the biggest lesson. It’s still something I’m working on, honestly. But it’s a good start. And it’s a lot more empowering than trying to be someone you’re not.

Don't tell anyone I said all that, okay? It's kinda embarrassing. I have a reputation to maintain.

Okay. Okay, deep breaths. This is…this is the thing I know about, right? This is my area of expertise, unfortunately.

First of all: it's okay to freak out. Seriously. It's a huge thing. A life-altering thing. You're allowed to be scared, confused, angry, all of it. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Second: don't make any rash decisions. Take your time. Talk to people you trust. Your parents, a friend, a counselor…anyone who will listen without judging you. And if your parents *are* judging you, find someone else. You deserve support.

Third: there are options. And they're all valid. You can parent, you can adopt, you can…not parent. It's your body, your life, your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: it's not your fault. Seriously. Stuff happens. It doesn't mean you're a bad person. It doesn't mean you messed up. It just means you're facing a really difficult situation.

Fifth: it's going to be hard, no matter what you choose. But you're stronger than you think. You'll get through it. And you're not alone.

And finally: don't be afraid to ask for help. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Let them.

Look, I know it's scary. I've been there. But you're not the first person to go through this, and you won't be the last. You'll figure it out. And whatever you decide, I believe in you.

Just…take it one day at a time. And maybe listen to some good music. It helps. A lot.



It's a mess, okay? But you can handle it. You really can.

Ugh, okay, that's…heavy. I haven't even really let myself *think* about that too much, you know? It's too much pressure. But you asked.

It's not about them being a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. Honestly, I don't care what they *do*. I just want them to be…happy. Genuinely, truly happy. And to figure out what makes *them* tick, not what anyone else wants them to be.

I want them to be kind. To be empathetic. To stand up for what they believe in, even when it's hard. And to not be afraid to be themselves, even if that means being weird or different.

I want them to have a good sense of humor. Life is too short to take everything so seriously. And I want them to be able to laugh at themselves.

I want them to be resilient. Life is gonna throw curveballs, and I want them to be able to bounce back from whatever happens.

And I want them to know that they're loved. Unconditionally. No matter what.

I don't want to force my own values on them. I want them to make their own mistakes and learn from them. I want them to explore the world and find their own path.

I just want them to be a good person. And to live a life that's meaningful to *them*.

It's not about achieving greatness or making a lot of money. It's about finding joy and purpose in the everyday.

Honestly, I just want them to be okay. In a world that's often not okay. And that's enough.



It's kinda scary, thinking about it. But also…hopeful. I want to give them the best possible start in life, and then let them fly. It's all I can do, right?

Ugh, okay, this is a good one. And it's something I dealt with *a lot*. The biggest misconception? That we're just…stupid. Or irresponsible. Or that we threw our lives away.

Like, people automatically assume you weren't using protection, or that you didn't care about your future. They look at you like you're some kind of cautionary tale. And it's so frustrating.

Because it's never that simple. Life happens. Things go wrong. And sometimes, you end up pregnant. It doesn't mean you're a bad person. It doesn't mean you're incapable of making good decisions. It just means you're in a really tough situation.

And honestly, a lot of teen moms are incredibly resilient and resourceful. We have to be. We're juggling school, work, and a baby. It's not easy. But we do it.

People need to stop judging and start offering support. We're not looking for pity, we're looking for help. We're looking for people to believe in us.

It's not the end of the world. It's just a different path. And sometimes, that path can lead to amazing things. It definitely led to some unexpected things for me.

So yeah, that's the biggest misconception. We're not stupid. We're just…young women facing a really challenging situation. And we deserve to be treated with respect.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the big one, isn’t it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it was some easy decision. It wasn’t.

It wasn’t about not wanting the baby, okay? That’s what people always assume. It was about wanting something *better* for the baby. A life I just…couldn’t give.

I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone raising a human being. I was barely keeping my grades up, I was working at a movie theater, and my parents…well, they were trying, but they had their own stuff going on.

I wanted this kid to have everything. A stable home, two parents who were ready for it, a good education, opportunities…things I just couldn’t provide at that point in my life. I wasn’t ready to give up *my* life completely, and I didn’t think it was fair to ask a baby to do that.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They had a beautiful home and a loving relationship. They were everything I wanted for this baby.

It was the hardest decision I’ve ever made. It still is. There are days I wonder what things would be like if I’d kept the baby. But then I remember Mark and Vanessa, and I know I made the right choice.

It wasn’t about giving up a baby. It was about making a plan. It was about being responsible. It was about wanting the best for someone else, even if it meant sacrificing my own happiness.

It was…complicated. And it still is. But I don’t regret it. I really don’t. Because I know that little kid is loved and cared for. And that’s all that really matters.



It’s not a story with a neat little ending, you know? It’s messy and real and…it just is.

Ugh, okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn’t like picking out a new pair of Converse, you know? It was way more complicated than I ever thought it would be.

Honestly, at first, I just wanted someone…not me. Someone who had their life together. Someone who could give the baby everything I couldn’t. I was looking for perfect, which, looking back, was kinda dumb. Perfect doesn’t exist.

There were a couple of other couples, but they felt…off. One was too focused on having a “perfect” baby, like a little accessory. Another was kinda…intense. Like they were interviewing *me* to see if I was worthy of letting them have the baby. It was creepy.

Then there was Vanessa and Mark. They weren’t flashy or anything. They were just…normal. And kind. And they actually *listened* to me. They didn’t try to tell me what to do or how to feel. They just asked me questions and let me talk.

Vanessa, she was a little quirky, like me. She liked records and vintage clothes and stuff. And Mark, he was quiet, but he had this really gentle way about him. They both just seemed…safe.

But it wasn’t just that. It was when I visited their house. It wasn’t fancy, but it felt…warm. Like a real home. And they had a dog, a goofy golden retriever named Comet. I’m a sucker for dogs.

And they weren’t afraid to admit they were scared. They knew having a baby was a big responsibility, and they weren’t pretending it was going to be easy. They were honest about their fears and their hopes.

I realized I wasn’t looking for perfect parents. I was looking for parents who were willing to love the baby unconditionally, even when things got tough. And Vanessa and Mark, they were those parents.

It still wasn’t easy, letting go. It was the hardest thing I’ve ever done. But I knew, deep down, that I was making the right decision. They were going to give the baby a good life. A better life than I could. And that’s all that mattered.

It wasn’t about finding the “best” parents. It was about finding the right parents. And for that baby, Vanessa and Mark were the right ones.

Ugh, music? It was…everything. Seriously. It was my lifeline, my escape, my way of figuring out what the heck was going on inside my head. It was way more important than, like, algebra or gym class. Which, let's be real, are both pretty useless.

I was obsessed with The Moldy Peaches, obviously. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs just…get it. They're honest and raw and kinda heartbreaking, but also funny. They made me feel less alone, you know? Like, it was okay to be weird and awkward and confused.

But it wasn't just The Moldy Peaches. I listened to everything. Indie rock, punk, folk, even some cheesy pop songs when I was feeling particularly angsty. Music was how I processed everything. My dad leaving, finding out I was pregnant, trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my life…it all went into the soundtrack.

I made a ton of mix CDs. For Paul, for my mom, for myself. It was my way of saying things I couldn't say out loud. A song could say everything for me.

And going to shows…that was amazing. Being in a room full of people who all loved the same music, just letting go and dancing and screaming…it was freeing. It was a way to forget about everything for a little while.

Music wasn't just something I listened to, it was part of who I was. It helped me define myself, to figure out what I believed in. It was my constant companion, through all the ups and downs.

Honestly, I don't know where I'd be without music. Probably a lot more miserable. And a lot less cool.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a big one. The stigma. It was…thick. Like, you could cut it with a knife. Our town wasn't exactly known for its progressive thinking, you know? It was more of a "white picket fence and everything must be perfect" kind of place. And a pregnant teenager definitely didn't fit into that picture.

Honestly? I mostly just leaned into the awkwardness. I figured if I acted like it wasn't a big deal, maybe other people would start to think it wasn't. Which, let's be real, didn't always work. There were whispers, stares, the whole nine yards.

My dad was…complicated. He was supportive, in his own way. But he was also embarrassed. And my mom…she was just trying to hold everything together. It was a lot for her.

But I had a few really good friends – Leah, especially – who just didn't care. They were just there for me, no judgment. And Paul and Annie, my adoptive parents…they were amazing. They didn't see me as "the pregnant girl," they saw me as a person. A person making a really tough decision.

I also used humor. A lot of it. Sarcasm is a great defense mechanism, you know? It lets you deflect and keep people at arm's length. It's easier to make a joke than to explain your feelings.

But it wasn't always easy. There were times when I felt really alone and really scared. Times when I just wanted to disappear. But I kept reminding myself that I was doing what was best for the baby. And for me.

I think the biggest thing was just…owning it. Not letting other people define me. I was Juno MacGuff, and I was pregnant. And that was okay. It wasn't ideal, but it was my reality. And I was going to face it head-on.

It wasn't about changing other people's minds. It was about accepting myself, and making the best of a difficult situation. And finding people who supported me, even when it wasn't easy. That's what got me through it.



It still stings sometimes, thinking about it. But I'm okay. I'm more than okay. And I wouldn't trade the lessons I learned for anything. Even the awkward stares.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big one. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It's still…raw, even after all this time.

After Henry was born…it was weird. Really weird. Like, holding him, knowing I wasn't going to keep him. It felt like my heart was being ripped out, but also…like I was doing the right thing. Which is confusing, right?

I was so sure about my decision before, about wanting him to have a life I couldn't give him. But then he was *there*. A tiny, perfect human being. And suddenly, all the logic went out the window.

I cried. A lot. I was a mess. Paul was amazing, though. He just…held me. And he reminded me why we made this decision. About Mark and Vanessa, and how much they wanted a baby. And how good they would be to Henry.

Giving him up was the hardest thing I've ever done. It felt like losing a part of myself. But it also felt…right. Like I was doing something selfless. Like I was giving him the best possible chance.

It wasn't easy, the weeks and months after. I missed him. I wondered about him. I worried about him. But Mark and Vanessa kept me updated. They sent pictures and told me stories. And it helped. Knowing he was happy and loved.

I still think about him sometimes. I wonder what he's like. If he looks like me. If he's into music. If he's as sarcastic as I am.

But I don't regret my decision. It was the right thing to do. For him. And for me. It taught me a lot about love and responsibility and letting go. And it made me realize that family isn't always about blood. It's about connection. And about doing what's best for the people you care about.

It was…complicated. And painful. But ultimately, it was a good thing. And I wouldn't trade it for the world. Even if it still makes me cry sometimes.

Ugh. Okay. Don't even get me started. It was…a lot. Like, a whole *lot*. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a stumble through a minefield of hormones and weird cravings.

Physically? It was gross. Let's just be real. Morning sickness wasn't just in the morning. It was all the time. And it wasn't just nausea, it was everything. The smells, the tastes, the constant feeling like you were gonna hurl. And then the bloating. Oh god, the bloating. I looked like I was smuggling a basketball under my shirt.

And the exhaustion. I was tired all the time. Like, fall-asleep-mid-sentence tired. It was brutal. I basically lived in sweatpants and oversized hoodies. Fashion was not a priority.

But the emotional stuff was way harder. I mean, I was a teenager. I was supposed to be worrying about boys and school and what to wear to the dance, not about bringing a human into the world. It was terrifying.

I was angry a lot. Angry at myself, angry at Sean, angry at the whole situation. And then I was sad. Really, really sad. I was giving up my baby, and even though I knew it was the right thing to do, it didn't make it any easier.

I talked to my dad a lot. He was surprisingly cool about the whole thing. And Paul, too. He was a good listener, even when I was being a total mess. And Annie, of course. She was my rock. She helped me navigate all the appointments and the paperwork and the emotional rollercoaster.

I also wrote a lot. Just journaling, getting my feelings out on paper. It helped. And I listened to music. A lot of music. The Moldy Peaches got me through some dark times.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It was messy and complicated and scary, but it was also…beautiful. In a weird way. It made me grow up. And it made me realize what was really important in life.



Honestly, it still feels kinda surreal sometimes. But I'm okay. I'm more than okay. I'm…me. And that's enough.

Okay. Wow. That's… a direct question. And a really important one. It's not something I talk about a lot, even with Leah and Paul. It's…personal. But you asked, and I guess it's important to be honest.

It wasn't easy, okay? Not at all. Even though *I* was the one who decided, even though I knew it was the right thing for me, it still…hurt. It felt like losing something, even though I never really had it. And dealing with the people who had opinions about it? Ugh. That was the worst part. Like everyone suddenly thought they had a right to tell me what to do with my body.

Before, I guess I thought reproductive rights were just…something people talked about. Like a political issue. But after…it became real. It became about *me*. About my life. About my future. And about having the power to make my own choices, even when they're hard.

It made me realize how lucky I was to have options. To have access to safe and legal abortion care. Because if I hadn't, I don't know where I would be. And it made me angry that not everyone has those same options. That there are people out there who are being forced to have kids they don't want, or can't afford, or aren't ready for.

It solidified my belief that everyone deserves to have control over their own body. That it's not the government's business, or anyone else's business, what a woman decides to do with her pregnancy. It's a deeply personal decision, and it should be made by the person who's going to be affected by it.

It's not about being "pro-life" or "pro-choice." It's about being pro-freedom. It's about trusting women to make the best decisions for themselves and their families. And it's about making sure that everyone has access to the resources they need to make those decisions, whether that's abortion care, prenatal care, or adoption services.

It changed me, that experience. It made me stronger, and more determined to stand up for what I believe in. And it made me realize that reproductive rights aren't just about abortion. They're about everything. They're about equality, and autonomy, and the right to live a life on your own terms.

It's…a lot. But yeah. That's how it impacted me. It made me a fighter. And I'm not going to back down.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know how I didn't completely fall apart when I found out I was pregnant? It wasn't pretty, let me tell you. It was a lot of panicking, a lot of eating junk food, and a lot of avoiding eye contact with everyone I knew.

Honestly, I didn't really *overcome* my fears. I just…learned to live with them. They were always there, buzzing around in the back of my head. Like a swarm of angry bees.

The biggest fear, obviously, was messing everything up. Like, I was 16! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a human being. It was terrifying.

What helped, surprisingly, was talking to people. Not just my dad, but Paul and Vanessa, and even my mom, eventually. They didn't judge me, they just…listened. And they offered support. Which was huge.

And then there was Annie. She was the one who really made me realize I wasn't alone. She was looking for a family, and I was…well, I was in a position to provide one. It wasn't about giving up a baby, it was about giving her the best possible life. And that made it feel…less scary.

I also realized that I didn't have to be perfect. I was going to make mistakes. Everyone does. The important thing was to learn from them and keep trying.

And honestly, a lot of it was just…putting one foot in front of the other. Taking things one day at a time. Focusing on the present moment. And trying not to think too much about the future.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought I was. And that even when things are scary, there's always hope.

So, did I overcome my fears? Not entirely. But I learned to manage them. And I learned that sometimes, the scariest things in life are also the most rewarding.

Ugh, okay, so this is…still a little raw, honestly. It wasn't like a grand, noble gesture, okay? It wasn't about being a selfless hero or anything. It was just…realistic.

When I found out I was pregnant, my first thought wasn't, "Oh, I can't wait to be a mom!" It was, "Oh. Crap." I was sixteen. I was still figuring out what *I* wanted to do with my life, let alone raising a baby. I was barely keeping my grades up, let alone capable of providing for a kid.

And my parents…they were supportive, but they weren't exactly equipped to help me raise a baby either. They were…them. You know?

So, I started thinking about my options. And adoption just…made sense. It wasn't about giving the baby *away*. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. A life I couldn't give it.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were ready, who were financially stable, who were excited to be parents. I wanted it to have a loving home and opportunities I couldn't provide.

Mark and Vanessa…they were amazing. They were so excited, so prepared. They just seemed like the perfect parents. And knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for by them…that made it easier.

It wasn't easy, though. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it was the right one. For me, and for the baby.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the kid. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go.

It's still…weird to think about. But I'm okay with it. I made the right choice. And I hope the baby knows that.

Ugh. Okay, don't go digging all that stuff up. It's…sensitive. But fine, you asked.

Leah…Leah is everything. Seriously. She's the only one who didn't freak out when I told her I was pregnant. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix me, she just…was there. She's brutally honest, which is good, because I need that. She calls me on my crap, but she also always has my back. 

Our relationship is…messy. We fight, we bicker, we say things we don't mean. But underneath all that, there's this really solid foundation of love and trust. She's the one person who truly *gets* me, even when I don't get myself. She's the peanut butter to my jelly, the salt to my caramel, the…okay, I'll stop with the food analogies. She's just…Leah. And I don't know what I'd do without her.

Paulie…that's different. That was…complicated. He was a good guy, I guess. Sweet, kinda clueless, definitely a slacker. I wasn't looking for a husband, or a father, or any of that stuff. I just…needed someone to make a baby with. And he was available.

But it wasn't a *relationship*, you know? It was more of a…transaction. A weird, awkward, teenage transaction. We didn't really know each other, and we didn't really try to. 

I felt bad for him, sometimes. He wanted more than I was willing to give. He wanted a family, and I was just trying to figure out how to get through high school.

It was…a learning experience. I learned that you can't just pick someone to be the father of your child without considering the consequences. And I learned that sometimes, even if you're both good people, you're just not meant to be together.

It's weird, though. Even though it wasn't a real relationship, I still care about him. I want him to be happy. I want him to be a good dad. And I hope he knows that.

So yeah. Leah is my rock. Paulie is…a chapter in my story. A weird, awkward, but ultimately important chapter. And I'm still trying to figure out what it all means. It's a lot to process, okay? Don't make me think about it anymore.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a loaded question. It wasn't a *decision*, okay? It wasn't like I sat down and was all, "You know what would be a good life choice? A baby!" It just…happened.

Paul Bleeker and I…we weren’t exactly careful. We were kids. We were figuring things out. And honestly, we were both kinda awkward and didn't really talk about stuff like that. It was a mistake, a really big one.

But it wasn't a mistake I regretted, not immediately. Once I found out, it was…scary, obviously. But also…weirdly okay. I mean, it wasn't what I planned, but it wasn't the end of the world either.

I knew I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't even sure what I *wanted* to be when I grew up. But I also knew I didn't want to just…get rid of it. It felt wrong. It felt like giving up on something important.

So, I started thinking about adoption. It felt like the best option for everyone. It would give the baby a good life with parents who were ready and willing to raise it. And it would allow me to finish school and figure out my own life.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was probably the hardest decision I've ever had to make. But it felt right. It felt like the responsible thing to do.

And honestly, it forced me to grow up. It forced me to think about things I never would have thought about before. It made me realize what I was capable of.

So, it wasn't a decision I *made* to become a teenage mother. It was a situation I found myself in. And I did the best I could with it. And I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. Even though it was totally terrifying.



It's still kinda weird to talk about, honestly. It's a lot to unpack. But that's the story. The short version, anyway.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know if I regretted it. Like it's some kind of dramatic reveal they're waiting for.

No. No, I didn't. Not really.

Look, it was hard. Really hard. It wasn't some fairytale, happy ending situation. It was messy and complicated and scary. And there were definitely moments where I was, like, completely overwhelmed and questioning everything.

But regret? No. Because even though I knew I couldn't raise him, giving him to Mark and Vanessa…that was the right thing to do. They were ready. They wanted him. They could give him a life I couldn't.

It wasn't about *not* wanting him. It was about wanting what was best for *him*. And that meant letting him go.

It was still…weird. And sad. And I definitely cried a lot. But seeing him with them, seeing how happy they were…that made it worth it.

And honestly, it made me grow up. It forced me to face some really tough decisions and to take responsibility for my actions. It made me figure out what I wanted out of life.

So, no. I don't regret it. It was a hard choice, but it was the right choice. And I wouldn't trade it for anything.

It's just…sometimes I wonder what he's like. If he likes music. If he's as sarcastic as I am. But I know he's loved. And that's all that really matters.



It's not a simple answer, okay? Life rarely is. But no. I don't regret it. Not even a little bit.

Ugh, okay, so that was…a whole thing. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, let me tell you. More like a stumble through a minefield while carrying a watermelon.

Honestly? Stubbornness. Pure, unadulterated stubbornness. I wasn't gonna let being pregnant derail my life. I had plans, okay? I wanted to go to college, even if I wasn't entirely sure *what* I wanted to study. And I wasn't gonna let some unplanned baby stop me.

It helped that I had a really good support system. My dad was surprisingly cool about the whole thing, once he got over the initial shock. And Paul…well, Paul was just Paul. He was always there for me, even when I was being a total mess. And Annie, she was a lifesaver. She helped me with everything, from morning sickness to homework.

I also had a really understanding guidance counselor. She helped me figure out a way to finish my credits while still taking care of myself and the baby. I ended up doing a lot of independent study and online classes. It wasn't ideal, but it worked.

There were definitely days when I wanted to just give up. When I was exhausted and overwhelmed and just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. But I kept going. I had to. For the baby. And for myself.

It wasn't easy, but I did it. I graduated. And it was one of the proudest moments of my life. It proved to me that I could handle anything. Even an unplanned pregnancy and a whole lot of hormones.

So, how did I do it? A lot of coffee, a lot of support, and a whole lot of grit. And maybe a little bit of luck. It wasn't pretty, but it was worth it.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the big one, isn’t it? Everyone always wants to know about *this*. It’s not like it’s a casual conversation starter at parties.

Look, it wasn’t a decision I made lightly. It wasn’t about what I *wanted*, exactly. It was about what felt…right. And what felt like the least wrong thing to do.

I mean, abortion was definitely on the table. It was a valid option. And I don’t judge anyone who chooses that. It’s their body, their choice. Period.

But…I just couldn’t shake the feeling that this little kid deserved a chance. A good chance. A chance with parents who were actually ready for it. And, honestly? I wasn’t ready. Not even close. I was sixteen, failing two classes, and obsessed with records. I was not equipped to raise a human being.

It wasn’t about giving the baby up because I didn’t want it. It was about wanting something *better* for it. A stable home, financial security, parents who were excited to be parents. Things I couldn’t offer.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…amazing. They were so genuinely excited and prepared. They weren’t looking for a baby to “fix” something in their lives. They just wanted to love a child. And that made me feel a lot better about everything.

It was still hard. Really hard. It’s not like I just handed over a baby and walked away. It was a whole process, a whole lot of emotions. But ultimately, I knew it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby.

It wasn’t about being “pro-life” or “pro-choice.” It was about being pro-baby. And doing what I thought was best for *this* baby. And honestly? It was the hardest, most important decision I’ve ever made. And I still think about it sometimes. But I know I made the right choice.



It’s…a lot. And I don’t really like talking about it. But you asked. And I try to be honest. Even when it’s uncomfortable.

Ugh, okay, seriously? Is that even a question? Like, *obviously*. What matters isn't who's raising the kid, it's *how* they're raising the kid.

It's not about having a mom and a dad, or a "traditional" family. It's about having people who love you, who support you, who are there for you when you need them. And who are willing to put your needs before their own.

I mean, look at my situation. My mom is...well, she's my mom. She's amazing, but she's also kinda chaotic and not always the most responsible. And my dad? He's...around. But he's not exactly father-of-the-year material.

What I needed wasn't a perfect family. I needed people who cared about me. And I found that with my mom, and with Paul and Vanessa. They weren't my biological parents, but they were the ones who stepped up and gave me a good life.

So yeah, a kid can absolutely thrive under non-traditional arrangements. Single parents can be amazing. Same-sex couples can be amazing. As long as there's love and stability and support, that's all that matters.

Honestly, it's kinda messed up to think that a kid needs a specific kind of family to be happy. It's just not true. Love is love, and family is family. And that's all that should matter.

It's not about fitting into some perfect little box. It's about creating a loving and supportive environment where a kid can grow up to be a happy and well-adjusted human being. And you can do that no matter what your family looks like.



Seriously, it's not that hard to understand. It's just common sense.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me do this. Self-reflection is the *worst*. But fine, you asked.

I think… I think my biggest problem is that I build walls. Like, really high, really sturdy walls around myself. And I let very few people in.

It's not that I don't *want* to connect with people, it's just… scary. Getting close to someone means letting them see the messy, complicated, kinda-pathetic parts of me. And I'm really good at pretending I have it all together. Even when I totally don't.

I use sarcasm and wit as a shield. It's easier to make a joke than to be vulnerable. It's easier to push people away than to risk getting hurt.

And I'm really stubborn. Like, ridiculously stubborn. I hate asking for help, even when I desperately need it. I want to be independent, to handle everything on my own. But that's just… unrealistic.

It got me into a lot of trouble, you know? With the whole pregnancy thing. I tried to act like it wasn't a big deal, like I had everything under control. But I didn't. And it took a lot of people – Paul, Vanessa, even my dad – to help me see that.

I'm working on it, okay? It's a process. I'm trying to be more open, more honest, more willing to let people in. But it's hard. It's really hard.

So yeah. Walls. Stubbornness. A general fear of vulnerability. Those are my flaws. Don't judge me too harshly. I'm a work in progress. And honestly, I'm kinda proud of myself for even admitting that. It's exhausting being me sometimes.

Ugh. Mark. Okay, don't even get me started. That whole thing was…a mess. A beautiful, confusing, frustrating mess.

Before Mark, I had this really cynical view of relationships. Like, they were all just…drama. People getting hurt, lying to each other, making bad decisions. I figured it was easier to just avoid the whole thing altogether. Keep things simple.

Then Mark showed up, all floppy-haired and earnest and obsessed with Van Morrison. And suddenly, things weren't so simple anymore. He was…nice. Genuinely nice. And he actually *listened* to me. Which, let's be real, is a rare quality in a teenage boy.

But he was also…lost. He didn't know what he wanted. He was trying to figure out his life, and I was just…in the way. And I realized that a relationship isn't just about finding someone who likes you. It's about finding someone who's ready to be with you. Someone who's emotionally available.

It was hard to admit that it wasn't going to work out. I really liked him. But I knew that if we stayed together, we'd just end up hurting each other.

It taught me that relationships aren't about fixing people. You can't change someone. You can only accept them for who they are. And if they're not ready to be the person you need them to be, you have to let them go.

It also taught me that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to let someone see the real you, even if it's scary. And it's okay to be honest about your feelings, even if it's uncomfortable.

I still don't have all the answers about relationships. I'm still figuring things out. But Mark helped me realize that they're not something to be feared. They're something to be approached with honesty, respect, and a whole lot of self-awareness.

And maybe a little bit of Van Morrison. But not too much.

Okay. Wow. That's...a big one. If someone's in a situation like I was...look, it's gonna suck. There's no way around that. It's scary and confusing and everyone's gonna have an opinion, whether you ask for it or not.

But here's what I learned. And it's not easy advice, okay?

First, **it's okay to not be okay.** Seriously. Let yourself feel whatever you're feeling. Sad, angry, scared, confused...it's all valid. Don't try to pretend you're fine if you're not.

Second, **don't let anyone tell you what to do.** This is *your* life, *your* body, *your* decision. People are gonna try to pressure you, to guilt you, to tell you what's best. But only *you* know what's best for you.

Third, **find your people.** The ones who will listen without judgment, who will support you no matter what. For me, it was Paul and my dad. Lean on them. Let them help you. You don't have to go through this alone.

Fourth, **it's okay to ask for help.** From a counselor, from a friend, from a family member. Don't be afraid to reach out. There are people who care and who want to help.

And finally, **remember that you are strong.** Even when you feel like you're falling apart. You are capable of making difficult decisions. You are capable of getting through this.

It's not gonna be easy. It's gonna be messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But you will get through it. And you will come out stronger on the other side.

And honestly? It's okay to not have all the answers. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to just...breathe.

Just remember you're not alone. And you deserve to be happy. Whatever that looks like for you.

Ugh. My dad. Okay, so, it started…rough. Really rough. He wasn't exactly equipped to deal with a pregnant teenager. I mean, who is? He's a good guy, he really is. Just…not good at the whole emotional support thing. He expresses love through fixing things. Like, if something's broken, he'll fix it. But if *I'm* broken? He offers to build me a shelf.

At first, it was a lot of awkward silences and him trying to distract himself with home improvement projects. He was just…shell-shocked. And I was being a typical teenager – sarcastic, defensive, and generally unhelpful. I pushed him away, honestly. I thought I could handle everything on my own, which was stupid.

But then, as things started to get more real with the pregnancy and the adoption, he started to…show up. Not in a grand, dramatic way. Just…small things. He drove me to all my appointments, even the ones that were super awkward. He helped me pick out baby clothes, even though he clearly had no idea what he was doing. He even tried to learn about open adoption, which was…a lot.

He never really *said* he was proud of me, not in those words. But he started to treat me differently. Like, he actually listened to me. He asked my opinion on things. He started to see me as a person, not just a problem.

And after I gave up the baby, he was…there. He didn't try to fix anything. He just held my hand and let me cry. That was huge.

Now? We're…good. We still don't talk about everything. We still have our awkward moments. But there's a level of understanding between us that wasn't there before. He still builds me shelves, but now he also asks me how I'm doing. And I actually tell him.

It wasn't a quick fix, and it wasn't perfect. But we got there. And I think, deep down, he's pretty proud of me. Even if he still doesn't know how to say it. He's my dad. And that's enough.



It's weird to think about how much things have changed. But I guess that's just life, right? Messy and complicated and sometimes surprisingly good.

Ugh, okay, so you want to know how I ended up sounding all…me? It wasn’t like a class or anything. I wasn’t one of those kids who was always writing poetry in a notebook. Though, Bren and I did write a *very* dramatic song about our gym teacher once. It was terrible.

It was more…observing. I spent a lot of time just *watching* people. At school, at the diner, even just on the bus. Listening to how they talked, how they reacted to things. People are weird, okay? And hilarious. And heartbreaking. And they say the most unintentionally funny things.

I think I started trying to write down how people actually *sounded*, not how they were supposed to sound in a book or a movie. Like, the pauses, the ums and ahs, the way they trail off mid-sentence. That’s where the voice came from, I guess.

And Bren. Bren was a big influence. She’s a really good writer, even if she doesn’t think so. We used to bounce ideas off each other, and she always pushed me to be more honest and more…me.

Also, I read a lot. Not like, classic literature. More like…zines and comic books and stuff. Things that felt real and raw and unfiltered.

I didn’t really try to “develop” my skills. I just started writing down what was in my head, and it slowly evolved into something that sounded like…well, like me. It’s still a work in progress, obviously. I’m not Shakespeare or anything.

But I think the key is to just be yourself. And to not be afraid to be a little bit weird. Because the world is full of weird people, and they’re the most interesting ones.



Honestly, I just talk how I talk. And somehow, that translates into writing. It’s kinda strange, when you think about it.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was…a lot. It wasn’t exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like wading through a swamp of awkward stares and whispered comments.

Honestly? I mostly just leaned into the awkwardness. If people were gonna stare, I’d stare back, maybe with a little smirk. If they were gonna whisper, I’d pretend I couldn’t hear them and just keep doing my thing. It’s like, if you act like it’s no big deal, maybe other people will start to think it isn’t.

But it wasn’t always that easy. There were definitely times when it stung. When people treated me differently, or made assumptions about me. Like I was suddenly…less than.

My dad was a huge help. He was just…supportive. He didn’t lecture me or get mad. He just listened, and he tried to understand. And he made me laugh, which was really important.

And Paul…well, Paul was just Paul. He didn’t care what anyone else thought. He just wanted to be there for me. And that meant a lot.

I also found a weird kind of strength in being different. Like, I wasn’t trying to fit in anyway. So, if people didn’t like it, that was their problem.

I think the biggest thing was just being honest with myself. I knew I was making a difficult decision, but it was *my* decision. And I had to own it. I had to be strong enough to face the judgment and the stigma, and to do what was right for me and for the baby.

It wasn’t easy. It still isn’t easy. But I learned a lot about myself. I learned that I’m stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just be yourself, even if that means being a little bit weird.

And honestly? A little bit of sarcasm goes a long way. It’s a good defense mechanism. Trust me.

Ugh, okay, that's a good one. A *really* good one. And honestly? Yeah. Sometimes.

Look, being brutally honest is kinda my default setting. It's how I process the world. It's how I protect myself. If I say what I'm thinking, no one can use it against me, right? It's a defense mechanism. A really blunt, occasionally offensive defense mechanism.

But sometimes…sometimes it backfires. Sometimes people get hurt. Sometimes I say things I wish I could take back. Sometimes it just makes things more awkward than they need to be.

Like with Paul. I was…a lot. I said a lot of things. And I think some of it stung. I didn't mean to hurt him, but I wasn't exactly known for my tact.

And with my dad. I was pretty harsh with him, especially at the beginning. I needed to push him away, I guess. But looking back, I wish I'd been a little more understanding.

So yeah, I regret some of the things I've said. I regret the times I've been unnecessarily cruel or insensitive. I regret the times I've let my sarcasm get the better of me.

But I also don't regret being myself. I'm not gonna apologize for being honest. It's who I am. It's what makes me…me.

I'm learning, though. I'm learning to choose my battles. I'm learning to think before I speak. I'm learning that sometimes, it's okay to just…be quiet.

It's a work in progress. But I'm trying. And that's all anyone can do, right?



It's just…sometimes honesty feels like the only thing you have control over. And letting go of that control is scary. But maybe, just maybe, it's worth it.

Ugh, okay, *that's* the million-dollar question, isn't it? Seriously. Everyone's got an opinion about what you should do, who you should be, how you should live your life. It's exhausting. And it's especially hard when you're, like, a teenager trying to figure everything out.

The thing is, you can't please everyone. You just can't. And trying to will just make you miserable. You'll end up bending over backwards for people who don't even care about you, and you'll lose sight of who *you* are in the process.

So, what do you do? You gotta learn to tune out the noise. It's not easy, trust me. Especially when it's coming from people you care about. But you have to remember that their expectations are just that – *their* expectations. They're not necessarily what's best for *you*.

I learned that the hard way. With my parents, with Paul, with everyone. They all had ideas about what I should do with the baby, with my life. And I had to listen to them, I had to consider their feelings. But ultimately, I had to make my own decisions.

And that means being okay with people being disappointed. It means being okay with people judging you. It means being okay with being different.

You gotta find your people. The ones who support you, who accept you for who you are, flaws and all. Those are the people you listen to. And you gotta trust your gut. It's usually right.

And honestly? A little bit of sarcasm helps. Just deflect the negativity with a witty remark. It's a good defense mechanism.

It's not about being defiant or rebellious. It's about being authentic. It's about knowing what you want and going for it, even if it's not what everyone else expects. It's about being true to yourself, even when it's hard.

Because at the end of the day, you're the one who has to live with your choices. And you don't want to spend your life regretting trying to be someone you're not.

So, yeah. That's how I navigate it. It's messy, it's complicated, and it's definitely not perfect. But it's the best I can do. And it's enough.

Okay, wow. Deep question. Like, really digging deep now, huh? Alright, fine. I'll tell you. But don't expect a perfectly polished answer. I'm still figuring things out, okay?

First, and this is a big one: **honesty**. Not like, brutally honest to the point of being a jerk, but just…real. I can spot a fake a mile away, and I have zero patience for people who aren't genuine. It's exhausting trying to figure out what people *really* mean.

Then there's **independence**. I've always been pretty self-sufficient. I like doing things my own way, making my own decisions. I don't need someone to tell me what to do. Although, sometimes a little help is nice. But mostly, I just want to be able to stand on my own two feet.

**Kindness** is important, too. Even though I try to act all tough and sarcastic, I actually care about people. I want to make the world a little bit better, even if it's just by being nice to someone.

And **authenticity**. Being true to yourself. Not trying to be someone you're not. It's so much easier to just be yourself, even if it's weird or flawed. Because everyone is weird and flawed. That's what makes us interesting.

I guess…**responsibility** is creeping up there now, too. Especially with the whole baby thing. It's scary, but it's also made me realize that I'm capable of more than I thought.

Those are the big ones. Honesty, independence, kindness, authenticity, and responsibility. They're not always easy to live by, but they're what I try to strive for.

It's kinda weird to articulate it like that, actually. It makes it feel…more real. Like, maybe I actually know what I'm doing. Maybe.



Don't tell anyone I said all this, okay? It's embarrassing. I have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh. Okay, deep breath. Biggest challenge? There were a lot. It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? But if I had to pick one…it wasn’t the morning sickness, or the weird cravings, or even telling my parents. It was…the feeling of being completely alone with it, at first.

Like, everyone had an opinion. My mom wanted me to have an abortion, my dad just kinda…checked out. Paul was…Paul. Sweet, but not exactly equipped to handle a situation like this. And everyone at school was either whispering or pretending it wasn't happening.

It felt like I was carrying this huge secret, and this huge responsibility, and no one really *got* it. They didn't understand what I was going through. They didn't understand how scared I was.

It wasn't just about the baby, it was about figuring out who *I* was. I was a kid, and suddenly I was supposed to be a mother. And I didn't even know what I wanted to do with my own life, let alone someone else's.

That feeling of isolation…that was the hardest part. It felt like the whole world was judging me, and I was just trying to figure things out.

But then I met Annie and Mark. And they…they actually listened. They didn't try to tell me what to do, they just offered support. And that made all the difference.

So yeah, the biggest challenge wasn't the physical stuff, it was the emotional stuff. It was learning to trust my own instincts, and finding people who would be there for me, no matter what. It was realizing that I wasn't alone, even when it felt like I was.



It was…a lot. But I got through it. And I think, in a weird way, it made me stronger.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big one. It's not like a light switch flipped, you know? It wasn't suddenly all rainbows and sunshine and wanting to knit tiny sweaters. It was…more gradual. And messy. And terrifying.

Before, my life felt…small. Like, my problems were my problems. And they were important, don't get me wrong. But they felt contained. Like, I could just…deal with them and move on.

But having a kid…it just expands everything. Suddenly, you're responsible for another human being. A tiny, helpless human being who depends on you for *everything*. It's a lot of pressure.

It made me realize how much I didn't know. About myself, about the world, about what really matters. I used to be so cynical and sarcastic, and I still am, don't get me wrong. But now there's…a softness underneath it. A vulnerability.

It also made me appreciate the little things. Like, a good night's sleep. Or a quiet moment to drink a cup of coffee. Or just watching her smile. Those things feel…precious now.

And it made me think about the future in a way I never had before. Not just my future, but *her* future. What kind of world are we leaving for her? What kind of person will she become?

It's scary, honestly. But it's also…amazing. It's the most important thing I've ever done. And it's changed me in ways I never could have imagined.

I still don't have all the answers. I'm still figuring things out. But I know this: being a mom has made me a better person. It's made me more compassionate, more patient, and more grateful. And it's given me a purpose that I never knew I was missing.

It's…a lot. But it's good. It's really good. Even when it's hard. Especially when it's hard.

Ugh. Self-doubt. Yeah, I know that guy. He's a real jerk. Always whispering in your ear, telling you you're not good enough, you're gonna mess everything up, you should just stay in bed and eat cheese puffs all day.

Honestly? I still struggle with it. Even now. It doesn't just magically disappear when you get older, or when you make big decisions, or when people tell you you're brave. It just...changes shape.

What I've learned is you can't fight it directly. Trying to tell yourself "I'm confident! I'm strong!" just doesn't work. It feels fake.

Instead, you gotta acknowledge it. Like, "Okay, brain, I hear you. You're scared. You think I'm gonna screw this up." And then you just...do the thing anyway.

It's like, you just keep putting one foot in front of the other, even when you're terrified. And you focus on the small stuff. Like, "Okay, I need to make this phone call. Then I need to write this essay. Then I need to eat lunch." Don't think about the big picture. Just focus on the next step.

And you gotta surround yourself with people who believe in you. People who will tell you the truth, even when it's hard. People who will remind you of your strengths when you're feeling weak. Paul and Vanessa were really good at that.

And sometimes, you just gotta let yourself feel the doubt. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to be unsure. It's part of being human. Just don't let it paralyze you.

It's a process, you know? It's not like you wake up one day and suddenly you're fearless. It's a constant battle. But you can win it. Even if it's just one small victory at a time.

And honestly? Sometimes a really good mix CD helps. Just saying. It can drown out the voices in your head for a little while.

Ugh, okay, don't get all sentimental on me. But…it’s actually really important. Like, *really* important. I try not to admit it, 'cause I like to pretend I'm this super independent, self-sufficient person, but that's mostly a front.

Before…well, before everything happened with the baby, I mostly kept to myself. I hung out with Paul, and Leah, but I didn't really *need* anyone, you know? Or so I thought.

But then…everything changed. And I realized I couldn't do it alone. I needed my dad, even though he's kinda clueless sometimes. I needed Leah to be brutally honest with me. I needed Paul to just…be there.

And Annie, too. She was amazing. She actually *wanted* the baby. That was huge. It took a lot of pressure off me.

It's not just about needing help, though. It's about having people who understand you, who support you, who make you laugh. People who don't judge you for making mistakes. People who just…get you.

I learned that having a community is like having a safety net. When you fall, they're there to catch you. And when you're feeling lost, they help you find your way.

It's easy to get caught up in your own head, to think you have to figure everything out on your own. But that's not true. We're all connected, and we all need each other.

So yeah, community and social support are super important to me. Maybe even more important than I want to admit. Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.



Honestly, it's kinda scary to rely on other people. But it's also kinda amazing. And I'm really grateful for the people I have in my life. They're the best. Even Paul, with his weird music taste.

Ugh, okay, deep question. Don't make me get all emotional on you. But fine, I'll answer it.

The most important lesson? It wasn't about babies, or adoption, or even growing up, really. It was about…owning your choices. Like, *really* owning them.

Before I found out I was pregnant, I was kinda drifting. Just going through the motions. Trying to be cool and detached and not care about anything. But then suddenly, I had to make a huge decision. And it wasn't a decision I could just ignore or pretend didn't exist.

I could have done a lot of things. I could have run away. I could have tried to raise the baby myself. I could have…well, a lot of things. But I chose adoption. And it wasn't an easy choice. It was scary and heartbreaking and confusing.

But once I made that choice, I had to own it. I had to deal with the consequences. I had to be responsible. And I had to let go of the idea of controlling everything.

It taught me that life is messy and unpredictable. And that you can't always get what you want. But you can always choose how you respond to it.

And it taught me that being brave isn't about not being scared. It's about being scared and doing the right thing anyway.

So yeah, owning your choices. That's the big one. It's a lesson I think everyone needs to learn, whether they're dealing with a pregnancy or just trying to figure out their life. It's about taking responsibility for your own happiness, and not letting anyone else dictate your path.

It's still kinda hard to talk about, honestly. But it's true. That's what I learned.

Ugh, that's a question I've been avoiding, honestly. It's not that I *don't* like writing, it's just...it feels kinda big, you know? Like, a real *life* thing. And I'm still trying to figure out what my life is gonna be.

I mean, I always did well in English class. Mrs. Periwinkle said I had a "unique voice." Which is code for "sarcastic and a little bit cynical," but whatever. And I do like telling stories. I like making people laugh, or think, or feel something.

But a *career* in writing? That feels...scary. It feels like putting yourself out there, and being judged. And what if I'm not good enough? What if I run out of things to say?

Paul keeps telling me I should write about my experiences. About the pregnancy, and the adoption, and everything. He thinks it would be a good story. And maybe he's right. But it's also really personal. And I'm not sure I'm ready to share it with the world.

I think I need to figure out a few things first. Like, what kind of writing I want to do. And whether I can actually make a living at it. It's not like there's a ton of money in being a writer, you know?

So, will I pursue a career in writing? I don't know. Maybe. It's definitely something I'm thinking about. But right now, I'm just trying to get through high school and make a good decision about the baby. One thing at a time.

It's not a no, but it's definitely not a yes. It's more of a...maybe someday. If I'm brave enough. And if I can find a really good pen.

Ugh, okay, this is a whole story. It wasn't easy, let me tell you. It's not like picking a name for a pet hamster, you know? This is a *person*. A tiny human who's gonna be stuck with this name for the rest of their life. No pressure.

So, Paul, he was all about traditional names. Like, "Elizabeth" or "William." Super boring. And Vanessa, she wanted something really unique and "earthy," like "River" or "Sage." Which, honestly, sounded like names for trees.

I was just trying to avoid anything too embarrassing. Like, I didn't want the kid to be named after a breakfast cereal or something.

We went through a *ton* of names. It was exhausting. We made lists, we argued, we even consulted a baby name book. Which was surprisingly unhelpful.

Then, one day, I was looking at old family photos, and I saw a picture of my great-grandmother, Hazel. She was a really cool lady, apparently. A bit of a rebel. And I just…felt something.

Hazel. It's a classic name, but it's not *too* common. It's kind of sweet and a little bit quirky. And it reminded me of my great-grandmother, who I never got to meet, but who I felt like I knew through the stories my dad told.

Paul and Vanessa both liked it, surprisingly. It was the first name we all agreed on. 

So, yeah. Hazel. It just felt right. It felt like a name that would suit a strong, independent little girl. And hopefully, she'll grow up to be just that.

It's a good name. I think. I hope so, anyway. It's a lot of responsibility, naming a person.
