Ugh. Okay. That's...a big one. It wasn't a rollercoaster, it was more like a Tilt-A-Whirl that was actively trying to throw me off. And succeeding, a lot of the time.

Honestly? I didn't cope *well* at first. I was good at being sarcastic and pretending I didn't care, but underneath all that, I was a mess. I mean, I was giving away my baby. My *baby*. That's not exactly a walk in the park.

There were days I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. And I did, a lot. Especially after meeting Mark and Vanessa. They were amazing, don't get me wrong. Perfect, even. And that made it *harder*. Because they were going to be such good parents, and I knew I wasn't ready to be one.

I talked to Paul, a lot. He was the only one who really understood. He didn't try to fix things or tell me what to do, he just listened. And he let me be angry and sad and confused.

And then there was my dad. He was...quiet about it. But he was there. He made me pancakes when I couldn't get out of bed. He just...showed up.

I also started writing things down. Just random thoughts and feelings. It helped to get it all out of my head. And I listened to a lot of music. The Moldy Peaches, mostly. They're good for wallowing.

The hardest part was letting go. Actually handing the baby over to Mark and Vanessa. It felt like...giving away a piece of myself. But I knew it was the right thing to do. I wanted my baby to have a good life, and they could give her that.

It didn't magically get easier after that. There were still moments of sadness and regret. But I started to realize that giving her up didn't mean I didn't love her. It meant I loved her enough to want the best for her.

It was messy and complicated and painful. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I was stronger than I thought. And I learned that sometimes, the hardest decisions are the right ones.

It still stings sometimes, you know? But I'm okay. I think. Mostly. It's a process. And it's not something you just "get over." It's something you learn to live with.

Okay, so music. This is important. It's, like, a lifeline, you know? Especially when you're dealing with…stuff.

I'm not really into mainstream stuff. Top 40 is just…noise. I need something with substance. Something real.

I'm a huge fan of **The Moldy Peaches**, obviously. Kimya Dawson is a genius. Her songs are funny and sad and honest all at the same time. They just *get* me.

I also like **Neutral Milk Hotel**. They're kinda weird and experimental, but their music is really beautiful. It makes me feel things.

And **Belle and Sebastian**. They're all indie-pop and melancholy and perfect for rainy days.

I listen to a lot of **punk rock** too. Not the super aggressive stuff, but more like…the melodic kind. Saves the Day, The Get Up Kids, that sort of thing. It's good for when I'm feeling angry or frustrated.

Oh! And **Death Cab for Cutie**. Ben Gibbard is a lyrical master. He can make even the most mundane things sound poetic.

Basically, I like music that's honest and authentic. Music that makes me think and feel. Music that doesn't try to be something it's not.

I'm not really into labels, though. I just like good music. Whatever genre it is. As long as it's real.

So yeah. That's my playlist in a nutshell. It's a little bit eclectic, but it reflects my personality. Which is also a little bit eclectic.



Don't judge me. My taste in music is my business. And it's a pretty good business, if you ask me.

Ugh, okay, that's a good question. A *real* question. It wasn't...easy.

When I went to visit Mark and Vanessa Loring, their house was...perfect. Like, magazine-perfect. Everything was beige and organized and smelled faintly of potpourri. It was the opposite of my house, which is, let's be honest, a controlled chaos of records and mismatched furniture.

And they were...perfect too. Mark was super nice and quiet, and Vanessa was all organic food and yoga and talking about "energy." It was a little overwhelming. They had a golden retriever named Comet, which was cute, but also kinda intimidating. Comet was *very* well-behaved.

It wasn't that I didn't *like* them. They were nice people. Really nice people. But it felt…different. Like I was stepping into a different world. A world where everything was calm and predictable and…boring.

I remember thinking, "This is where the baby is going to live." And it was a good house, a good life. But it wasn't *my* life. It wasn't the kind of life I knew.

I was worried the baby wouldn't get enough dirt under its fingernails, you know? That it would grow up too…polished. Too perfect.

But then I started to realize that "perfect" isn't necessarily a bad thing. And that the baby deserved a stable, loving home, even if it wasn't a chaotic, record-filled one.

It was a weird feeling. Relief, and sadness, and a little bit of jealousy, all mixed together. It was a reminder that this wasn't about me. It was about doing what was best for the baby.

So, yeah. Their house was nice. Their lifestyle was nice. It just wasn't *my* nice. And that was okay. It had to be.

Ugh, okay, so the band. That was…a whole thing. It wasn't like I woke up one day and was all, "I must start a garage band!" It was more of a desperate attempt to impress a boy, if I'm being honest. Don't judge. We all do stupid things for love.

Paulie Bleeker. He was…cute. And he played guitar. And he was into music. And I was…not into much of anything except avoiding responsibility and eating tater tots. So I figured, maybe if I pretended to be into music too, he'd notice me.

I'd never played an instrument in my life. I can barely carry a tune. But I figured, how hard could it be? I mean, people do it all the time, right?

So I asked Lolly and Renee if they wanted to start a band with me. Lolly was all in, because she's always up for anything. And Renee was hesitant, but she agreed because she's a good friend and she knew I was trying to impress Paulie.

We didn't really have a plan. We just started messing around with instruments in my garage. It sounded terrible. Like, *really* terrible. But we kept at it. And eventually, we started to sound…less terrible.

We called ourselves "The Cute Emergency." It was Lolly's idea. I thought it was kinda dumb, but it stuck.

It wasn't about the music, really. It was about spending time with my friends and trying to figure out who I was. And, okay, maybe a little bit about impressing Paulie. But mostly it was about just…being. And making something together.

It was messy and chaotic and imperfect. But it was *ours*. And that's what mattered.



Honestly, looking back, it was kinda ridiculous. But it was also kinda amazing. And it taught me a lot about myself. And about the power of friendship. And about the fact that sometimes, the best things in life are the things you never planned.

Okay. Wow. That's…a big one. And honestly? It's scary. It really is. But you asked, and I remember what it was like, so I'll try to be real.

First of all: it's okay to be freaking out. It's okay to be scared. It's okay to cry. It's okay to feel *all* the things. Don't let anyone tell you how you're supposed to feel.

Second: you are not alone. Even if it feels like it, there are people who care about you and want to help. Talk to someone you trust. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher…anyone. Don't try to go through this by yourself.

Third: you have options. And they're all valid. You can choose to parent, you can choose to adopt, you can choose to have an abortion. It's your body, your life, and your decision. Don't let anyone pressure you into doing something you're not comfortable with.

Fourth: it's going to be hard. Really hard. But you are stronger than you think. You're going to learn a lot about yourself, and you're going to grow as a person.

Fifth: don't let this define you. You are more than just a pregnant teenager. You have dreams, you have talents, you have a future. Don't give up on those things.

And finally: be kind to yourself. You're going through a lot. Take care of yourself, both physically and emotionally. And remember that you deserve happiness.

It's not going to be easy, but you can get through this. I did. And so can you. It's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be scared. And it's okay to make the decision that's right for *you*.

Seriously. You've got this. Even when you don't feel like you do. You really do. And if you ever just need someone to talk to, even a weird, sarcastic teenager from a movie…well, I'm here. Sort of.

Okay, okay, this is a good question. Finally, something I can actually answer without getting all philosophical.

My favorite shirt? It's this faded, kinda olive green army surplus thing. It's super soft because it's been washed a million times. It's got a couple of little holes in the elbows, but I don't care. It's comfortable, okay? That's the main thing.

It's not, like, a *fashion* statement. It's just...my shirt. I got it at this thrift store a while ago, and it just felt right. It's the perfect shirt for, like, hanging out, listening to music, and avoiding people.

It's kinda baggy, and I usually wear it with jeans and Converse. It's not trying to be anything it's not. It's just a shirt.

I have a lot of band t-shirts, too, but they're mostly for showing off. This one is just...me. It's the shirt I wear when I want to feel comfortable and invisible.

It smells faintly of old books and maybe a little bit of pizza. Don't judge. It's a good smell.

So yeah. Faded olive green army surplus shirt. It's not much, but it's mine. And I like it. A lot.

Ugh, aspirations. That's a big word. Honestly, for a long time, I didn't really think about the future. It felt…too far away. And kinda scary. Like, what if I messed everything up?

But things are changing, I guess. Having a baby…it makes you think about stuff. About what kind of person you want to be, and what kind of world you want your kid to grow up in.

I don't have some grand plan, okay? I'm not gonna be a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. I'm not really a "career" person. I just want to be…okay. I want to be happy. And I want to be able to support myself.

I've been thinking about maybe going to community college. Taking some classes. I don't know what I'd study, maybe something creative. Writing, maybe. Or music. I like music.

I also want to travel. See the world. Get out of this town. I want to experience new things and meet new people.

But mostly, I just want to be a good mom. That's the biggest thing. I want to give my baby a good life. A stable life. A loving life.

It's kinda terrifying, honestly. Being a mom is a huge responsibility. But it's also…exciting. And I think I'm ready for it. Or at least, I'm gonna try to be.

So, yeah. Those are my aspirations. They're not very glamorous, but they're mine. And that's what matters, right? Just figuring things out as you go along. And hoping for the best.



It's still kinda fuzzy, though. I'm still figuring it all out. But that's okay. I don't have to have all the answers right now. I just have to keep moving forward. One step at a time.

Ugh, the counseling. Okay, don't even get me started. It wasn't *bad*, exactly. It was just…a lot. And awkward. And involved a lot of talking about feelings, which, as you know, isn't exactly my forte.

It was mostly with this woman, Dr. Shellstrop. She was nice enough, I guess. But she kept asking me these really intense questions, like, "How do you envision your future?" and "Are you prepared for the emotional toll of this?" And I was just sitting there thinking, "I'm sixteen! I barely know what I'm having for dinner, let alone my entire life plan!"

It felt like she was trying to make me feel guilty, you know? Like I wasn't thinking this through enough. But I *was* thinking it through! I just wasn't expressing it in a way she understood. I'm not exactly good at the whole "vulnerability" thing.

And then there was the stuff with Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were going to adopt the baby. We had to have all these meetings with them, and talk about everything. It was weirdly intimate, and also kinda stressful. I wanted them to like me, but I also didn't want them to think I was just giving their baby away on a whim.

Honestly, it felt like everyone was trying to tell me what to feel. And I just wanted them to let me figure it out on my own.

But, I guess it was helpful, in a way. It made me think about things I hadn't considered before. And it helped me realize that I wasn't alone. There were other people who had gone through this, and they had survived.

So, yeah. The counseling was…an experience. It wasn't my favorite part of the whole process, but I'm glad I did it. Even if it meant having to talk about my feelings for hours on end. It's exhausting just *thinking* about it now.

Ugh, control. That's a big word. And honestly? It felt…slippery. Like trying to hold onto a greased watermelon.

At first, yeah, I thought I was totally in charge. I was picking the parents, right? I had the list, I was making the decisions. I was all, "I want a couple who likes music and isn't super religious and has a dog." Like I was ordering a pizza.

But then it got…more complicated. Meeting Mark and Vanessa, talking to them, realizing they were *real* people with real lives and real hopes…it messed with my head. It wasn't just about finding the "perfect" parents anymore. It was about what was best for the baby, and what was best for *them*.

And Annie…she was amazing, but she also had her own ideas. She wanted what was best for me, too, which was sweet, but sometimes it felt like she was trying to steer me in a certain direction.

So, did I have control? I guess I had some. I got to choose who the baby went to. But it wasn't as simple as I thought it would be. It was more about finding the right fit, and letting go of my own expectations.

It was scary, honestly. Giving up a baby is hard enough, but giving up control too? That was a whole other level of terrifying. But in the end, I think it was the right thing to do. I trusted my gut, and I trusted Annie, and I trusted Mark and Vanessa. And that's all I could do.

It wasn't about *me* being in control. It was about the baby having the best life possible. And that's what mattered. Even if it meant letting go of a little bit of my own power.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the big one, isn't it? The question everyone always wants to ask. And honestly? It still gets me sometimes.

It's not like it's a decision you just *make* and then forget about. It's…it's always there. A little ache, a little what-if.

But yeah. I would. I would make the same decision.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And there were a lot of times I doubted myself, a lot of times I wanted to just…keep her. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do.

I was a kid. Sixteen years old. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being ready to raise a baby. Paul and Vanessa…they were ready. They were excited. They could give her a life I just couldn't. A stable, loving life.

And it wasn't about me not loving her. It was about loving her enough to want the best for her. And the best for her wasn't with me, at that time.

It's still hard to talk about. It still makes me sad sometimes. But I know she's happy. I know she's loved. And that's all that matters.

I've grown a lot since then. I've learned a lot about myself. And I think…I think I needed to go through that experience to become the person I am today.

So yeah. I would make the same decision. It was the right thing to do. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

And honestly? I wouldn't trade it for the world. Because it taught me a lot about love, and loss, and the importance of making tough choices. And that's something you can't learn in school.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a tough one. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't like, "Okay, baby's gone, back to normal." It was…messy. Really messy.

For a while, I just felt…empty. Like a big hole had been ripped open inside me. I kept expecting to feel something, *anything*, and it was just…nothing. Which was almost worse.

I leaned on a lot of things. Paul, obviously. He was…good. He didn't try to fix me or tell me how I *should* be feeling. He just…listened. And made me hot chocolate. A lot of hot chocolate.

And my dad. He's not always the most emotionally available person, but he tried. He took me on drives and we just…sat there. In silence. Which, for my dad, is a big deal.

I also wrote a lot. Just…stream of consciousness stuff. It was mostly just complaining, to be honest. But it helped to get it out of my head.

There were days where I just wanted to curl up in bed and never get out. Days where I cried for no reason. Days where I was just…angry. At myself, at the situation, at everything.

It took a long time to realize that it was okay to grieve. Even though I knew I was doing the right thing, even though I *wanted* the baby to have a good life, it still hurt. A lot.

I think the biggest thing was realizing that it didn't mean I wasn't a good person. It didn't mean I didn't care. It just meant I wasn't ready to be a mom. And that was okay.

It still comes up sometimes. A random song on the radio, or seeing a baby in the grocery store. It's a little pang of sadness. But it's not as overwhelming as it used to be.

I think…I think I learned a lot about myself through all of it. About what I want, about what I'm capable of, about what's important to me. And that's something I wouldn't trade for anything.

It was hard. Really hard. But I got through it. And I think…I think I'm stronger for it.



It's not a story with a neat little bow on top, you know? It's just…life. And life is messy.

Ugh, yeah. Okay, so it wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, alright? People think adoption is just, like, handing over a baby and everyone's happy. It's way more complicated than that.

With Mark and Vanessa, they were…perfect. On paper. Successful, stable, wanted a kid. But "perfect" doesn't always mean easy.

The biggest thing was expectations. They had this *vision* of what their life with the baby would be like. And it didn't necessarily match up with reality. They wanted to be involved in everything, which was good, but sometimes it felt…intense. Like they were already planning the baby's entire life before it was even born.

There were a few times where we had disagreements about things like, what the baby should be named, or how it should be raised. It wasn't a fight, exactly, but it was…awkward. I felt like I was stuck in the middle, trying to navigate their feelings and my own.

And then there was the whole open adoption thing. They wanted to stay in touch, see the baby, be a part of its life. Which I was okay with, mostly. But it was scary, you know? Giving up a baby is hard enough, but giving up a baby and still having to see it…that's a whole other level of emotional mess.

I remember one conversation where Vanessa was talking about picking out baby clothes, and it just hit me. This wasn't just a theoretical baby anymore. This was a real person, and they were going to be raising it. And I wasn't.

It was hard. Really hard. But Mark and Vanessa were good people. They were genuinely excited about becoming parents, and they were committed to giving the baby a good life. And ultimately, that's all that mattered.

It just took a lot of communication, and a lot of honesty, to work through those challenges. And a lot of deep breaths. And maybe a few cheesy tater tots. You know, for emotional support.

Ugh. Okay, that's…still a tough one to talk about. It wasn't easy, okay? It wasn't like some clean, simple decision.

Paulie…he was a good guy. A little clueless, maybe, and definitely not ready to be a dad. But good. And he wanted to be involved. He *really* did. And for a while, I thought maybe…maybe we could make it work. Like, co-parenting or something.

But then I realized…it wasn't about him. It wasn't about what *he* wanted. It was about the baby. And what was best for the baby.

And I just…I couldn't see a situation where he could be a consistent, reliable presence in that baby's life. He was going to go back to finishing school, chasing his music dreams…he wasn't ready to settle down. And that's okay for *him*, but it wouldn't be fair to the kid.

So, I made the decision to move forward with the adoption without him. It was hard. Telling him was awful. He was hurt, and I felt terrible. But I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about punishing him or anything. It was about protecting the baby. And finding a family who could give that baby everything they needed. A stable home, loving parents, a good life.

I still think about him sometimes. I hope he's doing okay. But I don't regret my decision. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was the right thing.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted either, you know? It was about putting the baby first. And sometimes, that means making really difficult choices. Choices that hurt. But choices that are necessary.

It's just…complicated. It still is.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a tough one to talk about. It wasn't like a sudden decision, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and was all, "Yep, giving the baby away!" It was…a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, I was just…freaked out. Totally and completely freaked out. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to *eat* for dinner, let alone raise a human being. I wasn't ready. I didn't have a plan. I didn't have anything.

And then I started thinking about what would be best for the baby. I mean, I could try to keep it, but would that be fair? Could I give it the life it deserved? I wasn't exactly rolling in money, and my parents…well, they were great, but they had their own stuff going on.

I talked to Paul a lot. And Annie. They were really supportive, but they also made me think about things I hadn't considered. Like, what kind of future I wanted for myself, and what kind of future I wanted for the baby.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were…amazing. They were so excited about the idea of having a baby, and they were so prepared. They had a beautiful home, and they were just…good people.

It wasn't about finding a "perfect" family. It was about finding a family that could give the baby everything I couldn't. A stable home, financial security, a loving environment.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. And it still hurts sometimes. But I knew, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

It wasn't giving up on the baby. It was giving the baby a chance. A better chance. And that's what mattered.



It's still…a lot to unpack, even now. But that's the gist of it. It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. I think. I hope.

Ugh. Okay. That's…the hard part. The part I don't really like talking about, honestly. But you asked.

It wasn't…easy. Not even a little bit. People kept saying, "You're so brave," and I wanted to punch them. Brave had nothing to do with it. It was just…what I had to do. What was best for the baby. But knowing that didn't make it hurt any less.

At first, it was just…numbness. Like, I was going through the motions, but I didn't really *feel* anything. And then, after…after she was born and I handed her over to Mark and Vanessa…it hit me. Like a ton of bricks.

I cried. A lot. Like, ugly crying. For days. I couldn't eat, I couldn't sleep, I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear.

Paul was really good, actually. He didn't try to fix things or tell me it would be okay. He just…sat with me. And listened. And brought me cheesy tater tots, which, surprisingly, helped.

Bren and my dad were also there for me. They didn't always understand, but they tried. And that meant a lot.

I started writing in a journal. Just…dumping all my feelings onto the page. It helped to get it out of my head. And I talked to a therapist. Which, yeah, was kinda awkward at first, but she was really good. She helped me process everything.

It wasn't about "getting over" it. It was about learning to live with it. Learning to accept that I had made a difficult decision, and that it was the right decision, even though it hurt like hell.

And it was about remembering that I wasn't losing a baby, I was *giving* a baby a life. A good life. With parents who wanted her and could give her everything I couldn't.

It still stings sometimes. I still think about her. But it gets easier. And I know that she's happy. And that's all that really matters.

It's…a long process. And it's not something you just "get over." But you learn to live with the sadness. And you learn to find joy in other things. And you learn that you're stronger than you thought you were.

It's just…complicated. And messy. And real. And that's okay.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a tough one. It wasn't simple, you know? It wasn't like in a movie where everything's all warm and fuzzy and everyone cries happy tears. It was...real.

Mark and Vanessa, they were...good people. Really good. They were just...different than I expected. I pictured, like, a perfect, picture-book family. And they were...quirky. Mark was obsessed with pottery, and Vanessa was super into organic gardening. It was a little intense.

At first, it was awkward. Really awkward. I was a teenager, they were older, and we were all navigating this really weird situation. I was giving them their baby, and they were trying to be supportive of me, but it was hard to connect. I felt like I was being interviewed, you know? Like they were checking me out to make sure I was "worthy" or something.

But then, as things went on, it started to change. We started talking more. Not just about the baby, but about our lives. I learned about their struggles with infertility, and they learned about my…everything. My dad, my stepmom, Paul…the whole mess.

They were really understanding, actually. They didn't judge me for my choices. They just wanted to make sure I was okay. And they were genuinely excited about the baby.

After the baby was born, and I handed her over…that was the hardest part. It was like a piece of me was being ripped away. But Mark and Vanessa were so gentle and loving. They made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

We stayed in touch, you know? They sent me pictures and updates. I went to visit a few times. It wasn't the same as being a mom, but it was…good. It was a different kind of connection.

I think they helped me realize that family isn't just about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other. And they gave that baby a really good home. That's all I ever wanted.

It was complicated, messy, and sometimes heartbreaking. But it was also beautiful. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what it means to be a family.



It still makes me think sometimes, you know? But I know I made the right decision. And I'm grateful for Mark and Vanessa. They were good to me, and they gave my baby a good life.

Ugh. Okay. Yeah. That's...a big question. And honestly? It's still kinda raw, even after all this time.

Has it changed me? Are you kidding? It completely flipped my world upside down. Before, I was just...Juno. A sarcastic, music-obsessed teenager who was mostly concerned with avoiding gym class and finding the perfect vintage record. I had plans, you know? Vague plans, but plans nonetheless.

Then, boom. Positive pregnancy test. And suddenly, all those plans went out the window. I had to grow up, like, *fast*. I had to make decisions that no sixteen-year-old should have to make.

It forced me to confront things I wasn't ready for. Responsibility. Maturity. The complexities of love and family. It made me realize that life isn't always fair, and that sometimes, things happen that you can't control.

I think it made me stronger, in a way. I had to be. I had to advocate for myself, and for the baby. I had to learn to trust my instincts, and to stand up for what I believed in.

But it also made me more vulnerable. It stripped away a lot of my defenses. It forced me to be honest with myself, and with the people around me.

I'm not the same person I was before. I'm more aware of the world, more compassionate, and more grateful for the good things in my life. I'm still sarcastic and a little bit cynical, but underneath it all, I think I'm a better person because of it.

It wasn't easy. It's still not easy. But I wouldn't trade the experience for anything. It taught me a lot about myself, and about what really matters in life. And it led me to Mark and Vanessa, and to a future I never could have imagined.

So yeah. It changed me. A lot. And I think, ultimately, it changed me for the better. Even if it was the hardest thing I've ever had to go through.

Ugh. Okay, *that*. That was…the worst part, honestly. Worse than the morning sickness, worse than the doctor's appointments, even worse than having to tell my parents. It was like, suddenly everyone in Beaverton had an opinion on my life. And none of them were very nice.

It started small, you know? Whispers in the hallway at school. People staring. Then it got louder. People actually *talking* about it. Making up stories. Saying things that weren't true. It was mortifying.

I tried to ignore it at first. Just pretend it wasn't happening. But that didn't work. It just made me feel more isolated and ashamed.

Then I started getting angry. Really angry. I wanted to yell at everyone, to tell them to mind their own business. But I knew that would just make things worse.

So, I did what I always do when I'm feeling overwhelmed: I leaned on my friends. Paulie and Leah were amazing. They defended me, they made me laugh, and they reminded me that I wasn't alone.

And then…I just started being myself. I didn't try to hide or apologize for being pregnant. I just went to school, I hung out with my friends, and I tried to live my life as normally as possible.

It didn't stop the rumors completely, but it did make them less painful. People eventually got bored, I guess. Or maybe they realized that I wasn't going to break down and cry in the hallway.

I also learned something important: people are always going to talk. You can't control what they say, but you can control how you react to it. And you can choose to surround yourself with people who support you and believe in you.

It was a tough time, but I got through it. And honestly, it made me stronger. It taught me to stand up for myself and to not care what other people think. Which is a pretty valuable lesson, you know? Even if it took a pregnancy to learn it.

Ugh. Okay. Here we go. This is…the big one, isn’t it? The question everyone wants to ask. It’s not easy to talk about, but…okay.

It wasn’t one big moment, you know? It wasn’t like I woke up one day and suddenly decided. It was a lot of thinking. A lot of talking to Paul and Vanessa. A lot of staring at the ceiling at 3 AM, trying to figure out my life.

I was sixteen. *Sixteen*. I was still figuring out what I wanted to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I was still in high school. I had plans. Not, like, super concrete plans, but I wanted to go to college. I wanted to write. I wanted to…just *be* me, without being responsible for another person.

And it wasn’t that I didn’t want a baby. I did. I loved her already, even before she was born. But I knew I couldn’t give her what she deserved. I couldn’t give her a stable home, a secure future, two parents who were actually ready to be parents.

Vanessa and Mark…they were perfect. They were older, they were financially stable, they were desperate to have a baby. They were good people. And they wanted her. They wanted to love her and raise her and give her everything I couldn’t.

It was the hardest decision I’ve ever made. It still is. There are days when I wonder what my life would be like if I’d kept her. But I know, deep down, that I made the right choice. For her. And for me.

It wasn’t about giving her up. It was about giving her a life. A good life. And that’s what mattered most.

It’s…it’s complicated. And it still hurts sometimes. But I’m okay. I’m learning to live with it. And I know she’s happy. And that’s all that really matters.



It’s not a story with a neat little ending. It’s messy and complicated and real. And it’s my story.

Ugh. Okay, that's…a good question. A hard one, but a good one. It wasn't, like, the birth or anything. I mean, that was scary, obviously, but I knew I could handle it. It was what came *after*.

My biggest fear? That they wouldn't…love the baby enough.

I know, it sounds stupid. I was giving them a gift, right? A whole little person. But what if they weren't ready? What if they regretted it? What if they were just…disappointed?

I spent so much time picking out the perfect couple, Mark and Vanessa. They seemed so…normal. And perfect. And I was worried that I wasn't perfect enough for them. That the baby wouldn't be perfect enough. 

I kept imagining them looking at the baby and thinking, "This isn't what we expected." Or, "This is too much." It was a really messed up thing to worry about, I know. But I couldn't help it.

I wanted them to be happy. I wanted the baby to be happy. And I was terrified that I was messing everything up. That I was making a mistake.

It was a lot of pressure, you know? Trying to be responsible and selfless and make the right decision. And all the while, being a mess inside.

It took a lot of talking to Paul and my dad to realize that I couldn't control everything. That I had to trust that Mark and Vanessa were good people, and that they would love the baby unconditionally.

And they did. They really did. But that fear…it stuck with me for a long time. It's still there, a little bit, I guess. It's just…hard to let go of something like that.

Ugh, okay, so the Bleeker story. It's...a long one. And kinda embarrassing, if I'm being honest.

It wasn't some deep, meaningful thing, okay? It wasn't like I was channeling the spirit of a great poet or anything. It was just...a moment of panic.

Paulie Bleeker was this guy I knew from school. He was a drummer in a band, and he was...okay. Not my type, really. But he was nice enough. And he had a really distinctive last name.

When I found out I was pregnant, I needed a name for the father in the adoption paperwork. And my brain just completely blanked. I was freaking out, and I couldn't think of anything.

And then, out of nowhere, "Bleeker" just popped into my head. It sounded...normal enough. And it wasn't a name I associated with anyone I actually *knew*. Which was important, because I didn't want to use a real person's name without their permission.

So I wrote it down. And then I just...stuck with it. It felt less weird than making up a completely fake name.

It was a terrible plan, obviously. But it worked. And no one questioned it. Except for maybe Mark, but he didn't push it.

Honestly, I still cringe when I think about it. It was a really impulsive decision. But hey, it got the job done. And it's a good story, I guess. A slightly pathetic story, but a good story nonetheless.

Don't judge me too harshly, okay? I was a teenager. I was stressed. And I was trying to navigate a really complicated situation. I did the best I could.

Ugh, okay, so you wanna know about the whole punk thing? It wasn't like a conscious decision, you know? It wasn't like I sat down and said, "I'm gonna be a punk." It just…happened.

I think it was the honesty, mostly. Everything else felt so fake. Like, everyone was trying so hard to be cool and fit in, and it was exhausting. And then you listen to bands like The Moldy Peaches, or Bikini Kill, and they're just…raw. They're not trying to be anything they're not. They're just saying what they think, even if it's messy and uncomfortable.

And the energy! It's just…loud and angry and defiant. It felt like a way to scream into the void without actually screaming. Which, let's be real, was a pretty appealing option at the time.

It wasn't about the fashion, although the ripped jeans and combat boots were kinda cool. It was about the attitude. It was about rejecting everything that felt wrong with the world. It was about being yourself, even if that meant being an outcast.

My dad gets it, kinda. He was into music when he was younger, different stuff, but he understands the need to express yourself. He just wishes I wouldn't use so much language.

It just felt…right. Like I'd found a place where I could be myself, without having to apologize for it. And honestly, that's a pretty rare thing.

It's not like I'm a hardcore punk or anything. I just appreciate the spirit of it. The DIY ethic. The refusal to conform. It's a good reminder that you don't have to follow the rules if the rules are stupid. And honestly, most of them are.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a heavy one. It's not something I talk about a lot, honestly. It still kinda stings, even after all this time.

My parents’ divorce…it wasn’t like a screaming, fighting kind of divorce. It was more of a slow fade. They just…stopped connecting. Stopped *seeing* each other. It was like they were roommates who just happened to have a kid. And that was…weird. And sad.

It definitely messed with my head, you know? It made me scared of commitment. Like, if two people who are supposed to love each other forever can just…give up, what’s the point of even trying?

I think that’s why I was so hesitant with Paul. He was a good guy, really. Sweet, kind, a little dorky. But I was so afraid of getting hurt, of ending up like my parents. I kept pushing him away, testing him, trying to find a reason to not let myself care.

It also made me really independent. I learned early on that I could only rely on myself. My parents were too wrapped up in their own stuff to really be there for me. So I built up these walls, you know? I became sarcastic and cynical and kinda prickly. It was a defense mechanism.

It took me a long time to realize that my parents’ relationship wasn’t a blueprint for my own. That I could choose to do things differently. That I could find someone who would actually *see* me, and love me for who I am.

And honestly, going through the pregnancy and deciding to give the baby up…that forced me to confront a lot of those issues. It made me realize that love isn’t always about happily ever after. Sometimes, it’s about doing what’s best for everyone involved, even if it’s hard.

So yeah, my parents’ divorce definitely impacted my relationships. It made me scared, independent, and a little bit messed up. But it also taught me a lot about myself, and about what I really want in life. And that’s…something, I guess.



It's still something I'm working through, honestly. It's not like you just get over stuff like that. It just…becomes part of who you are.

Ugh, okay, now you're making me get all introspective. It's kinda embarrassing, honestly. But fine, I'll bite.

I think what made my story…well, not *better*, because that sounds pretentious, but…different, was that it wasn't about the pregnancy itself. It was about everything *around* it.

Like, yeah, I was a teenager who got pregnant. That happens. It's not exactly groundbreaking. But it wasn't a cautionary tale, you know? It wasn't about shame or regret or making the "right" decision. It was about me figuring out what *I* wanted, and then actually going for it.

And it wasn't about finding the perfect family for the baby, either. It was about finding the right *fit*. Mark and Vanessa weren't perfect, but they were real. They were a little bit messy and a little bit weird, just like me.

I think people connected with it because it was honest. I didn't try to be someone I wasn't. I was sarcastic and awkward and a little bit cynical. And I didn't sugarcoat things.

And it wasn't just about me, either. It was about Paul and Vanessa, and even my dad. It was about all of us figuring out how to be better people.

I guess what I'm trying to say is, it wasn't about the situation. It was about the people. And the way they dealt with it. And the fact that even when things are really hard, you can still find humor and hope.

It was just…real. And maybe people were tired of everything being fake.



Ugh, I sound like a movie critic now. I'm gonna stop talking. It's making me blush.

Okay, good friends. That's important. Especially when life is being a total mess, which, let's be real, is most of the time.

I don't need a friend who's gonna tell me everything's gonna be okay, because sometimes it's *not* gonna be okay. I need someone who's gonna sit with me in the mess and be like, "Yeah, this sucks. But we'll get through it."

Honesty is huge. I can handle the truth, even if it's not what I want to hear. Just don't sugarcoat it. I'll figure it out.

And a good sense of humor. Like, someone who can make me laugh when I want to cry. Or just make a really stupid face. That works too.

Someone who doesn't judge me for my weirdness. Because I'm pretty weird. And I'm not gonna pretend to be anything else.

And someone who's a good listener. Not just waiting for their turn to talk, but actually *listening* to what I have to say.

Basically, I need someone who's real. Someone who's not afraid to be themselves, and who accepts me for who I am. Someone who's loyal and supportive and just...there.

It's not about having a ton of friends. It's about having a few really good ones. The kind of friends you can count on, no matter what.

Paul and Leah are like that for me. They're the best. And I'm really lucky to have them.

So yeah. Honesty, humor, acceptance, and loyalty. Those are the things I value in a good friend. And a shared love of The Moldy Peaches doesn't hurt either.

Ugh. Okay, that's...a big one. It's not like it just changed *my* life, you know? It kinda rippled out and messed with everyone else's too.

With my dad, it was...weird at first. He was trying to be supportive, but he's my dad. He's always been kinda clueless. He kept offering to buy me maternity clothes, which was just...no. Eventually, he got it together and actually started being really helpful. He's still clueless sometimes, but he means well.

My mom was...intense. She wanted to be involved in everything, which I appreciated, but it was also kinda suffocating. She kept trying to plan the nursery and pick out names. I had to set some boundaries, which was hard, but necessary.

Paul…that was the hardest part. We were just kids. And suddenly, we were facing this huge responsibility. It was scary and overwhelming. We fought a lot. We had to figure out what we wanted, what we could handle, and what was best for the baby. It wasn't always pretty.

And then there was Leah. My best friend. She was amazing. She didn't judge me, she just supported me. She helped me with everything, from doctor's appointments to picking out baby names. She was my rock. But even with her, things were different. I was changing, and she was trying to understand.

It made me realize that relationships are complicated. They require work and communication and a willingness to compromise. And sometimes, even with all that, things still fall apart.

It also made me appreciate the people who stuck by me. The ones who didn't judge me or abandon me. They're the ones who really matter.

It wasn't easy, but it taught me a lot about myself and about the people in my life. And it made me realize that even when things are messy and complicated, there's still hope. And love. And a whole lot of awkwardness.

Okay, so you want to know what makes me, me? That's...a big question. It's not like I have a whole philosophy worked out or anything. I'm still figuring things out, you know? But here's what I've landed on so far.

First off: **honesty.** I really value people being straight with me. No BS. Life's too short for fake smiles and empty promises. I try to be honest myself, even when it's awkward. Which is, like, all the time.

Then there's **independence.** I don't want to rely on anyone else to make me happy or to fix my problems. I want to be able to take care of myself and make my own decisions. It's not always easy, but it's important.

I also believe in **being true to yourself.** Don't try to be someone you're not just to fit in or to please other people. Embrace your weirdness, your flaws, your quirks. That's what makes you unique.

And **kindness.** It sounds cheesy, I know. But it's important to be kind to other people, even when they don't deserve it. You never know what someone else is going through.

I also think it's important to **question everything.** Don't just accept things at face value. Ask why. Challenge assumptions. Think for yourself.

And finally, **finding the humor in things.** Life is messy and complicated and sometimes really awful. But if you can't laugh at it, you'll just go crazy.

Those are kinda my core beliefs, I guess. They're not written in stone or anything. They're just...what I've learned so far. And they're probably still evolving.

It's all about figuring out what's important to you and living your life accordingly. And trying not to screw things up too badly along the way.



Honestly, it's a work in progress. But that's okay. We're all works in progress, right?

Ugh, okay, the name. That was…a process. A surprisingly emotional process, actually. It wasn't like, "Oh, let's pick something cute!" It was way more complicated than that.

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who were adopting him, they had some ideas, obviously. But they wanted my input too, which was…nice. And kinda terrifying. It felt like a huge responsibility.

I went through a *ton* of names. Like, seriously. I made lists and lists. I wanted something that wasn't too common, but not too weird either. Something that sounded good, but also had a good meaning. It's a lot to ask of a name, honestly.

We were tossing around a lot of stuff, and then Vanessa suggested **Henry**. And it just…clicked.

It wasn't a family name for either of them, which I thought was good. It felt like a fresh start. And it means "ruler of the home," which is kinda sweet, right? Like, he's gonna be loved and taken care of.

But the real reason I liked it…was because it sounded like a good, solid name. Like a name for a kid who's gonna be brave and kind and a little bit quirky. A name that fits a real person.

It felt…right. And that's what mattered. It wasn't about finding the perfect name, it was about finding a name that felt like *him*. Even though I hadn't even met him yet.

It was a weird feeling, you know? Choosing a name for someone you're giving up. But it also felt…important. Like I was giving him a good start in life.

So yeah, Henry. It's a good name. I still think about it sometimes. And I hope he likes it.

Ugh, okay, deep thoughts time. Don't judge. It's been a while since I've really *thought* about all of it, you know? It was...a lot.

The biggest thing I learned? I'm way stronger than I thought I was. Like, seriously. Before all this, I was just trying to get through high school without being totally weird. And then suddenly, I was making this huge decision, about a whole other person's life. It was terrifying. But I did it. And I didn't fall apart. Not completely, anyway.

I also learned that the world isn't as black and white as I thought it was. People are messy and complicated. Paul and Mark, they weren't perfect. Annie and Vanessa, they weren't perfect either. But they were good people, trying to do the right thing. And sometimes, the right thing isn't easy.

I realized that "family" doesn't always mean blood. It means the people who love you and support you, no matter what. Annie and Vanessa, they became my family. And even Paul, in his own weird way, he was part of it too.

And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I tried to be all independent and tough, but I couldn't have done it without my friends and family. They were there for me, even when I was being a total mess.

It also taught me a lot about responsibility. It's one thing to think about having a baby, it's another thing to actually be pregnant and realize what's at stake. It made me grow up, a little bit.

Honestly, it was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was also the most rewarding. I gave a baby a good life, and I learned a lot about myself in the process. I figured out what I wanted, what I didn't want, and who I was. And that's a pretty good thing, you know?

It wasn't a fairytale. It was messy and complicated and sometimes really sad. But it was real. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the cheesy tater tots. Okay, maybe I would trade it for a lifetime supply of cheesy tater tots. But almost not.

Ugh. Okay. That's…a big question. And it's one I've thought about a *lot*. Like, a ridiculous amount. Especially late at night when I can't sleep.

Honestly? There are a million little things. I probably would have been nicer to my dad, at least some of the time. He was trying, even if he was being…my dad. And maybe I would have spent less time trying to be cool and more time just being…me. Whatever that even means.

But the big stuff? I don't know. I really don't.

I think if I had made a different decision about the adoption, things would have been…different. Not necessarily better, not necessarily worse. Just different. And that's kinda scary to think about.

I was so determined to be independent, to prove I could handle everything on my own. And I did, in a way. But I also pushed a lot of people away. Paul, even. I was so afraid of getting hurt that I didn't let myself get close to anyone.

Looking back, I wish I had let myself lean on people more. Let them help me. It's okay to ask for help, you know? It doesn't make you weak.

But then again, maybe I needed to go through all of that on my own. Maybe I needed to learn those lessons the hard way. Maybe it made me stronger.

I don't know. It's all just…complicated.

I guess if I could go back and change one thing, it would be to just…breathe. To not worry so much. To trust that things would work out, even if they didn't go exactly as planned.

Because life is messy and unpredictable. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go and see where it takes you.

It was a weird, intense, life-changing experience. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the awkward conversations and the questionable music choices. It made me who I am. And that's…okay. I think.

Ugh, disappointment. Yeah, I know that feeling *really* well. Like, intimately. It's kinda my specialty, honestly. Life throws a lot of curveballs, and I've definitely been hit by a few.

The thing is, you can't control everything. No matter how much you plan, or how much you want something to happen, things are gonna go sideways. It's just a fact of life. And getting all worked up about it doesn't help. It just makes you feel worse.

So, what do I do? Well, first, I let myself be bummed out for a little bit. Like, a good wallow session. Listen to sad music, eat some junk food, maybe cry a little. It's okay to feel your feelings. Don't try to bottle them up.

But then, you gotta pick yourself up and move on. You gotta realize that this one disappointment doesn't define you. It doesn't mean you're a failure. It just means things didn't work out the way you wanted them to.

And sometimes, things not going as planned is actually a good thing. It forces you to re-evaluate your priorities, to try new things, to grow as a person.

I learned that the hard way, you know? With the whole baby thing. It wasn't what I expected my life to be like. But it ended up being...okay. More than okay, actually.

So, yeah. Disappointment sucks. But you gotta roll with the punches. You gotta find the silver lining. And you gotta remember that you're stronger than you think.

And maybe listen to The Moldy Peaches. They're good for wallowing *and* picking yourself back up. It's a win-win.

Ugh, Leah. Okay, so, our friendship…it was a mess for a while, honestly. It started out as just…being friends. We’d been friends since, like, forever. Sharing secrets, gossiping, doing all the normal teenage girl stuff. But then everything happened with the baby, and it just…shifted.

At first, she was super supportive. Like, really supportive. She was the one who went with me to the doctor, and she helped me look through the adoption listings. But then she started getting…weird. She started wanting to be involved in *everything*. Picking out names, decorating the nursery, even trying to pick the adoptive parents. It was like she was trying to live her life through my pregnancy.

And I got annoyed. Really annoyed. It felt like she wasn’t seeing *me* anymore, just seeing this…project. Like I was a vessel for her own feelings and desires. I mean, she was dealing with her own stuff, her dad and all that, but it wasn’t about her. It was about *my* baby.

We had that huge fight at the arcade, right? That was…rough. I said some things I probably shouldn’t have, and she said some things too. It felt like we were completely over.

But then, after I met Mark and Vanessa, and I started to realize I was actually going to go through with the adoption, I realized I needed Leah. Not to make decisions for me, but just to be there. To be my friend.

She came around, eventually. She apologized, and I apologized too. We just…talked. Really talked. And we realized that we both just wanted what was best for the baby, and for each other.

It wasn’t the same friendship as before, not exactly. It was…more mature, I guess. We learned to respect each other’s boundaries and to support each other without trying to control each other.

It was messy, and complicated, and sometimes really frustrating. But in the end, our friendship survived. And that’s what mattered. Because even though I was going through this crazy thing on my own, I still needed my best friend. And she was still my best friend, even if she was a little bit of a mess sometimes. Just like me.

Ugh. Okay, don't get me wrong, it wasn't exactly a picnic. Morning sickness? More like all-day sickness. And the cravings? Don't even get me started on the pickle and mustard phase. It was…a lot.

But if I had to pick a favorite part…it was the feeling of…well, connection. I know that sounds super cheesy, but it's true. Like, there was this little person *inside* me, growing and kicking and just…being. And it was weird and amazing and kinda terrifying all at the same time.

It made me think about things differently. About responsibility and the future and what it means to be a parent. It forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not.

And honestly, the kicks were kinda cool. Like, a little secret language between me and the baby. It was a reminder that even though I was a mess, and my life was kinda falling apart, there was something good happening. Something beautiful.

It wasn't about *wanting* to be pregnant, you know? It was about accepting it and making the best of it. And finding a little bit of joy in the midst of the chaos.

It was also kinda nice to have an excuse to eat whatever I wanted. But mostly, it was the connection. That's what I'll remember. And the kicks. Definitely the kicks.



It's hard to explain. It was just…a feeling. A weird, wonderful, complicated feeling. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Even the pickle and mustard. Okay, maybe I would trade the pickle and mustard. But not much else.
